document.body:
111-12008-August. New records added to the Supportive and Palliative Care Library

NATIONAL LIBRARY OF GUIDELINES

 

Patient Safety Guidance

  • Technical patient safety solutions for ventilator-associated pneumonia in adults. NICE Patient Safety Guidance 2. Published 27 August 2008.

 

Dept of Health

  • Updated national guidance on the safe administration of intrathecal chemotherapy, Published 11th August 2008.
    (This guideline updates and replaces the October 2003 guideline of the same title).

 

American Society of Clinical Oncology

  • 2007 clinical practice guideline update on the role of bisphosphonates in multiple myeloma. Published 21 May 2007.

 

Mayo Clinic College of Medicine (USA)

  • Mayo clinic consensus statement for the use of bisphosphonates in multiple myeloma. Published August 2006.

 

UKCCSG-PONF Mouth Care Group

  • Mouth care for children and young people with cancer : evidence-based guidelines. Published February 2006.

 

NHS Quality Improvement Scotland

  • Best practice statement : working with dependent older people to achieve good oral health. Published May 2005.

 

DATABASE OF ABSTRACTS OF REVIEWS OF EFFECTS (DARE)

  • A systematic literature review of the clinical and cost-effectiveness of hadron therapy in cancer
  • A systematic review and economic model of the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of docetaxel in combination with prednisone or prednisolone for the treatment of hormone-refractory metastatic prostate cancer
  • Clinical effects of reminiscence therapy in older adults: a meta-analysis of controlled trials
  • Do the benefits of anti-dementia drugs extend to caregivers?
  • Does religious activity improve health outcomes: a critical review of the recent literature
  • Does this patient have dementia?
  • Effects of music listening on adult patients' pre-procedural state anxiety in hospital
  • Efficacy of group psychotherapy to reduce depressive symptoms among HIV-infected individuals: a systematic review and meta-analysis
  • Meta-analyses of chemotherapy for locally advanced and metastatic pancreatic cancer
  • Preventive intervention possibilities in radiotherapy- and chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis: results of meta-analyses
  • Survival in cancer patients undergoing in-hospital cardiopulmonary resuscitation: a meta-analysis
  • Systematic review of the effects of chronic disease management on quality-of-life in people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
  • Systematic review: the evidence that publishing patient care performance data improves quality of care
  • The effectiveness of Web-based vs. non-Web-based interventions: a meta-analysis of behavioral change outcomes.
  • The role of intraperitoneal chemotherapy in the first-line treatment of women with stage III epithelial ovarian cancer: a clinical practice guideline

 

OTHER

  • Bereavement Advice Centre [website]
  • Mapping global health inequalities: challenges and opportunities [Public Health SL]

DATABASE OF ABSTRACTS OF REVIEWS OF EFFECTS (DARE)

NHS ECONOMIC EVALUATION DATABASE (NEED)

document.body:
111-12009-November. New records added to the Supportive and Palliative Care specialist collection

National Library of Guidelines

NICE: all guidance published 25 November 2009

  • Topotecan for the treatment of relapsed small-cell lung cancer. NICE Technology Appraisal Guidance 184. Published 25 November 2009


British National Formulary for Children – all published 10 July 2009:

  • Acute diarrhoea
  • Laxatives
  • Stoma and enteral feeding tubes


Clinical Knowledge Summaries (CKS)

  • Tiredness/fatigue in adults: Tiredness/fatigue in adults
  • Tiredness/fatigue in adults

 

Health Technology Assessments (HTA)

  • Aromatherapy for pain relief and psychological problems. Systematic review
  • Avastin (bevacizumab) (Genentech Inc.) for metastatic breast cancer
  • Avastin (bevacizumab) for the treatment of ovarian cancer
  • Bach flower remedies for pain relief and psychological problems. Systematic review
  • Bevacizumab for the treatment of patients with advanced colorectal cancer
  • Bexxar (tositumomab and iodine-131 tositumomab) (GlaxoSmithKline) for treatment of refractory or relapsed non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL)
  • Calypso 4D localization system (Calypso Medical Technologies Inc.) for guidance of prostate cancer radiation therapy
  • Cancer antigen 15-3 (CA 15-3) for breast cancer prognosis
  • Cancer antigen 27.29 (CA 27.29) for diagnosis, staging, and treatment monitoring of breast cancer
  • CellSearch circulating tumor cell kit (Veridex LLC) for monitoring breast cancer
  • Cetuximab for the management of advanced colorectal cancer
  • ChemoFX assay (Precision Therapeutics Inc.) for prediction of response to chemotherapy
  • Colon hydrotherapy for defecation disorders. Systematic Review

  • Effectiveness of lenalidomide in multiple myeloma patients

  • Helical tomotherapy (TomoTherapy Hi-Art System) for non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)
  • HER2 testing to manage patients with breast or other solid tumors

  • Improving the evaluation of therapeutic interventions in multiple sclerosis: the role of new psychometric methods
  • Intensity modulated radiotherapy (IMRT) for prostate cancer
  • Intradialytic parenteral nutrition (IDPN) for end-stage renal disease in adults
  • Intraoperative radiotherapy for primary breast cancer. Systematic Review

  • Lapatinib in breast cancer
  • Motor cortex stimulation in the treatment of central and neuropathic pain
  • Non-drug therapies in Alzheimer's disease
  • Optimal management of lymphedema secondary to breast cancer treatment (project)

  • Prevention of ventilator-associated pneumonia
  • Renal replacement therapy in advanced chronic kidney disease. Review of the starting criteria in dialysis programs and assessment of the efficacy and effectiveness of an early start
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy in breast cancer management (project)
  • Spinal cord stimulation for chronic pain of neuropathic or ischaemic origin: systematic review and economic evaluation
  • Sunitinib for the management of renal cell carcinoma
  • Sunitinib in metastatic renal-cell cancer: efficacy and safety
  • Systematic guideline search and appraisal for the DMP "Asthma/COPD"
  • Systematic guideline search and appraisal for the DMP "Breast cancer"

  • T-cell vaccines for the treatment of multiple sclerosis
  • Time to full publication of studies of anti-cancer medicines for breast cancer, and the potential for publication bias: a short systematic review
  • Towards accreditation of teams fighting cancer. Lessons learned from the international literature (project)
  • Usefulness of high-intensity focused ultrasound in prostate cancer
  • Usefulness of multislice computed tomography for the assessment of liver metastases
  • Usefulness of real-time PCR for the monitoring of chronic myeloid leukemia patient
  • Usefulness of real-time PCR in acute promyelocytic leukemia patient monitoring


Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects (DARE)

  • A systematic review of quality of life associated with standard chemotherapy regimens for advanced non-small cell lung cancer

  • How effective are patient-based educational interventions in the management of cancer pain: systematic review and meta-analysis
  • Massage therapy for cancer palliation and supportive care: a systematic review of randomised clinical trials
  • Meta-analysis of pre-operative aromatase inhibitor versus tamoxifen in postmenopausal woman with hormone receptor-positive breast cancer
  • Risk of valvular heart disease associated with the use of dopamine agonists in Parkinson's disease: a systematic review
  • Staging investigations for oesophageal cancer: a meta-analysis
  • The use of aromatherapy to treat behavioural problems in dementia
  • UK self-care support initiatives for older patients with long-term conditions: a review
     

 

UK DUETs (Database of Uncertainties of the Effects of Treatments)

  • Chinese medicinal herbs for alleviating chemotherapy-induced short term side effects in breast cancer patients
  • Covered versus uncovered metal palliative biliary stents for obstructing pancreatic carcinoma
  • Cryotherapy for hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Decision aids and the effect on choice for surgery and knowledge of treatment options for breast cancer patients
  • Management of lymphoedema following surgery for breast cancer
  • Metal versus plastic palliative biliary stents for obstructing pancreatic carcinoma in patients with a life expectancy of less than six months
  • Palliative endobronchial brachytherapy for non-small cell lung cancer
  • Perflouro alkoxy plastic versus metal palliative biliary stents for obstructing pancreatic carcinoma
  • Polymer-based oral rehydration solution versus ORS ≤ 270 for acute watery diarrhoea
  • Prevention of lymphoedema following surgery for breast cancer
  • Selective internal radiation therapy in combination with chemotherapy as front-line therapy for liver metastases from colorectal cancer
  • Self-expanding metal stent insertion versus non-stent therapy or combination non-stent and stent therapy for dysphagia in oesophageal cancer
  • Stainless-steel alloy versus nickel-titanium alloy endoscopic palliative biliary stents for obstructing pancreatic carcinoma
  • Pemetrexed disodium in combination with cisplatin versus other cytotoxic agents or supportive care for the treatment of malignant pleural mesothelioma
  • Treatment of constipation on the number of urinary incontinence episodes in frail elderly people
  • What clinical and patient characteristics determine the effectiveness and acceptability of treatment and management strategies for neurogenic bladder dysfunction in multiple sclerosis?
  • What therapy can reduce neurological pain triggered by urinary incontinence in multiple sclerosis?

NHS Economic Evaluation Database (NEED)

  • A 1-year prospective cost-effectiveness analysis of roflumilast for the treatment of patients with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
  • A cost-effective analysis of adjuvant therapies for the treatment of stage I endometrial adenocarcinoma
  • Cost-effectiveness of 99mTc-sestamibi in predicting response to chemotherapy in patients with lung cancer: systematic review and meta-analysis
  • Cost-effectiveness of cetuximab in combination with irinotecan compared with current care in metastatic colorectal cancer after failure on irinotecan: a Belgian analysis
  • Economic analysis of esophageal stenting for management of malignant dysphagia
  • Primary surgery versus chemoradiation in the treatment of IB2 cervical carcinoma: a cost effectiveness analysis
  • Trastuzumab in early stage breast cancer: a cost-effectiveness analysis for Belgium

 

Recent items of evidence news from the collection's RSS feed

 

Morphine 'might spread cancer'

25 November 2009, 15:15:21 | BBC

"Laboratory tests suggest morphine could in fact encourage the spread of cancer, for which it is routinely prescribed to relieve pain from surgery and tumours. US scientists say the opiate promotes the growth of new blood vessels which deliver tumours oxygen and nutrients."

 

Annual Evidence Update - Supportive and pallaitive care in chronic lung disease

23 November 2009, 13:31:24 | Richard Stevens, NHS Evidence

"The Annual Evidence Update on supportive and palliative care in chronic lung disease collects together the best new knowledge covering two key symptoms which affect most patients - cough and dyspnoea (breathlessness). Our review of the literature encompasses recent advances in our understanding of the mechanisms of these symptoms as well as their management using drugs, physical, nursing and other non-pharmacological methods."

 

Women denied cancer drug that could extend life

20 November 2009, 11:34:54 | Sarah Boseley, Guardian

"A drug which can give women with advanced breast cancer extra weeks or months of life has been turned down by a government watchdog body for use in the NHS...The National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (Nice) says it proposes to reject Tyverb (lapatinib) in spite of changes in the rules brought in specifically to allow people at the end of their lives to have the chance of new and often expensive treatments."

 

Ketamine causes memory loss research finds

20 November 2009, 11:30:47 | Telegraph

"A study of frequent users found the drug had a ''profound'' impact on short and long-term memory...Users became ''dissociated'' in their day-to-day lives and struggled to remember names and conversations."

 

Dementia patient care criticised

20 November 2009, 11:29:37 | BBC

"Half of all dementia patients leave hospital in a worse state than when they arrive, it is claimed."

 

National CJD Surveillance Unit publishes 17th Annual Report for 2008

13 November 2009, 13:48:54 | Dept of Health

"The report looks back over the period from May 1990 (when the Unit was set up) to 31 December 2008. The report outlines the Unit’s work in the clinical surveillance of variant (vCJD), sporadic and iatrogenic CJD."

 

Government takes action on antipsychotic drugs and dementia

13 November 2009, 13:46:06 | Dept of Health

"A tough new action plan to tackle the over prescribing of antipsychotic drugs to people with dementia was today announced by Care Services Minister Phil Hope...The action plan responds to an independent review by Professor Sube Banerjee, commissioned by the Department of Health. Professor Banerjee’s review shows that too many people with dementia are routinely prescribed antipsychotic drugs to treat aggression and agitation, contrary to National Institute of Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) guidance."

 

Drug 'shrinks lung cancer tumour'

13 November 2009, 13:25:47 | BBC

"Scientists have identified a drug which may offer hope to patients with a particularly lethal form of lung cancer...The drug eliminated small cell lung cancer tumours in 50% of mice, and blocked the cells' ability to resist standard chemotherapy treatment."

]]>

document.body:

Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects (DARE)

  • A meta-analysis on the efficacy of oral theophylline in patients with stable COPD

  • Bone health in postmenopausal women with early breast cancer: how protective is tamoxifen?

  • Effectiveness of nonpharmacological interventions in delaying the institutionalization of patients with dementia: a meta-analysis

  • Home-based telehealth: a review and meta-analysis
  • Management of brain metastases: role of radiotherapy alone or in combination with other treatment modalities
  • Meta-analysis of adjuvant chemotherapy after radical surgery for advanced gastric cancer
  • Multiple-treatments meta-analysis of chemotherapy and targeted therapies in advanced breast cancer
  • Second-line or subsequent systemic therapy for recurrent or progressive non-small cell lung cancer: a clinical practice guideline

  • The functional effects of physical exercise training in frail older people: a systematic review

 

NHS Economic Evaluation Database (NEED)

  • Cost-effectiveness of tipranavir versus comparator protease inhibitor regimens in HIV infected patients previously exposed to antiretroviral therapy in the Netherlands
  • The cost-effectiveness of HLA-B*5701 genetic screening to guide initial antiretroviral therapy for HIV
  • Time to give nutrition interventions a higher profile: cost-effectiveness of 10 nutrition interventions

 

DUETs (Database of Uncertainties of the Effects of Treatments)

  • Acupuncture vs routine care for tension-type headache
  • Acupuncture vs sham treatments for tension-type headache
  • Different types of practitioners and treatment response to acupuncture for migraine prophylaxis
  • Effectiveness of a second acupuncture treatment in improving migraine
  • Effectiveness of different types of acupuncture for migraine prophylaxis
  • Epidural blood patching for preventing and treating post–dural puncture headache
  • Importance of correct point location in acupuncture for migraine prophylaxis
  • Length of duration of improvements associated with acupuncture treatment for migraine
  • Optimal frequency and duration of acupuncture sessions for migraine prophylaxis
  • Palliative care for heart failure
  • Targeted drug therapies for the management of metastatic colorectal cancer
  • The impact of targeted drug therapies on current management of metastatic colorectal cancer
  • Whole brain radiotherapy for the treatment of multiple brain metastases

 

Recent items of evidence news from the collection's RSS feed

A 'care' pathway that effectively leads to the vast majority of terminal patients not being hydrated stands to be seen as inhumane
30 October 2009, 15:30:52 | Prof Sam Hjelmeland Ahmedzai (letter), Times
"Sir, The debate about end of life care will have, if nothing else, brought the medical management of dying people into the consciousness of lay people who are usually better at avoiding the subject..."

The Liverpool Care Pathway
22 October 2009, 11:23:41 | National Council for Palliative Care
"The National Council for Palliative Care has commented as follows in response to recent media coverage of the Liverpool Care Pathway: The Liverpool Care Pathway is a nationally-recognised evidence-based tool intended to help clinicians give appropriate and high-quality care to people who have reached the last few hours or days of life. Its purpose is to promote the comfort of dying people and to address the needs of their informal carers. It should not be substituted for a clinician’s professional judgement in the individual circumstances of each case..."

The Liverpool Care Pathway brings the subject of dying into the open
21 October 2009, 14:36:35 | Joan Bakewell, Times
"How we die and who makes that decision is once again a subject of public concern. Attention has been drawn to the Liverpool Care Pathway, a series of guidelines for health professionals charged with supervising deaths under their care...Many people were not aware of the guidelines until recently but alarmist letters to the press have made them more widely known and questions are being asked. This can only be good: the debate is on..."

Dying patients - A group of experts who care for the terminally ill claim that some patients are being wrongly judged as close to death
15 October 2009, 11:31:05 | PH Millard - Emeritus Professor of Geriatrics - University of London et al (letter) Telegraph
"SIR – The Patients Association has done well to expose the poor treatment of elderly patients in some parts of the NHS (report, August 27). We would like to draw attention to the new “gold standard” treatment of those categorised as “dying”. Forecasting death is an inexact science...."

New assisted suicide guidelines to give 'clear advice' to relatives
24 September 2009, 11:06:55 | Alexandra Topping, Guardian
"Director of public prosecutions says assisted suicide remains illegal and guidance will not mean immunity from legal action".

Cancer molecule breakthrough could halt deadly muscle loss
14 September 2009, 07:52:43 | Telegraph
"Cancer deaths through muscle loss could be prevented after British scientists discovered a molecule which stops suffers fatally wasting away."

Over-the-counter painkillers 'can cause addiction within three days'
07 September 2009, 14:10:41 | Kate Devlin, Telegraph
"Over-the-counter painkillers taken by millions can cause addiction in just three days, the Government’s drug watchdog has said. The pills, which contain codeine, include brand names such as Nurofen Plus and Solpadeine Plus. They are sold without prescription and are routinely used to ease headaches, back problems and period pain."

Sentenced to death on the NHS
03 September 2009, 13:30:31 | Kate Devlin, Telegraph
"Patients with terminal illnesses are being made to die prematurely under an NHS scheme to help end their lives, leading doctors have warned."

Doctor facing disciplinary action over drug prescriptions
02 September 2009, 14:29:44 | Telegraph
"Dr Jane Barton, who prescribed "potentially hazardous" levels of drugs to elderly patients at Gosport War Memorial Hospital, could be struck off after she was found guilty of recklessly prescribing the powerful painkillers."

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: 9 February 2009 AEU: Bowel obstruction
document.publisher: National Library for Health: Supportive and Palliative Care Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ GASTRO-INTESTINAL,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,COLON & RECTUM,GASTROENTEROLOGY & LIVER DISEASES,FEBRUARY 2009,RECENT ADDITIONS]]>
document.body:
111-19 February 2009 AEU: Bowel obstruction

RETURN TO THE CONTENTS PAGE

 

Methods

 

We searched Pubmed with the following search strategy:

 

Intestinal Obstruction[MeSH Terms]

AND

systematic or "meta-analysis" or "meta analysis"

AND

palliat* or supportive or hospice*

 

Limits = 2007 to the present date.

 

2 Cochrane reviews from 2000 are also included. In addition, some other key sources are included.

 

 

Included records

 

  • Colonic stenting for malignant disease: review of literature. Dionigi G, Villa F, Rovera F, Boni L, Carrafiello G, Annoni M, Castano P, Bianchi V, Mangini M, Recaldini C, Laganà D, Bacuzzi A, Dionigi R. Surg Oncol. 2007 Dec;16 Suppl 1:S153-5. Epub 2007 Nov 26. [Link to PubMed abstract]

 

  • Self-expanding metallic stents for relieving malignant colorectal obstruction: a systematic review. Watt AM, Faragher IG, Griffin TT, Rieger NA, Maddern GJ. Ann Surg. 2007 Jul;246(1):24-30. [Link to PubMed abstract]

 

  • Medical treatment for inoperable malignant bowel obstruction: a qualitative systematic review. Mercadante S, Casuccio A, Mangione S. J Pain Symptom Manage. 2007 Feb;33(2):217-23. [Link to PubMed abstract]

 

  • Comparison of colonic stenting and open surgery for malignant large bowel obstruction. Tilney HS, Lovegrove RE, Purkayastha S, Sains PS, Weston-Petrides GK, Darzi AW, Tekkis PP, Heriot AG. Surg Endosc. 2007 Feb;21(2):225-33. Epub 2006 Dec 9. PMID: 17160651 [Link to PubMed abstract]

 

  • Surgery for the resolution of symptoms in malignant bowel obstruction in advanced gynaecological and gastrointestinal cancer. Feuer DJ, Broadley KE, Shepherd JH, Barton DP. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2000;(4):CD002764. [Link to full text]

 

  • Corticosteroids for the resolution of malignant bowel obstruction in advanced gynaecological and gastrointestinal cancer. Feuer DJ, Broadley KE. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2000;(2):CD001219. [Link to full text]

 

 

Other key sources

 

  • Report of the clinical protocol committee: development of randomized trials for malignant bowel obstruction. Anthony T, Baron T, Mercadante S, Green S, Chi D, Cunningham J, Herbst A, Smart E, Krouse RS. J Pain Symptom Manage. 2007 Jul;34(1 Suppl):S49-59. Epub 2007 Jun 4. [Link to PubMed abstract]

 

  • Ethical issues in research to improve the management of malignant bowel obstruction: challenges and recommendations. document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: 9 February 2009 AEU: Constipation
document.publisher: National Library for Health: Supportive and Palliative Care Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,GASTROENTEROLOGY & LIVER DISEASES,COMMON CLINICAL PRESENTATIONS,CONSTIPATION,RECENT ADDITIONS,CONSTIPATION AND OTHER BOWEL PROBLEMS,FEBRUARY 2009]]>
document.body:
111-19 February 2009 AEU: Constipation

RETURN TO THE CONTENTS PAGE

 

Methods

 

A Medline search was conducted using the Ovid interface.

 

1.Explode palliative care (MESH TERM)

2.Palliative care as free text

3. Explode terminal care (MESH TERM)

4. Terminal care as free text

5. Explode terminally ill (MESH TERM)

6.Terminally ill as free text

7.Hospice$ as free text

8. Explode hospices (MESH TERM)

9. End of life as free text

10. 1 or 2 or 3 or 4 or 5 or 6 or 7 or 8 or 9

11. Limit above to years 1999-2009, to humans and to English     language

12. Constipation as free text or explode constipation (MESH TERM)

13. 11 and 12

 

173 items were retrieved in search 13.

4 systematic reviews were identified.

In addition, 5 other abstracts were included.

a) Clinical guidelines published in Palliative Medicine in 2008. (An international  panel of palliative care practitioners reviewed  the best available evidence)

b) The abstracts of three articles indicated that a comprehensive literature had been undertaken on constipation management.

c) One article outlined a survey of constipation management practice in the UK

A clinical knowledge summary on the subject is available at:

http://cks.library.nhs.uk/palliative_cancer_care_constipation

 

Performing a similar search on EMBASE produced no new systematic reviews or meta-analyses. Another systematic review from Clinical Evidence was also found.

From the list of records included at that stage, just 7 were included in our final list below. This includes a key consensus paper and a recent good quality review

 

 

Included records

 

  • A systematic review of treatments for constipation in children and young adults undergoing cancer treatment. J Pediatr Hematol Oncol. 2008 Nov;30(11):829-30. Phillips RS, Gibson F. [Link to PubMed abstract]

 

  • Constipation in people prescribed opioids. Ahmedzai SH, Boland J. Clinical Evidence 2007. [Link to full text]

 

  • Peripherally acting opioid antagonists in the treatment of opiate-related constipation: a systematic review. J Pain Symptom Manage. 2007 Nov;34(5):547-65. Epub 2007 Sep 27.Becker G, Galandi D, Blum HE. [Link to PubMed abstract]

 

  • Laxatives for the management of constipation in palliative care patients.Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2006 Oct 18;(4):CD003448.Miles CL, Fellowes D, Goodman ML, Wilkinson S. [Link to full text]

 

  • Opioid antagonists: a review of their role in palliative care, focusing on use in opioid-related constipation. J Pain Symptom Manage. 2002 Jul;24(1):71-90. Choi YS, Billings JA.PMID: 12183097 [Link to PubMed abstract]

 

 

In addition, although not systematic reviews, we include a key consensus paper and a recent good quality review:

 

  • The management of constipation in palliative care: clinical practice recommendations. Palliat Med. 2008 Oct;22(7):796-807. Larkin PJ, Sykes NP, Centeno C, Ellershaw JE, Elsner F, Eugene B, Gootjes JR, Nabal M, Noguera A, Ripamonti C, Zucco F, Zuurmond WW; European Consensus Group on Constipation in Palliative Care. [Link to PubMed abstract]

 

  • Management of constipation in palliative care patients. Clemens KE, Klaschik E. Curr Opin Support Palliat Care. 2008 Mar;2(1):22-7.  [Link to Pubmed abstract]

 

  • Contents of the Library on Constipation

 

RETURN TO THE CONTENTS PAGE 

]]>

document.title: 9 February 2009 AEU: Nausea and vomiting
document.publisher: National Library for Health: Supportive and Palliative Care Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,COMMON CLINICAL PRESENTATIONS,GASTROENTEROLOGY & LIVER DISEASES,NAUSEA & VOMITING,NAUSEA & VOMITING,FEBRUARY 2009,RECENT ADDITIONS]]>
document.body:
111-19 February 2009 AEU: Nausea and vomiting

RETURN TO THE CONTENTS PAGE

 

Methods

 

We ran an "advanced" search on Pubmed, selecting the "clinical queries" option and then using the "Find systematic reviews" field to enter this search string:

 

Search (emesis[tw] OR vomiting[mh] OR nausea[mh]) AND systematic[sb]

 

Limits: Humans, English

 

2005 to present date

 

Our initial search (without limiting by year) gave 377 hits of which 197 were listed under the review tab. 

We then limited by year. In addition, we included some additional sources we found.

We included 20 records in our final list.

 

 

 

Included records

 

  • The impact of prophylactic dexamethasone on nausea and vomiting after laparoscopic cholecystectomy: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Karanicolas PJ, Smith SE, Kanbur B, Davies E, Guyatt GH. Ann Surg. 2008 Nov;248(5):751-62. [Link to Pubmed abstract]

 

  • P6 stimulation for the prevention of nausea and vomiting associated with cesarean delivery under neuraxial anesthesia: a systematic review of randomized controlled trials. Allen TK, Habib AS. Anesth Analg. 2008 Oct;107(4):1308-12.  [Link to Pubmed abstract]

 

  • Evidence-based recommendations for cancer nausea and vomiting. Naeim A, Dy SM, Lorenz KA, Sanati H, Walling A, Asch SM. J Clin Oncol. 2008 Aug 10;26(23):3903-10. [Link to Pubmed abstract]

 

  • Therapeutic use of Cannabis sativa on chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting among cancer patients: systematic review and meta-analysis. Machado Rocha FC, Stéfano SC, De Cássia Haiek R, Rosa Oliveira LM, Da Silveira DX. Eur J Cancer Care (Engl). 2008 Sep;17(5):431-43. Epub 2008 Jul 9. [Link to Pubmed abstract]

 

  • Use of intrathecal midazolam to improve perioperative analgesia: a meta-analysis. Ho KM, Ismail H. Anaesth Intensive Care. 2008 May;36(3):365-73. [Link to Pubmed abstract]

 

  • Does supplemental oxygen reduce postoperative nausea and vomiting? A meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. Orhan-Sungur M, Kranke P, Sessler D, Apfel CC. Anesth Analg. 2008 Jun;106(6):1733-8.  [Link to Pubmed abstract]

 

  • Antiemetics: an update and the MASCC guidelines applied in clinical practice. Herrstedt J. Nat Clin Pract Oncol. 2008 Jan;5(1):32-43.  [Link to Pubmed abstract]

 

  • Oral nabilone capsules in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting and pain. Davis MP. Expert Opin Investig Drugs. 2008 Jan;17(1):85-95.  [Link to Pubmed abstract]

 

  • Is ondansetron more effective than granisetron for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting? A review of comparative trials. Vrabel M. Clin J Oncol Nurs. 2007 Dec;11(6):809-13.  [Link to Pubmed abstract]

 

  • Hypnosis for nausea and vomiting in cancer chemotherapy: a systematic review of the research evidence. Richardson J, Smith JE, McCall G, Richardson A, Pilkington K, Kirsch I. Eur J Cancer Care (Engl). 2007 Sep;16(5):402-12.  [Link to Pubmed abstract]

 

  • Prevention of postoperative nausea and vomiting.  Wilhelm SM, Dehoorne-Smith ML, Kale-Pradhan PB. Ann Pharmacother. 2007 Jan;41(1):68-78. Epub 2007 Jan 2. [Link to Pubmed abstract]

 

  • The efficacy of 5-HT3 receptor antagonists for the prevention of postoperative nausea and vomiting after craniotomy: a meta-analysis. Neufeld SM, Newburn-Cook CV. J Neurosurg Anesthesiol. 2007 Jan;19(1):10-7.  [Link to Pubmed abstract]

 

  • Antiemetics for reducing vomiting related to acute gastroenteritis in children and adolescents. Alhashimi D, Alhashimi H, Fedorowicz Z. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2006 Oct 18;(4):CD005506.  Update of: Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2006;3:CD005506. [Link to full text]

 

  • Acupuncture for nausea and vomiting: an update of clinical and experimental studies. Streitberger K, Ezzo J, Schneider A. Auton Neurosci. 2006 Oct 30;129(1-2):107-17. Epub 2006 Sep 1. [Link to Pubmed abstract]

 

  • Antiemetics for reducing vomiting related to acute gastroenteritis in children and adolescents. Alhashimi D, Alhashimi H, Fedorowicz Z. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2006 Jul 19;3:CD005506.  Update in: Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2006;(4):CD005506. [Link to full text]

 

  • Drugs for preventing postoperative nausea and vomiting. Carlisle JB, Stevenson CA. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2006 Jul 19;3:CD004125.  [Link to full text]

 

  • Acupuncture-point stimulation for chemotherapy-induced nausea or vomiting. Ezzo JM, Richardson MA, Vickers A, Allen C, Dibble SL, Issell BF, Lao L, Pearl M, Ramirez G, Roscoe J, Shen J, Shivnan JC, Streitberger K, Treish I, Zhang G.Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2006 Apr 19;(2):CD002285.  [Link to full text]

 

  • The efficacy of ginger for the prevention of postoperative nausea and vomiting: a meta-analysis. Chaiyakunapruk N, Kitikannakorn N, Nathisuwan S, Leeprakobboon K, Leelasettagool C. Am J Obstet Gynecol. 2006 Jan;194(1):95-9. Comment in: Evid Based Nurs. 2006 Jul;9(3):80.  [Link to Pubmed abstract]

 

  • Prevention of chemotherapy- and radiotherapy-induced emesis: results of the 2004 Perugia International Antiemetic Consensus Conference. Ann Oncol. 2006 Jan;17(1):20-8. Epub 2005 Nov 28.  [Link to Pubmed abstract]

 

  • Effectiveness and safety of ginger in the treatment of pregnancy-induced nausea and vomiting. Borrelli F, Capasso R, Aviello G, Pittler MH, Izzo AA.Obstet Gynecol. 2005 Apr;105(4):849-56. Comment in: Obstet Gynecol. 2005 Sep;106(3):640; author reply 640-1. [Link to Pubmed abstract]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Annotated reference/bibliography on user involvement in palliative care
document.publisher: National Library for Health: Supportive and Palliative Care Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,FAMILIES & CARERS,DEATH,COMMUNICATION ISSUES,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-1Annotated reference/bibliography on user involvement in palliative care

Back to the CONTENTS PAGE


Beresford, P, Broughton, F, Croft, S, Fouquet, S, Oliviere, D, Rhodes, P. (2000) Palliative Care: developing user involvement, improving quality. Middlesex: Brunel University

Significant, as this is a report of the first seminar held, at St Christopher’s Hospice, on user involvement as it related to palliative care. The themes that emerged are of interest at a time when the concept of user involvement was generally foreign to the field of palliative care.

 

Beresford, P, Croft, S, Adshead, L, Walker, J, Wilman, K (2005). Involving service users in palliative care: from theory to practice. In Firth, P, Luff, G, Oliviere, D. Loss, change and bereavement in palliative care. Maidenhead: Open University Press

This chapter explores the meaning of participation and relates it to palliative care. It provides a very good overview of thinking underpinning user involvement in palliative care from experienced writers on the topic along with service users.

 

Beresford, P, Adshead L, Croft S (2006) Palliative care, social work and service users, Making life possible. London: Jessica Kingsley

Based on a range of interviews with consumers of social work services in palliative care, this groundbreaking study offers insights into the value of palliative care social work and involvement which is of benefit to all professions working in palliative care.

 

Clark, D, Thomas, C, McDermott, E, Bingley, A, Payne, S, Seymour, J (2005) What are the views of people affected by cancer and other illnesses about end of life issues? Professional and patient perspectives. Lancaster: International Observatory on End of Life Care, Institute of Health Research, Lancaster University

The report of the research study to explore narratives written about end of life issues: medical professionals’ writings since 1975 concerning their experience of caring for people with cancer and writings since 1950 of people facing death. The different issues that emerged are identified and differing perspectives fascinating.

 

Cotterell, P, Findlay, H, Macfarlane, A (2009) Patient and carer narratives and stories. In Gunaratnam, Y and Oliviere, D Narrative and Stories in Health Care. Illness, Death and Bereavement. Oxford: Oxford University Press  ( in press)

The role and uses of patient stories are presented, as part of user involvement initiatives in palliative care. Narrative and storied accounts are discussed as a form of knowledge that can and should be utilized to greater effect. Some powerful stories.

 

Coulter, A, Ellins, J (2007) Effectiveness of strategies for informing, educating, and involving patients. BMJ  335 (7 July): 24-27

The paper argues that effective strategies to strengthen patient engagement are substantial.  However, any strategy to reduce health inequalities must promote patient understanding of all aspects of care ie “health literacy”. The research for the study on which this useful article is based, is by the Picker Institute, an independent research and development institute specialising in measuring patients’ experience of health care.

 

Edmonds, P, Burman, R, Sinnott, C (2004) The goldfish bowl. European Journal of Palliative Care: 11(2): 69-71

This article summaries the experience of an education method for training fifth year medical students in palliative care, using the ‘goldfish bowl’. The method is highly evaluated by the medical students and service users speak of it as empowering.

 

Jarrett, L (2007) (ed) Creative engagement in palliative care. New perspectives on user involvement. Abingdon: Radcliffe Publishing

Although largely a collection of examples of creative work with patients and of patient-centred care, the whole philosophy underpinning this work is good user involvement and the empowerment of users and carers through therapeutic interventions.

 

Kraus, F, Levy, J, Oliviere, D. (2003) Brief report on user involvement at St Christopher’s Hospice. Palliative Medicine 17(4):375-377

This brief account outlines developments at St Christopher’s pioneering a User Forum and other methods of eliciting the user voice and fuller partnership working with users and carers. It offers some practice experience to those working in the field.

 

Monroe, B, Oliviere, D (eds) (2003) Patient participation in palliative care. A voice for the voiceless. Oxford: Oxford University Press

A wide variety of clinical, team and organisational aspects of palliative care are considered from a patient-centred perspective. The second half of the book provides a critical analysis on how to involve users from the perspective of five different professional groups in the multi-professional palliative care team.

 

National Council for Palliative Care (2004) Listening to Users. Helping professionals address User Involvement in Palliative Care. London: National Council for Palliative Care

The short publication aims to put ideas about user involvement into the palliative care context and make them of practical use to health professionals. In addition to providing helpful information and guidance, it attempts to present some of the debates around user involvement within palliative care. The original document is:

 

National Council for Palliative Care (2008) Listening to the experts. A summary of ‘User involvement in palliative care: a scoping study’. London: National Council for Palliative Care

The summary of this scoping study offers a thorough literature review as well as the analysis of interviews of users/carers, professionals and experts. Examples of user involvement in action are given and attention drawn to the limitations of research and enquiry in the field. The work offers one of the few comprehensive studies of user involvement within the field of palliative care by a high profile research team.

Original study: Payne, S, Gott, M, Small, N, Oliviere, D, Sargeant, A, Young, E (2005) User involvement in palliative care: a scoping study. Sheffield: University of Sheffield.

 

Oliviere, D (2006) User involvement – the patient and carer as team members? In Speck, P. Teamwork in palliative care. Fullfiling or frustrating? Oxford: Oxford University Press

A comprehensive account of the roles and functions of users and carers in their contributions to the multi-professional team. Within the team, the user/carers are presented as having seven core aspects.

 

Sahlsten, MJM, Larssen, IE, Sjostrom,B, Plos, KAE (2008) An analysis of the concept of patient participation. Nursing Forum 43(1): 2-11

A thorough exploration of various terms linked with participation, using concept analysis. Collaboration, partnership and power sharing are discussed within the context of the nurse-patient relationship. A Swedish study.

 

Sargeant A, Payne S, Gott M, Small N, Oliviere D. (2007) User involvement in palliative care: motivational factors for service users and professionals. Progress in Palliative Care 15(3):126-132

This study addresses what motivates or discourages users, carers and professionals from participating in user involvement activities, as part of the larger scoping study into user involvement in palliative care. (See National Council for Pallaitive Care 2008 above)

 

Small, N, Rhodes, P (2000). Too ill to talk? User involvement and palliative care. London: Routledge

An ‘early’ yet thoughtful contribution to debates around user involvement in the field of palliative care. The second part of the book offers useful perspectives based on narratives of users with cystic fibrosis, multiple sclerosis and motor neurone disease.

 

Small N (2005) User voices in palliative care. In Faull, C, Carter, Y and Daniels, L (eds) Handbook of palliative care. 2nd. Ed. Oxford: Blackwell

This is an excellent summary of the issues and concerns involved and the contribution of user voices in three areas: the impact on individual professionals; users shaping organisations; and how national policy engages with and reflects user views.

 

Tritter, J, Daykin, N, Evans, S, Sanidas, M (2004). Improving cancer services through patient involvement. Abingdon: Radcliffe Medical Press

This publication is more concerned with user involvement systems in healthcare organisations and the potential impact on cancer services. However, the principles and practices are relevant to palliative care. A toolkit style approach is taken, with case studies.

 

Organisations that have funded or provide key information on aspects of user participation:

  • Cancer Experiences Collaborative
    http://www.ceco.org.uk/narratives/index.php
  • Joseph Rowntree Foundation
    http://www.jrf.org.uk/
  • NHS Centre for Involvement
    http://www.nhscentreforinvolvement.nhs.uk/

 

David Oliviere
Director of Education and Training
St Christopher’s Hospice
January 2008

 

Back to the CONTENTS PAGE

 

 

 


 

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 12 April 2010: Pain in supportive and palliative care. Introduction

 

[Go to the Contents page]

 

Welcome to this AEU on pain - the 4th we have produced since starting the Supportive and Palliative Care specialist collection in 2005 (originally under the title of Palliative and Supportive Care specialist library).  We have included only material published in 2008, 2009 and 2010, because of the large volume of material now emerging in the topic of pain.  

Once again, we have taken a broad inclusive view of supportive and palliative care, which extends to non-malignant disease as well as cancer and at all stages of disease.  You can read more about our definition of supportive and palliative care here. 

We would like to thank the members of the editorial team who have contributed to this AEU:

  • Denise Brady
  • Melanie Hodson
  • Julia Barnes
  • Elaine Cachia
  • Clare Rayment
  • Rachel Vedder

 

Sam H Ahmedzai, Clinical Lead

Richard Stevens, Project Manager/Information Specialist

 

[Go to the Contents page] 

]]>

document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 12 April 2010: Pain in supportive and palliative care. Methodology

[Go to Contents page]

 

Databases searched

Medline, EMBASE, Cochrane, CINAHL, DARE, AMED.

We also searched: NHS Evidence main page, 'NHS Evidence - Supportive and palliative care' specialist collection, EAPC website, British Pain Society website.

 

Search strategy

We used the same search strategy as when the previous general pain AEU searches were run in 2007 and 2008. We amended this to fit the requirements of the various databases.

 

Reviewing

Search results were passed to four reviewers (Julia Barnes, Elaine Cachia, Clare Rayment and Rachel Vedder) for assessment of abstracts for basic quality and relevance. The final list was agreed by Prof Sam H Ahmedzai.

 

[Go to Contents page]

document.title: Annual Evidence Update 17 November 2008. Supportive and palliative care in chronic lung disease
document.publisher: Supportive and Palliative Care Specialist Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,RESPIRATORY DISEASES,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD)]]>
document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 17 November 2008. Supportive and palliative care in chronic lung disease

 

Introduction

 

This Annual Evidence Update complements the Respiratory Library's COPD Annual Evidence Update by providing links to the newest evidence in this area that is of particular interest for supportive and palliative care professionals.

 

The evidence update is based upon the knowledge set out in a new document published by the National Council for Palliative Care and a special conference on this topic. The national conference 'A Breath Of Fresh Air: Implementing the End of Life Care Strategy for Respiratory Disease' took place on 18 November 2008 in London to explore the issues arising.

 

All the talks from the conference are available to download as pdf files from NCPC:

 

  • Respiratory Disease: The Size of the Problem.  Martyn R Partridge, MD FRCP. Professor of Respiratory Medicine, Imperial College London
  • The Palliative Care Perspective.  Dr Sharon Chadwick
    Macmillan Consultant in Palliative Medicine, Hospice of St Francis
  • Perceptions & Levels of Current Involvement: Results of the first National Survey.  Professor Sam Ahmedzai. Professor of Palliative Medicine, University of Sheffield
  • Palliative Care Needs in COPD – What Evidence & What Direction Should We Take?  Dr Patrick White, Senior Lecturer, Kings College London School of Medicine
  • The End of Life Care Strategy & Its Importance for CRD.  Lucy Sutton, Director of Policy Development, NCPC
  • The National Service Framework for COPD & EoLC.  Kevin Holton, Head of COPD programme, Department of Health
  • Putting It All Together: The NHS Next Stage Review.  Dr Mark Roland, Consultant Respiratory Physician & Director of Cancer Services, Portsmouth Hospitals NHS Trust
  • Surviving from Dying: A Personal Experience.  Mandy Paine, Service User
  • What People with CRD Tell Us: Results of a National Survey. Jo Black, User Involvement Project Manager, NCPC 
  • Integrating Health & Social Care.  Dr David Lyon, GP, Castlefield Health Centre
  • Advanced COPD: A Study of Palliative Care Needs & Service Provision. Allison Spence, Hospice Community Nurse
  • Specialist Palliative Care & Respiratory Services: Developing a Systematic Process. Clare Littlewood, Consultant in Palliative Medicine, Whiston Hospital

 

  • Contents of the Supportive Care Library on the topic COPD

 

  • See the Respiratory Library's COPD Annual Evidence Update

 

 

Comment from Lucy Sutton, National Council for Palliative Care; and Policy Team, Help the Hospices

 

Chronic respiratory diseases (CRD) account for a significant number of UK deaths. The World Health Organization has found that the growing number of people affected means that CRD is set to become the fourth leading cause of death worldwide by 2030, surpassed only by cardio vascular disease, pneumonia and HIV/AIDS.  In England and Wales, CRD, excluding lung cancer, already accounts for 14% of all deaths.

 

Despite the significant numbers involved, people affected by these conditions can struggle to receive palliative and end of life care that addresses their needs. The symptoms experienced by many people with CRD are often more severe versions of those of people with lung cancer. Current palliative care services may sometimes still focus on specialist palliative care which has historically been developed for people with cancer. It is much harder to give a prognosis for many forms of CRD than for cancer, which often has made it difficult to determine when a person has specific palliative or end of life care needs.

 

These issues led The National Council for Palliative Care to set up the CRD Policy Group in June 2007. This group has carried out extensive work since this time and is now able to offer some solutions to these issues. In it’s first publication Focus on Chronic Respiratory Disease the group presents the results of a survey into the interaction between respiratory and palliative care consultants, what users and carers have said they need and some examples of good practice all of which will help services implement the recommendations set out in recent policy notably The End of Life Care Strategy.

 

For further information visit www.ncpc.org.uk.

 

 

 

 

 

 

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PATIENT EXPERIENCE,PPI IN PRACTICE,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,RESEARCH,FAMILIES & CARERS,COMMUNICATION ISSUES,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,KIDNEY DISEASES,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE]]>
document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 18 January 2010: Patient and carer involvement in chronic disease. Introduction

[RETURN TO CONTENTS PAGE]

The Annual Evidence Update on ‘Patient and carer involvement in chronic disease’ for 2010 was published online on 18 January 2010.  This was the second AEU on patient and carer engagement in chronic disease management and we have continued to broaden the scope of the literature we accessed, in order to reflect the widening field of supportive and end of life care.  

 

Our understanding of supportive care is based on the NICE (2004) guidance on supportive and palliative care for adults with cancer, but it is readily accepted that this definition can apply just as well out of malignant disease [see definition].

 

In this AEU, we have included literature mainly from 2009 but also included a few publications of note from earlier years.  The papers we have identified fall into three broad groups –

 

1. Systematic reviews of published and quality-checked literature on user experience of healthcare 

 

For an interesting example of this group, see:

 

Long-term oxygen therapy: review from the patients' perspective. Cullen DL, Stiffler D. Chron Respir Dis. 2009;6(3):141-7.  [Link to abstract PMID: 19643828]

 

 

2. Systematic reviews of user involvement in educating healthcare professionals in giving better care in chronic and terminal conditions 

For example, see:

 

Perceptions of service user and carer involvement in healthcare education and impact on students' knowledge and practice: A literature review. Morgan A., Jones D. Medical Teacher, February 2009, vol./is. 31/2(82-95), 0142-159X;1466-187X. [Link to abstract PMID: 19090412]

 

3. Guidance and policy documents published on user involvement in chronic illnesses and end of life care 

 

These come from the Department of Health and influential bodies such as National Council for Palliative Care.  

 

For an example, see:

 

A Guide to Involving patients, carers and the public in palliative care and end of life care services. Including a Practical Educational Tool. National Council for Palliative Care. [Download pdf] 

It is possible that even with our exhaustive web-searches, we may have missed important examples of the last group, perhaps coming from other national charities.  If readers of the AEU are aware of other key policy documents or guidance, preferably available freely on the internet, please let us know and we will try to include them in our listings.

 

We also welcome feedback on this AEU from healthcare professionals, students, managers – and of course, users of healthcare who are the focus of this evidence review.  Please send your comments to our email discussion group – joining is easy and allows you to receive monthly updates on the literature in  the field of supportive and palliative care:

 

www.jiscmail.ac.uk/lists/supportive-and-palliative-care-evidence.html

 

Many thanks go to the following colleagues who have contributed to this evidence update, either by conducting the original internet searches or by reviewing and sifting out the key papers –

 

  • Denise Brady
  • Melanie Hodson
  • Ashique Ahamed
  • Julia Barnes
  • Clare Rayment

 

Sam H Ahmedzai

Clinical Lead

 

Richard Stevens

Project Manager/Information Specialist

 

[RETURN TO CONTENTS PAGE] 

]]>

document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 18 January 2010: Patient and carer involvement in chronic disease. Methodology

 

[RETURN TO CONTENTS PAGE]

 

Databases searched

1. PubMed
2. DARE
3. Cochrane database of systematic reviews
4. NHS Evidence: National Library of Guidelines
5. NHS Evidence: supportive and palliative care specialist collection
6. Cinahl
7. Embase
8. Whole of NHS evidence

 

Notes on the methods

Melanie Hodson and Denise Brady searched the databases – CINAHL, PUBMED and EMBASE expanding on the search performed by Richard Stevens in 2009. We searched CINAHL and EMBASE  for 2009 only – but it was possible to be more specific on PUBMED and we were able to search back to November 2008 on this database.  A search on self care was added as well as a search using the Clinical query resource on Pubmed.  

A search using only the terms Participation, involvement, self-man* and ”self man*" was also conducted on the Cochrane database and on DARE (2009). 

Searching NHS Evidence as a whole, there were hundreds of references - so rather than search the whole database for relevant material, we only searched the patient and public involvement and the Supportive and Palliative Care specialist collections. Having looked through this on a second occasion we have highlighted what we think are the most relevant items. Unlike the searches on PUBMED, CINAHL  and EMBASE this search was not confined to systematic reviews or meta-analyses. This has yielded a variety of government reports and highlighted the work of the National Council for Palliative Care.

 

Search strategies

We searched Medline, Cinahl, Embase using the following terms in each database. They are broadly similar except for the different subject headings in each database. See below. Our initial search yielded 31 items.

document.title: Annual Evidence Update 22 November 2010. Supportive and palliative care in chronic lung disease. Introduction
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - supportive and palliative care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,RESPIRATORY DISEASES,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD),DYSPNOEA,COUGH]]>
document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 22 November 2010. Supportive and palliative care in chronic lung disease. Introduction

GO TO THE CONTENTS PAGE

 

Introduction

Welcome to the Annual Evidence Update on supportive and palliative care issues in people with respiratory disease.  We are again linking this update to the recent AEU presented by the Respiratory Specialist Collection, which focused on COPD.  Readers will find many relevant topics for professionals and researchers regarding supportive and palliative care in that collection.

For our own specific search through the literature, we have concentrated on two of the most important issues for patients with pulmonary problems.  The first is dyspnoea (or breathlessness).  This symptom is usually one of the most prevalent in surveys of problems associated with respiratory and also many other systemic illnesses.  For this AEU, we have taken our customary broad and inclusive view of supportive and palliative care, and have therefore included reviews and studies which cover cancer treatment as well as end of life care topics.

Our second specific topic is cough, which is less common but can nevertheless be just as distressing for patients with cancer and other chronic conditions.  Again, we have chosen key publications representing the best systematic reviews and selected studies from the last few years, covering the whole disease trajectory.

 

GO TO THE LIST OF REFERENCES

 

  • Sam H Ahmedzai
  • Denise Brady
  • Melanie Hodson
  • Richard Stevens

[Project team of the Specialist Collection for Supportive and Palliative Care]

 

We would like to thank the following for their helpful contribution in reviewing and appraising the literature –

  • Jason Boland [Clinical Lecturer and PhD student, Sheffield]
  • Sarah Mollart [Specialist Registrar in Palliative Medicine, Sheffield and Chesterfield training programme]
  • Dilanki Ranmuthu
  • Clare Rayment [Specialist Registrar in Palliative Medicine, Leeds]

 

GO TO THE CONTENTS PAGE

 

]]>

document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 22 November 2010. Supportive and palliative care in chronic lung disease. List of included references

 

GO TO THE CONTENTS PAGE

 

 

1. Epidemiology and measurement

 

1a. Dyspnoea
  • Understanding Breathlessness: Cross-Sectional Comparison of Symptom Burden and Palliative Care Needs in Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease and Cancer. 1b. Cough

1c. Mixed/non-specific/quality of life

Health technology assessment. Mant J., Doust J., Roalfe A., Barton P., Cowie M.R., Glasziou P., Mant D., McManus R.J., Holder R., Deeks J., Fletcher K., Qume M., Sohanpal S., Sanders S., Hobbs F.D.  (Winchester, England), July 2009, vol./is.13/32(1-207, iii), 1366-5278 (Jul 2009) [PubMed abstract]

 

2. Interventions

2a. Dyspnoea

NHS EVIDENCE

 

This was confined to 2009-2010 using the NHS Evidence main interface and using dyspnoea and palliative care  in the search box.  Some items were excluded if they were short items from BNF, items  that seemed broader in scope and items that were primarily patient information.  Of course not all are systematic reviews/meta-analyses but it always checked for relevant material.

 

Cochrane

 

All text: dyspnoea or dyspnea or breathlessness 2009-2010

297 items were examined for relevance and results are provided in a separate file.  Items dated before 2009 (despite being found in the text were excluded).



DARE

 

All text: dyspnoea or dyspnea or breathlessness 2009-2010

29 items were examined for relevance and results are provided in separate file


No items were found on PSYCINFO using a search strategy the same as CINAHL.

 

ASTHMA and BRONCHIECTASIS were generally not included in items retrieved from above searches.

Denise Brady, October 2010

 

 

 

 

 

Post-search processing of reference lists - Richard Stevens

 

The lists of search results were formatted in separate Word documents (with html links to abstracts in some cases) in such a way as to make the appraisal process more reader-friendly.

 

 

 

 

Appraisal of reference lists - Jason Boland

 

The Word documents were passed to Jason Boland, who organised distribution amongst the review team for first appraisal. Titles were highlighted in green, yellow or red using the highlight function in Word (to indicate 'yes', 'maybe' or 'no') by each reviewer. In some cases comments were added alongside references where the decision was contentious or to make other points.

 

After this first appraisal, the amended documents were sent by each reviewer to Prof Sam H Ahmedzai for approval, who then passed his amended and annotated final versions of these files to Richard Stevens.

 

 

 

 

Preparation of final list and formatting for the web with other pages - Richard Stevens

 

The references highlighted for inclusion in the Word documents received from Prof Ahmedzai after second appraisal were compiled into an aggregated list and duplicates removed.

 

References were put in appropriate categories as indicated by the review team.

 

PubMed and full text web links were put in as appropriate. Final checks of references were done. The pages were put online and navigational links checked.

 

 

 

Richard Stevens, November 2010

 

 

 

GO TO THE CONTENTS PAGE

document.title: Annual Evidence Update 22 October 2007. National Knowledge Week on Palliative and supportive care in chronic non-malignant diseases [inc. chronic lung disease]
document.publisher: National Library for Health
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,RESPIRATORY DISEASES,MOTOR NEURONE DISEASE,ALZHEIMER’S DISEASE,LYMPHOEDEMA,CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD),RENAL DISEASES,HAEMATOLOGIC AND LYMPHATIC DISEASES]]>
document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 22 October 2007. National Knowledge Week on Palliative and supportive care in chronic non-malignant diseases [inc. chronic lung disease]

This National Knowledge Week was organised by the National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care to provide a concise summary of some key points in the best current evidence on these topics in an easy-to-read format.

The National Knowledge Week pages include the results of a literature search for systematic reviews for each topic, supported by commentaries on current knowledge by expert clinicians and a summary of the Library's contents in that area. Systematic reviews are regarded as the highest level of evidence on health interventions.

The items below will be published on a day-by-day basis. The pages will remain accessible until the next Annual Evidence Update for each topic in 12 months time. If you would like to contribute to this activity or you have any comments on how it could be improved, please use our feedback form.

 

 

Contents

 

Day One - Monday 22nd October:

 

  • Introduction from the National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care - Sam H. Ahmedzai, Clinical Lead
  • Introduction from the National Council for Palliative Care's Policy Unit - Lucy Sutton, National Policy Lead
  • Methodology - National Knowledge Week 22-26 Oct 2007. By Richard Stevens, Information Specialist.

 

Day Two - Tuesday 23rd October:

[Cardiovascular Diseases]: Chronic Heart Failure

  • 'Heart failure and palliative care: a team approach' e-book. For a limited period only we are able to provide online access to the entire text of the book “Heart Failure and Palliative Care: a team approach”, edited by Miriam Johnson and Richard Lehman.
  • Chronic heart failure - systematic reviews in 2007. By Jason Boland.
  • 'Cardiovascular Diseases' - search of the Pallilative and Supportive Care Library

 

    • Elsewhere in NLH: 'The importance of palliative care in heart failure'. By Louise Gibbs (for the Cardiovascular Diseases Library).

 

[Respiratory Conditions]: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)

  • COPD - systematic reviews in 2006-07. By Jason Boland.
  • 'COPD' - search of the Palliative and Supportive Care Specialist Library

 

    •  Elsewhere in NLH: 'COPD and palliative and supportive care'. By Sam H. Ahmedzai (for the Respiratory Library).

Day Three - Wednesday 24th October:

[Renal Diseases]: End-Stage Renal Disease

  • Introduction to end-stage renal disease in palliative and supportive care. By Fliss Murtagh.
  • Epidemiology and prognosis in advanced chronic kidney disease: Implications for palliative care. By Neil Sheerin.
  • Dialysis decision-making and advance planning – an evidence guide for palliative professionals. By Helen Noble.
  • Using strong opioids in advanced chronic kidney disease –  what is the evidence? By Claire A. Douglas.
  • 'Renal Diseases' - search of the Palliative and Supportive Care Library.

 

    • Elsewhere in NLH: Kidney Diseases Specialist Library

Day Four - Thursday 25th October:

[Haematologic and Lymphatic Diseases]: Lymphoedema

  • Lymphoedema / chronic oedema – a neglected area? By Vaughan Keeley.
  • The treatment of lymphoedema / chronic oedema. By Vaughan Keeley.
  • Other sources of information. By Vaughan Keeley.
  • 'Lymphoedema' - search of the Pallliative and Supportive Care Library.

Day Five - Friday 26th October:

[Nervous System Diseases]:

  • Palliative care input and advance decision-making in patients with long-term neurological conditions. By Joy Waldock.
  • Palliative care for Motor Neurone Disease. By Nigel Sykes.
  • Dementia: Some background reading. By Sharon Scott.

 

    • Elsewhere in NLH: Later Life Specialist Library.
]]>

document.title: Annual Evidence Update 23 November 2009. Supportive and palliative care in chronic lung disease. Introduction
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - supportive and palliative care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,RESPIRATORY DISEASES,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD),DYSPNOEA,COUGH]]>
document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 23 November 2009. Supportive and palliative care in chronic lung disease. Introduction

 

GO TO THE CONTENTS PAGE

 

Introduction

Welcome to the Annual Evidence Update on supportive and palliative care issues in people with respiratory disease.  We are linking this update to the recent AEU presented by the Respiratory Specialist Collection, which focused on COPD.  Readers will find many relevant topics for professionals and researchers regarding supportive and palliative care in that collection.

For our own specific search through the literature, we have concentrated on two of the most important issues for patients with pulmonary problems.  The first is dyspnoea (or breathlessness).  This symptom is usually one of the most prevalent in surveys of problems associated with respiratory and also many other systemic illnesses.  For this AEU, we have taken our customary broad and inclusive view of supportive and palliative care, and have therefore included reviews and studies which cover cancer treatment as well as end of life care topics.

GO TO THE LIST OF DYSPNOEA REFERENCES

Our second specific topic is cough, which is less common but can nevertheless be just as distressing for patients with cancer and other chronic conditions.  Again, we have chosen key publications representing the best systematic reviews and selected studies from the last few years, covering the whole disease trajectory.

GO TO THE LIST OF COUGH REFERENCES

  • Sam H Ahmedzai
  • Denise Brady
  • Melanie Hodson
  • Richard Stevens

Specialist Collection for Supportive and Palliative Care

We would like to thank the following for their helpful contribution in reviewing and appraising the literature –

  • Jason Boland
  • Sarah Mollart
  • Rachel Vedder

Specialist Registrars in Palliative Medicine, Sheffield and Chesterfield training programme

 

GO TO THE CONTENTS PAGE

 

]]>

111-1Annual Evidence Update 23 November 2009. Supportive and palliative care in chronic lung disease. Methods

 

GO TO THE CONTENTS PAGE

 

Databases searched

1. PubMed
2. DARE
3. Cochrane database of systematic reviews
4. NHS Evidence: National Library of Guidelines
5. NHS Evidence: supportive and palliative care specialist collection
6. Cinahl
7. Embase
8. Whole of NHS evidence

 

Search notes - Cough. Searcher = Melanie Hodson

 

PubMed search for cough

Search: ("2005/01/01"[Publication Date] : "2009/10/31"[Publication Date]) AND ((cough* [tw] OR cough [mh]) AND (hospice* [tw] OR hospice care [mh] OR hospices [mh] OR palliative care [mh] OR palliat* [tw] OR terminal care [mh] OR terminally ill [mh] OR "terminal care" [tw] OR terminally ill [tw] OR "end of life care" [tw] OR "end-of-life-care" [tw] OR supportive [tw]) AND (systematic [sb] OR systematic [tw] OR "meta-analysis" [tw] OR "meta analysis" [tw])) Limits: English = 11 results

 

DARE search for cough

Search string: cough AND ( hospice* OR palliative* OR "end-of-life-care" OR "end of life care" OR supportive OR terminal* ) RESTRICT YR 2005 2009

 

Cochrane search for cough

Search string: cough* AND “terminally ill” OR “terminal care” OR hospice* OR palliat* OR “supportive care” OR “end of life care”, from 2005 to 2009 in Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews. Excluded protocols. Results= 23

 

NHS evidence: supportive and palliative care specialist collection search for cough

Search string: cough = 16 results. No date restriction.

 

Embase search for cough

1. EMBASE; exp COUGHING/ [Limit to: Publication Year 2005-2009 and English Language]; 12110 results.
2. EMBASE; cough*.tw. [Limit to: Publication Year 2005-2009 and English Language]; 5108 results.
3. EMBASE; 1 OR 2 [Limit to: Publication Year 2005-2009 and English Language]; 13306 results.
4. EMBASE; exp HOSPICE/ OR exp HOSPICE CARE/ OR exp HOSPICE NURSING/ OR exp HOSPICE PATIENT/
[Limit to: Publication Year 2005-2009 and English Language]; 1119 results.
5. EMBASE; hospice*.tw. [Limit to: Publication Year 2005-2009 and English Language]; 817 results.
6. EMBASE; exp CANCER PALLIATIVE THERAPY/ OR exp PALLIATIVE NURSING/ OR exp PALLIATIVE
THERAPY/ [Limit to: Publication Year 2005-2009 and English Language]; 8552 results.
7. EMBASE; palliative*.tw. [Limit to: Publication Year 2005-2009 and English Language]; 5903 results.
8. EMBASE; exp TERMINALLY ILL PATIENT/ OR exp TERMINAL DISEASE/ OR exp TERMINAL CARE/ [Limit
to: Publication Year 2005-2009 and English Language]; 4615 results.
9. EMBASE; terminal*.tw. [Limit to: Publication Year 2005-2009 and English Language]; 55553 results.
10. EMBASE; supportive ADJ care.tw. [Limit to: Publication Year 2005-2009 and English Language]; 1628 results.
11. EMBASE; end ADJ of ADJ life.tw. [Limit to: Publication Year 2005-2009 and English Language]; 2016 results.

Language]; 70097 results.
13. EMBASE; 3 AND 12 [Limit to: Publication Year 2005-2009 and English Language]; 295 results.

results.

results.

Language]; 56646 results.

10671 results.
18. EMBASE; exp META ANALYSIS/ [Limit to: Publication Year 2005-2009 and English Language]; 13882 results.
19. EMBASE; meta ADJ analys*.tw. [Limit to: Publication Year 2005-2009 and English Language]; 11648 results.
20. EMBASE; 14 OR 15 OR 16 OR 17 OR 18 OR 19 [Limit to: Publication Year 2005-2009 and English Language];
90777 results.
21. EMBASE; 13 AND 20 [Limit to: Publication Year 2005-2009 and English Language]; 48 results.

 

NHS evidence: whole collection search for cough

Search string: cough* AND (hospice* OR palliat* OR "end of life care" OR "supportive care" OR "terminal care" OR "terminally ill"), results sorted by date = 513. Then selected search filter: systematic reviews = 58

 

Melanie Hodson, November 2009

 

Search notes - Dyspnoea. Searcher = Denise Brady

Main search on Pubmed – using search terms as defined by NHS Evidence project team.  However, I did not limit this to clinical queries.  So I searched Dyspnoea and the agreed subject headings that relate to palliative care:

palliat* OR hospice* OR “terminal care” OR “terminally ill” OR “end-of-life-care” OR “end of life care” OR supportive

I then chose what I regarded as systematic reviews, meta-analyses and what seemed to be reviews from these results.

I used NHS Evidence suite of databases to search CINAHL confining myself to systematic reviews and meta-analyses.

I used Ovid to search Embase.

I searched Cochrane and DARE using  the term dyspnoea or dyspnea only.  I included only references that seemed to pertain to late stage disease.

I used dyspnoea to search NHS Evidence - supportive and palliative care.  

I used dyspnoea and palliative care as terms in all of NHS Evidence

Search was from 2007 to date based on the fact that a clinical knowledge summary was completed in 2007.

document.publisher: National Library for Health: Supportive and Pallliative Care Specialist Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 28 April 2008. Pain in supportive and palliative care. 2008

Introduction

This page gives the results of our search for systematic reviews and other high quality reviews on pain in supportive and palliative care published since our previous review 12 months ago. This comprises our Annual Evidence Update on pain for 2008.  

The 2007 Annual Evidence Update on pain is still available. Being our first on this topic, it included articles from the years 2000 to 2006.

The methodology for our search strategy can be found here.

The coverage includes not only advanced cancer (ie most of palliative care) but also other non-malignant conditions with chronic pain and cancer patients in the earlier stages of disease (supportive care).

This time there are 12 included reviews from the original total of 22 potential items in the first sift of our search.

 

Accessing these reviews

Links are included to PubMed abstracts or to the full text of Cochrane reviews. Full text versions may also be available for some items via online journals.

In addition to the journal subscriptions that your organisation may hold, the NHS buys a number of online journals which can be accessed if you have an Athens password. The A-Z list of NHS online journals is here: http://journals.library.nhs.uk/

If you need help accessing any of the resources listed here, or with getting an Athens password, please contact your local health library. The staff there will be happy to help. 

 

Commentary

(By Jason Boland)

Over the past year there has been a diversity of systematic reviews added to the palliative and supportive care literature. These include:

  • A review on the TRPV1 receptor and its role in pain with special reference to the role in capsaicin in pain management –  predicting a “revival” of this class of drug.
  • A review of the cannabinoid nabilone, suggests a role in both nerve pain and when central sensitisation exists. 
  • The use of Oxycodone in pain management indicated that this strong opioid is useful across a range of pain conditions and that the biphasic pharmacokinetic profile of the prolonged release offers rapid pain relief and due to its different properties may be an alternative to morphine. 
  • Despite this a review of physician barriers to cancer pain management shows that concerns about side effects led to ineffective doses being used, which is compounded by poor prescription of medicines to counteract the side effects.
  • A review of the evidence for palliative care at the end of life, indicted that there is evidence for interventions to improve end of life care, but many important issues lack quality evidence and this highlights the need for further work across the range of terminal conditions. 
  • There have been Cochrane reviews on the opioids methadone and morphine, as well as antidepressants for nerve pain.

 

2008

Capsaicin (TRPV1 Agonist) therapy for pain relief: farewell or revival?
Knotkova H, Pappagallo M, Szallasi A.
Clin J Pain. 2008 Feb;24(2):142-54.
Link to pubmed: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18209521

 

Evidence for improving palliative care at the end of life: a systematic review.
Lorenz KA, Lynn J, Dy SM, Shugarman LR, Wilkinson A, Mularski RA, Morton SC, Hughes RG, Hilton LK, Maglione M, Rhodes SL, Rolon C, Sun VC, Shekelle PG.
Lorenz KA
Ann Intern Med. 2008 Jan 15;148(2):147-59.
Link to pubmed: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18195339

 

Oral nabilone capsules in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting and pain.
Davis MP
Expert Opin Investig Drugs. 2008 Jan;17(1):85-95.Link to pubmed: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18095921

 

Oxycodone: a review of its use in the management of pain.
Riley J, Eisenberg E, Müller-Schwefe G, Drewes AM, Arendt-Nielsen L.
Curr Med Res Opin. 2008 Jan;24(1):175-92.
Link to pubmed
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18039433

 


2007

Physician-related barriers to cancer pain management with opioid analgesics: a systematic review.
Jacobsen R, Sjøgren P, Møldrup C, Christrup L.
J Opioid Manag. 2007 Jul-Aug;3(4):207-14.
Link to pubmed: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17957980

 

Antidepressants for neuropathic pain.
Saarto T, Wiffen PJ.
Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2007 Oct 17;(4):CD005454.
Link to full text

 

Methadone for cancer pain.
Nicholson AB
Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2007 Oct 17;(4):CD003971.
Link to pubmed: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17943808

 

Oral morphine for cancer pain.
Wiffen PJ, McQuay HJ.
Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2007 Oct 17;(4):CD003868.
Link to full text

 

Peripherally acting opioid antagonists in the treatment of opiate-related constipation: a systematic review.
Becker G, Galandi D, Blum HE.
J Pain Symptom Manage. 2007 Nov;34(5):547-65. Epub 2007 Sep 27.
Link to pubmed: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17900855

 

Optimal management of metastatic bone disease.
Major P
Eur J Oncol Nurs. 2007;11 Suppl 2:S32-7. Epub 2007 Sep 4.
Link to pubmed: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17804294

 

Burden of bone disease.
Kinnane N
Eur J Oncol Nurs. 2007;11 Suppl 2:S28-31. Epub 2007 Sep 4.
Link to pubmed: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17768092

 

Should we add clonidine to local anesthetic for peripheral nerve blockade? A qualitative systematic review of the literature.
McCartney CJ, Duggan E, Apatu E.
Reg Anesth Pain Med. 2007 Jul-Aug;32(4):330-8.
Link to pubmed: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17720118

 

For systematic reviews in 2000-2006 see the 2007 Annual Evidence Update on pain

]]>
