document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 30 April 2007. National Knowledge Week on pain in palliative and supportive care. Contents Page

This National Knowledge Week was organised by the National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care to highlight the best current evidence on this topic in a concise, easy to read format.

The National Knowledge Week pages include our first Annual Evidence Update on this topic, which this year was the result of a search for systematic reviews covering a broad view of pain in palliative and supportive care. Systematic reviews are regarded as the highest level of evidence on health interventions.

There are also links to other sources of information on pain in palliative and supportive care, and a range of invited commentaries from specialists.

As the National Knowledge Week comes one week after the British Pain Society Annual Scientific Meeting 2007, a special feature will be daily 'Meet the Expert' interviews with selected speakers at the conference.

The items below will be published on a day-by-day basis. The pages will remain accessible until the next Annual Evidence update in 12 months time. If you would like to contribute to this activity or you have any comments on how it could be improved, please use our feedback form.

 

Contents

 

Contributors' details and photos here.

 

Day One - Monday 30th April:

1. Introduction. By Professor Sam H Ahmedzai, Clinical Lead, National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care.

2. Annual Evidence Update on pain in palliative and supportive care - Systematic reviews. By Jason Boland, Richard Stevens, Sam H Ahmedzai.

3. Methodology for the Annual Evidence Update on pain in palliative and supportive care. By Richard Stevens.

4. Conference highlight:  Dr Joan Hester, President of the British Pain Society, introduces the Annual Scientific Meeting 2007.

 

Day Two - Tuesday 1st May:

5. Sources of knowledge on pain in palliative and supportive care within the Specialist Library. By Jason Boland, Richard Stevens, Sam H Ahmedzai.

6. Other resources on pain. Sam H Ahmedzai. Richard Stevens.

7. Conference highlight: Pete Moore and Di Wright from the Expert Patients Programme introduce PPP (Persistent Pain Programme) - helping patients to improve their own quality of life.

 

Day Three - Wednesday 2nd May:

8. Knowledge outline: "Mechanisms of pain". By Jason Boland.

9. Conference highlight: Professor Jürgen Sandkühler. The cellular mechanisms of pain memory.

10. Conference highlight: Professor Mike Salter. Microglia and pain.

 

Day Four - Thursday 3rd May:

11. Knowledge outline: "Medical management of cancer and chronic pain". Jason Boland, Sam H Ahmedzai.

12. Knowledge outline: "Breakthrough pain". By Laura McTague.

13. Knowledge outline: "Pain in HIV disease". By Jason Boland, David H Dockrell.

14. Conference highlight: Professor Henry McQuay. What have systematic reviews told us about managing pain?

 

Day Five - Friday 4th May:

15. Knowledge outline: "The role of the pain clinic". By Donald Graham. 

16. Conference highlight: Workshop on pain in cancer survivors

  • (a) Post-surgical pain in breast cancer. John Williams
  • (b) Chemotherapy-induced neuropathic pain. Paul Farquhar-Smith
  • (c) Pain in cancer survivors following radiotherapy. Bill Macrae

17. British Pain Society Cancer Pain Committee: Jon Raphael

18. "Pain in palliative and supportive care: The next 12 months". By Professor Sam H Ahmedzai, Clinical Lead, National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care.

 

 

]]>

document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 30 April 2007. National Knowledge Week on pain in palliative and supportive care. Expert Patients

Persistent Pain Programme – helping patients to improve their own quality of life

 

Pete Moore and Di Wright

The Expert Patients Programme has generated a large variety of self-help projects for patients with a wide range of chronic conditions.  One of these is the ‘Persistent Pain Programme’ (PPP), which was presented at the British Pain Society’s Annual Scientific Meeting in Glasgow on 24-27 April 2007. 

Two of the programme’s leaders, Pete Moore and Di Wright, were actively engaging delegates to the conference and informing them of the problems associated with persistent pain, and the benefits of PPP for these patients. 

Patients with persistent pain say they feel –

  • Different to other people
  • Their life is out of control
  • Becoming and keeping active could cause more harm
  • Depressed, angry and lack self-confidence
  • That they can’t enjoy a full life.

According to Pete and Di, the pain self-management approach of PPP consists of ‘learning and using simple skills to let YOU take more control of YOUR persistent pain’.

People who attend PPP learn

  • How to reduce good day – bad day episodes
  • How to pace daily activities
  • How to set goals and make action plans
  • Problem-solving techniques
  • How to manage pain flare-ups
  • How to manage the distress and low moods that come with persistent pain
  • Keeping active does not cause harm
  • How to manage relationships with family, friends, work colleagues and healthcare professionals
  • How to maintain a healthy diet
  • How to look forward and plan for the future.

Each programme runs for approximately two and a half hours each week for six weeks.  They are organised and run by trained tutors with direct experience of living with persistent pain.

 

For further details, contact –


Pete Moore pete.moore1@nhsepp.org
Di Wright Dianne.wright@nhsepp.org

www.expertpatients.nhs.uk

 

Return to the National Knowedge Week homepage

]]>

document.publisher: National Library for Health
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 30 April 2007. National Knowledge Week on pain in palliative and supportive care. Introduction

Welcome to the first National Knowledge Week run by the Specialist Library for Palliative and Supportive Care.  We chose ‘pain’, as this is probably the topic that is most commonly associated with the specialty of palliative care and it is also a major concern within the broader interdisciplinary field of supportive care. 

We acknowledge that pain management is clearly an important part of other acute illnesses and of chronic disease management, but these are covered by other specialist libraries in the National Library for Health (see, for example, the Musculoskeletal Diseases Library, the Trauma and Orthopaedics Library, and the Surgery, Theatres and Anaesthesia Library).

Our approach to searching for evidence is deliberately broad, encompassing both cancer and non-malignant diseases; early and advanced stages of disease; patients who are having treatment with curative or life-prolonging intent, and those at the end of life.

We have timed this National Knowledge Week on Pain to run just after the British Pain Society’s Annual Scientific Meeting, which was held in Glasgow from 25-27 April 2007.  For details of this exciting mixture of basic science, clinical research and patient experience, visit the BPS website.

Day by day the National Knowledge Week will contain a mixture of items –

  • Evidence review from the National Library for Health database and beyond
  • Specialist reviews focusing on topics of particular interest to practitioners in palliative and supportive care
  • Useful resources on pain
  • Highlights from the BPS 2007 Annual Scientific Meeting.

Please visit our webpages each day to take in this vast field of literature.  We will revisit the subject as a whole in one year’s time, but meanwhile, do visit the Pain section within the Palliative and Supportive Care specialist library for more frequent incremental additions to this evidence database.

 

Return to the National Knowledge Week homepage

]]>

document.publisher: National Library for Health: Supportive and Palliative Care Library

document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 30 March 2009: Pain in supportive and palliative care [1: Pain and cancer survivorship]

Methods

We searched PubMed and the St Christopher's Hospice Library literature database.

 

Search strategies


PubMed

MeSH term search:
Search string: ("Pain"[Mesh] AND "Neoplasms"[Mesh]) AND "Survivors"[Mesh]
Limits: Human. Added to PubMed between 01 Jan 2004 – 31 Jan 2009
(All results = 51)
Records defined by PubMed as 'Review' = 10

Textword search
Search string: (pain [tw] AND survivor* [tw] AND (cancer [tw] OR neoplasm* [tw]) ) AND systematic[sb]
Using “Clinical Query” and “Find systematic reviews” field
Limits: human, English language
Date added to PubMed: 01 Jan 2008 – 31 Jan 2009


St Christopher's Hospice Library database

Searched simply for "cancer survivors"

 

Commentary

No meta-analyses or systematic reviews were found. References found in the search were mostly review articles/case reviews/comparative studies. There was one small RCT. We looked at the full text of some articles which we thought may be good quality ‘other’ studies.

 

Systematic reviews and meta-analyses

None were found.

 

Other resources


2008

Opioids and cancer survivors: issues in side-effect management. Palos GR. Oncol Nurs Forum. 2008 Nov;35 Suppl:13-9. [Get PubMed abstract]

Effect of exercise on upper extremity pain and dysfunction in head and neck cancer survivors: a randomized controlled trial. McNeely ML, Parliament MB, Seikaly H, Jha N, Magee DJ, Haykowsky MJ, Courneya KS. Cancer. 2008 Jul 1;113(1):214-22. [Get PubMed abstract]

Chronic pain in the cancer survivor: a new frontier. Burton AW, Fanciullo GJ, Beasley RD, Fisch MJ. Pain Med. 2007 Mar;8(2):189-98. [Get PubMed abstract]

Content comparison of quality of life questionnaires used in head and neck cancer based on the international classification of functioning, disability and health: a systematic review.  Tschiesner U, Rogers SN, Harréus U, Berghaus A, Cieza A. Eur Arch Otorhinolaryngol. 2008 Jun;265(6):627-37.  [Get PubMed abstract]

Surviving cancer: a comparison of 5-year disease-free breast cancer survivors with healthy women. Helgeson VS, Tomich PL. Psycho-Oncol 05 v14 no4 p307-17 [Get PubMed abstract]

Sentinel lymph node biopsy and axillary dissection: added morbidity of the arm, shoulder and chest wall after mastectomy and reconstruction. Sclafani LM, Baron RH. Cancer J. 2008 Jul-Aug;14(4):216-22. [Get PubMed abstract]

Lymphedema after breast cancer: incidence, risk factors, and effect on upper body function. Hayes SC, Janda M, Cornish B, Battistutta D, Newman B. J Clin Oncol. 2008 Jul 20;26(21):3536-42.  [Get PubMed abstract]

 

2007

Patient-reported outcomes in cancer: a review of recent research and policy initiatives. Lipscomb J, Gotay CC, Snyder CF. CA Cancer J Clin. 2007 Sep-Oct;57(5):278-300. [Get PubMed abstract]

Fatigue in breast cancer survivors two to five years post diagnosis: a HEAL Study report. Meeske K, Smith AW, Alfano CM, McGregor BA, McTiernan A, Baumgartner KB, Malone KE, Reeve BB, Ballard-Barbash R, Bernstein L. Qual Life Res. 2007 Aug;16(6):947-60. Epub 2007 Apr 25 [Get PubMed abstract]

Physical activity, long-term symptoms, and physical health-related quality of life among breast cancer survivors: a prospective analysis. Alfano CM, Smith AW, Irwin ML, Bowen DJ, Sorensen B, Reeve BB, Meeske KA, Bernstein L, Baumgartner KB, Ballard-Barbash R, Malone KE, McTiernan A. .J Cancer Surviv. 2007 Jun;1(2):116-28. [Get PubMed abstract]

 

See also

National Cancer Survivorship Initiative Newsletters 

 

Authors

  • Ashique Ahamed
  • Sam H Ahmedzai
  • Jason Boland
  • Denise Brady
  • Elaine Cachia
  • Clare Farrington
  • Melanie Hodson
  • Georgina Keenleyside

  • Phil Wiffen

111-1Annual Evidence Update 30 March 2009: Pain in supportive and palliative care [3: Pain and cannabinoids]

Methods

We used the PubMed Clinical Queries search filter to find Systematic Reviews and limited the search to 'humans', published 2007 to date

First of all we searched for ‘pain’ systematic reviews, then searched for ‘cannabi*’ within those.

Of the 9 records found, 6 are labelled ‘reviews’ by PubMed. We included 5 of these in our list below.

 

 

Systematic reviews

 

2008

Complementary therapies for neuropathic and neuralgic pain: systematic review. Pittler MH, Ernst E. Clin J Pain. 2008 Oct;24(8):731-3. [Get PubMed abstract]

 

Adverse effects of medical cannabinoids: a systematic review. Wang T, Collet JP, Shapiro S, Ware MA. CMAJ. 2008 Jun 17;178(13):1669-78. Comment in: CMAJ. 2008 Jun 17;178(13):1685-6.    Evid Based Nurs. 2009 Jan;12(1):16. [Get PubMed abstract]

 

Pharmacological management of neuropathic pain following spinal cord injury. Baastrup C, Finnerup NB. CNS Drugs. 2008;22(6):455-75. PMID: 18484790 [Get PubMed abstract]

 

Oral nabilone capsules in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting and pain. Davis MP. Expert Opin Investig Drugs. 2008 Jan;17(1):85-95.[Get PubMed abstract]

 

2007

Pharmacological management of chronic neuropathic pain - consensus statement and guidelines from the Canadian Pain Society. Moulin DE, Clark AJ, Gilron I, Ware MA, Watson CP, Sessle BJ, Coderre T,Morley-Forster PK, Stinson J, Boulanger A, Peng P, Finley GA, Taenzer P, Squire P, Dion D, Cholkan A, Gilani A, Gordon A, Henry J, Jovey R, Lynch M,Mailis-Gagnon A, Panju A, Rollman GB, Velly A; Canadian Pain Society. document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 30 March 2009: Pain in supportive and palliative care. [2: Pain and dementia]

Methods

Search strategies

MEDLINE
1. Pain (exploded subject heading)
2. Pain measurement (exploded subject heading)
3. 1 or 2
4. Dementia (exploded subject heading and major descriptor/focus)
5. 3 and 4   (176 items)
6. Limit to meta analysis as publication type
7. Limit to systematic and review (title or abstract)

EMBASE
1. Dementia (exploded subject heading and major descriptor/focus)
2. Pain assessment (exploded subject heading) or pain assessment (exploded subject heading)
3. Meta analysis or systematic review (as subject headings)

Systematic reviews

document.publisher: National Library for Health: Supportive and Palliative Care Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,CANCER,NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT,ALZHEIMER’S DISEASE,MEDICINES]]>
document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 30 March 2009: Pain in supportive and palliative care. Contents Page

  

1: Pain and cancer survivorship

 

2: Pain and dementia

 

3: Pain and cannabinoids

 

Introduction

Welcome to the third Annual Evidence Update from the Supportive and Palliative Care Specialist Library on pain.  This year we have broadened our scope somewhat to capture three areas which are of increasing clinical interest: pain in the expanding group of cancer ‘survivors’; pain in older people with dementia; and the use of cannabinoids for pain management. Although these are clinically of relevance to specific groups of professionals (broadly speaking, to oncologists, geriatricians and chronic pain specialists respectively), we hope that the literature in these areas will be of interest to all who deal with chronic pain. 

We were disappointed to find relatively little grade 1 evidence (systematic review and meta-analysis) in any of the areas, and so we have included lower grade publications and also additional resources such as reports and individual trials.

]]>

document.title: Annual Evidence Update 6 September 2010: Treatments for anorexia and cachexia in chronic disease and palliative care. Commentary
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - supportive and palliative care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,GASTRO-INTESTINAL,NUTRITION,WEIGHT LOSS]]>
document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 6 September 2010: Treatments for anorexia and cachexia in chronic disease and palliative care. Commentary

 

[Return to AEU contents page]

Anorexia (lack of appetite and interest in eating) is one of the commonest symptoms in patients with acute and chronic illnesses. The pathophysiology behind it is very complex and still incompletely understood. It is one of the main factors leading to poor quality of life in patients and carers.  It is distressing for both professional and family carers as providing food is one of the principal ways of caring for someone.

Cachexia is a metabolic syndrome which is found not only in patients with cancer, but also in many other chronic illnesses such as COPD, heart failure, rheumatoid conditions, AIDS etc. Ongoing research is revealing the complicated interactions between different organs and biological systems that result in the clinical manifestations of this syndrome, namely anorexia, loss of muscle and fat, weight loss and asthenia (weakness) (Evans 2008). It is partly due to this marked complexity that current clinical interventions have failed to provide much benefit.

It appears that inflammation, insulin resistance and break down of muscle and fat are important components of the anorexia-cachexia syndrome (ACS).  These are not helped by simple protein and energy supplementation, except in highly selected cases. A systematic review on the management of cancer-related anorexia and cachexia concluded that current approaches to treatment, with use of nutritional supplements and dietary advice to increase energy and protein intake, have failed to improve nutritional status or any other examined outcome, such as appetite, quality of life, survival, disease progression etc (Brown, 2002). Megestrol acetate increased appetite and weight and improved the sense of well-being but had no effect on nutritional status of patients or survival, while exercise seemed to bring some benefit to nutritional parameters.

A number of recent studies and reviews covered in this AEU have examined various treatment strategies. Still it appears that we have a long way to go. The first step in the provision of nutritional care is to use a nutrition screening tool to recognise those patients that require special care and attention. The second step is a formal nutrition assessment (carried out by trained staff) which aims to identify the nutrition issues for the patient, which should then lead to an individualised nutritional care plan. Although a number of such screening and assessment tools exist in other areas, one adapted to the specific needs of palliative care patients has yet to be developed. The Food and Nutrition Group at Help the Hospices is currently in the process of developing such a specific nutritional screening and assessment tool for palliative care and has produced a Consensus Statement that has been endorsed by many organisations (Food and Nutrition Group 2009).

There is an urgent need to advance the care of patients with anorexia and cachexia and move it to the modern age of nutrigenomics and epigenetics (Ornish 2008; Tollefsbol 2010). Nutrition and its importance is gaining more interest and awareness among healthcare professionals. Additionally, more research to evaluate the potential benefits of different methods of care is needed. The wide-range of research findings produced by other disciplines have the potential to develop into better possibilities of helping patients with chronic, incurable diseases. For example:

  • scientific evidence points to certain foods, cooking methods and physical activity as having a significant pro-inflammatory or anti-inflammatory effect (Warnberg 2009; O’Connor 2010).
  • In cancer patients with ACS, nutrients such as omega-3 fatty acids have been shown to have anti-inflammatory effect and help them stabilise their weight (August 2009), while 
  •  increased consumption of lean and oily fish has led to a reduction in serum C-reactive protein (Pot 2010) .

Until further research increases our understanding still further, using our present knowledge and best judgment can help each individual patient benefit from recent discoveries. The benefits of a scientific approach to understanding and managing ACS should apply across the whole spectrum of chronic disease, not only in the palliative or end of life stage. The author makes a plea for the recognition that many aspects of healthcare and medicine centered on nutritional considerations need to be stepped up fundamentally.

Dr Eleni Tsiompanou

Associate Specialist in Palliative Medicine

Kingston Hospital and Princess Alice Hospice

Chair of the Food and Nutrition Group at Help the Hospices

 

References

  • August, D. A., Huhmann, M. B.; American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition (A.S.P.E.N.) Board of Directors, 2009. A.S.P.E.N. clinical guidelines: nutrition support therapy during anticancer treatment and in hematopoietic cell transplantation. Journal of Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition, 33: 472-500. [Abstract]
  • Brown JK (2002) A systematic review on the evidence on symptom management of cancer-related anorexia and cachexia. Oncol Nurs Forum 29(3):517-32. [Abstract]
  • Evans WJ, Morley JE, Argiles j et al (2008) Cachexia: A New Definition. Clin Nutr 27:793-9. [Abstract]
  • Food and Nutrition Group at Help the Hospices, 2009. Professional consensus statement of nutritional care in palliative care patients. thttp://www.helpthehospices.org.uk/our-services/running-your-hospice/food-and-nutrition/consensus-statement/  [Full text]
  • O’Connor, M. F. & Irvin, M. R., 2010. Links between behavioral factors and inflammation. Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics, doi:10.1038/clpt.2009.255. [Abstract]
  • Ornish, D., Magbanua, M. J., Weidner, G, Weinberg, V., Kemp, C. Green, C., Mattie, M. D., Marlin, R., Simko, J., Shinohara, K., Haqq, C. M. & Carroll, P. R., 2008 (1). Changes in prostate gene expression in men undergoing an intensive nutrition and lifestyle intervention. Proceedings of the National Academies of Sciences USA, 105: 8369-8374. [Abstract]
  • Pot, G. K., Geelen, A., Majsak-Newman, G., Harvey, L. J., Nagengast, F. M., Witteman, B. J., van de Meeberg, P. C., Hart, A. R., Schaafsma, G., Lund, E. K., Rijkers, G. T. & Kampman, E, 2010. Increased consumption of fatty and lean fish reduces serum C-reactive protein concentrations but not inflammation markers in feces and colonic biopsies. Journal of Nutrition, 140: 371-6. [Abstract]
  • Tollefsbol, T. O. Role of epigenetics in cancer. In: Cancer epigenetics, ed. Tollefsbol Trygve O, 1-4. CRC Press; Boca Raton: 2009. [COPAC citation]
  • Warnberg, L., Gomez-Martinez, S., Romeo, J., Diaz, L. E. & Marcos, A., 2009. Nutrition, inflammation and cognitive function. Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences, 1153: 164-75. [Abstract]

 

For further information about the Help the Hospices' Food and Nutrition Group, visit:

http://www.helpthehospices.org.uk/our-services/running-your-hospice/food-and-nutrition

 

 

[Return to AEU contents page]

 

]]>

document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 6 September 2010: Treatments for anorexia and cachexia in chronic disease and palliative care. Introduction

[Return to AEU contents page]

Welcome to this AEU on treatments for anorexia and cachexia in chronic disease and palliative care. This is our third AEU on gastrointestinal symptoms in supportive and palliative care. The previous two are still available here.

We are grateful to Dr Eleni Tsiompanou for providing the commentary. Dr Tsiompanou is Associate Specialist in Palliative Medicine at Kingston Hospital and Princess Alice Hospice, and Chair of the Food and Nutrition Group at Help the Hospices.

We would also like to thank the members of the editorial team who have contributed to this AEU:

  • Ashique Ahamed
  • Denise Brady
  • Melanie Hodson
  • Sarah Mollart
  • Clare Rayment

Sam H Ahmedzai, Clinical Lead

Richard Stevens, Project Manager/Information Specialist

[Return to AEU contents page]

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Annual Evidence Update 6 September 2010: Treatments for anorexia and cachexia in chronic disease and palliative care. Methodology
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - supportive and palliative care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,GASTRO-INTESTINAL,WEIGHT LOSS]]>
document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 6 September 2010: Treatments for anorexia and cachexia in chronic disease and palliative care. Methodology

[Return to AEU contents page]

 

Databases searched

Pubmed/Medline, EMBASE, Cochrane, CINAHL, DARE, AMED.

We also searched: NHS Evidence main page, 'NHS Evidence - Supportive and palliative care' specialist collection. 

 

Search strategies

 

PUBMED [anorexia]:

The “Clinical Query” PubMed search on anorexia, covered material published in the last five years.

The search string below shows the strategy entered with number of results. There were 122 results in all We went through the results list and excluded references:

  • relating to anorexia nervosa
  • two withdrawn references (one relating to tacrine for alzheimer’s disease and the other about dopamine agonists for cocaine dependence).

However, some of the results were “false hits” – ie: records where we were unsure if there could be any clinical relevance, so we included them just in case.

(anorexia [mh] OR anorex* [tw]) AND systematic[sb] Limits: Humans, English, Publication Date from 2005/01/01 to 2010/07/31 06:07:28 122

  
("anorexia"[MeSH Terms] OR (anorexia[tw] OR anorexia/adipsia[tw] OR anorexia/bulimia[tw] OR anorexia/cachexia[tw] OR anorexia/decreased[tw] OR anorexia/early[tw] OR anorexia/fatigue[tw] OR anorexia/feed[tw] OR anorexia/hunger[tw] OR anorexia/hypokalemia[tw] OR anorexia/hypophagia[tw] OR anorexia/inapettence[tw] OR anorexia/low[tw] OR anorexia/nausea[tw] OR anorexia/nausea/vomiting[tw] OR anorexia/pharyngitis[tw] OR anorexia/poor[tw] OR anorexia/vomiting[tw] OR anorexia/weight[tw] OR anorexia'[tw] OR anorexia's[tw] OR anorexiagenic[tw] OR anorexiant[tw] OR anorexiants[tw] OR anorexias[tw] OR anorexic[tw] OR anorexic's[tw] OR anorexicants[tw] OR anorexicnation[tw] OR anorexics[tw] OR anorexics'[tw] OR anorexictics[tw] OR anorexient[tw] OR anorexients[tw] OR anorexigen[tw] OR anorexigene[tw] OR anorexigenesis[tw] OR anorexigenic[tw] OR anorexigenic/catabolic[tw] OR anorexigenic/orexigenic[tw] OR anorexigenics[tw] OR anorexigenig[tw] OR anorexigens[tw] OR anorexigens'[tw] OR anorexignic[tw] OR anorexikum[tw] OR anorexin[tw] OR anorexine[tw] OR anorexinergic[tw] OR anorexinogen[tw] OR anorexinogens[tw] OR anorexins[tw] OR anorexiogenic[tw] OR anorexipens[tw] OR anorexogen[tw] OR anorexogenic[tw] OR anorexua[tw] OR anorexy[tw] OR anorexygenic[tw])) AND systematic[sb] AND ("humans"[MeSH Terms] AND English[lang] AND ("2005/01/01"[PDAT] : "2010/07/31"[PDAT]))

 

PUBMED [cahexia]:

The PubMed “Clinical Query” search on Cachexia is below. This is for period 2000-2010 and as there were just 48 results we did not sift this list at this stage.

Search string used here was:

Search (cachexia [mh] OR cachex* [tw]) AND systematic[sb] Limits: Humans, English, Publication Date from 2000/01/01 to 2010/07/31 08:04:30 48

And this was translated by PubMed into:
("cachexia"[MeSH Terms] OR (cachexia[tw] OR cachexia/anorexia[tw] OR cachexia/dehydration[tw] OR cachexia/disability[tw] OR cachexia/proteolysis[tw] OR cachexia/uremia[tw] OR cachexia/wasting[tw] OR cachexia'[tw] OR cachexia's[tw] OR cachexias[tw] OR cachexic[tw] OR cachexigenic[tw] OR cachexin[tw] OR cachexins[tw] OR cachexy[tw] OR cachexysing[tw])) AND systematic[sb] AND ("humans"[MeSH Terms] AND English[lang] AND ("2000/01/01"[PDAT] : "2010/07/31"[PDAT]))

 

CINAHL:

1. Anorexia (Subject heading)
2. Cachexia  (Subject heading)
3. Systematic review (Subject heading)
4. systematic review (free text)
5. Meta analysis (Subject heading)
6. Practice guidelines (Subject heading)
7. consensus (free text)
8. 3 or 4 or 5 or 6 or 7
9. 1 or 2
10. 8 and 9

(no year restriction)

 

EMBASE:

(focused on the first 2 subject headings because there were such large numbers - over 27,000 for anorexia and over 5690 for cachexia)

1. Anorexia (Subject heading focussed)
2. Cachexia (Subject heading and focussed)
3. Systematic review (Subject heading)
4. systematic review (free text)
5  Meta analysis (Subject heading)
6. Practice guideline (Subject heading)
7. Consensus (Subject heading)
8. 1 or 2
9. 3 or 4 or 5 or 6 or 7
10. 8 and 9 and  (2005-2010)

 

NHS EVIDENCE:

In searching NHS evidence we searched anorexia and cachexia as joint terms and found 169 items which were looked through.  If already found in one of the above searches, we did not included them in results. 

We also searched the first 30 items on anorexia as a stand-alone term and the first 30 items on cachexia.  This should be the items most recently added to NHS Evidence and thus, the most recent. 

 

Reviewing

Search results were passed to three reviewers (Ashique Ahamed, Sarah Mollart and Clare Rayment) for assessment of abstracts for quality and relevance. The final list was agreed by Prof Sam H Ahmedzai. At this final stage, after further reflection, we decided to exclude anything published before 2005.

 

[Return to AEU contents page]

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Annual Evidence Update 9 February 2009: Gastrointestinal symptoms in supportive and palliative care
document.publisher: National Library for Health: Supportive and Palliative Care Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,GASTRO-INTESTINAL,NAUSEA & VOMITING,STOMACH,GASTROENTEROLOGY & LIVER DISEASES,COMMON CLINICAL PRESENTATIONS,COLON & RECTUM,CANCER,RECENT ADDITIONS,FEBRUARY 2009]]>
document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update 9 February 2009: Gastrointestinal symptoms in supportive and palliative care

Contents

 

  • Nausea and vomiting

 

  • Constipation

 

  • Bowel obstruction

 

 

Introduction

 

This week we are pleased to present the first supportive and palliative care Annual Evidence Update on symptom management in gastroenterology. The latest high quality evidence is collected together on three common and troublesome conditions which continue to pose challenges in symptom management. These areas are Nausea & Vomiting, Bowel Obstruction and Constipation. All of these have a multitude of aetiologies and although critical to investigate and if possible treat the underlying problem, it is important to also manage the symptoms themselves.

Supportive and palliative care in our view, encompasses much more than cancer and terminal illness - see definitions.

We therefore embrace the symptom management (both physical and psychological) aspects of many illnesses, especially chronic diseases. However, even with acute illnesses there may be important lessons to be learnt about symptom management which may be transferable to other conditions.  Thus, the reviews included encompass a range of medical topics which would not normally be found in a ‘traditional palliative care’ review, eg nausea and vomiting associated with gastroenteritis and following cranial surgery.

This update collects together the best current knowledge on the supportive care management of these conditions, concentrating on systematic reviews as well as high quality reviews and randomised controlled trials within the scope of supportive and palliative care.  We have also included some expert-led consensus statements and guidelines, as although they may not meet the definition of ‘systematic review’, they may be more immediately applicable in a clinical situation and they do contain detailed references.

The contents of this Annual Evidence Update should be browsed in conjunction with the often much more detailed literature on the underlying conditions which are found in the Specialist Library for Gastroenterology and Liver Diseases.

 

Jason Boland
Elaine Cachia
Clare Wotton
Sam H Ahmedzai
Richard Stevens

 

]]>

document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update on pain in palliative and supportive care - Systematic reviews

This page gives the results of our search for systematic reviews and other high quality reviews on pain in palliative and supportive care.

The methodology of our search strategy can be found here.

We have made a deliberately broad sweep of the literature for this, our first National Knowledge Update on Pain within this specialist library –

  • Inclusion of articles from 2000 up till 2006.  Future annual evidence updates will be restricted to the previous year’s literature output
  • Inclusion of not only advanced cancer (ie most of palliative care) but also other non-malignant conditions with chronic pain and cancer patients in the earlier stages of disease (supportive care).

The 37 included reviews (from the original total of 93) are below. They are listed by year of publication, in reverse chronological order from 2006 back to 2000.

Links are included to PubMed abstracts (full text versions may also be available for some items) or Cochrane reviews.

In addition to the journal subscriptions that your organisation may hold, the NHS buys a number of online journals which can be accessed if you have an Athens password. The A-Z list of NHS online journals is here: http://journals.library.nhs.uk/

If you need help accessing any of the resources listed here, or with getting an Athens password, please contact your local health library. The staff there will be happy to help.

 

 

 

Published in 2006:

 

 

[1] Pain assessment tools: is the content appropriate for use in palliative care? Link to PubMed abstract 

Holen JC, Hjermstad MJ, Loge JH, Fayers PM, Caraceni A, De Conno F, Forbes K, Furst CJ, Radbruch L, Kaasa S. J Pain Symptom Manage. 2006 Dec;32(6):567-80.

[6] Evaluating CAM treatment at the end of life: a review of clinical trials for massage and meditation. Link to PubMed abstract

[8] Oxycodone for cancer-related pain: meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. Link to PubMed abstract

Erratum in:

Published in 2005:

document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update. 7 September 2009: Gastrointestinal symptoms in supportive and palliative care. 1: Mouth care

Go to the Contents page for this AEU

 

Note on scope

One of our original 'topics' was 'Mouth care', which would have included such diverse clinical situations as candidiasis to xerostomia (dry mouth). We have therefore focused this time on just one subject - mucositis - as this conceptually, and pathophysiologically, links in with another topic of this AEU, namely chemotherapy-related diarrhoea. Other important  mouth care subjects will be reviewed in future AEUs.

We assigned the selected records to 3 categories:

  • Radiotherapy and chemotherapy (mixed)
  • Radiotherapy alone
  • Chemotherapy alone

 

Radiotherapy and chemotherapy (Mixed)

  • A review of quality assessment of the methodology used in guidelines and systematic reviews on oral mucositis. Potting, Carin. Mistiaen, Patriek. Poot, Else. Blijlevens, Nicole. Donnelly, Peter. van Achterberg, Theo. Journal of Clinical Nursing. 18(1):3-12, 2009. PMID: 19120727 
  • Management of oral and gastrointestinal mucositis: ESMO Clinical Recommendations. Peterson D.E., Bensadoun R.-J., Roila F. Annals of Oncology. 20(SUPPL. 4)(pp iv174-iv177), 2009. PMID: 19454447   Full text 
  • NCCN task force report: Prevention and management of mucositis in cancer care. Bensinger W. Schubert M. Ang K.-K. Brizel D. Brown E. Eilers J.G. Elting L. Mittal B.B. Schattner M.A. Spielberger R. Treister N.S. Trotti III A.M. JNCCN Journal of the National Comprehensive Cancer Network. 6(SUPPL. 1)(pp S1-S21), 2008. PMID: 18289497   Full text 
  • Interventions for preventing oral mucositis for patients with cancer receiving treatment. Helen V Worthington, Jan E Clarkson, Tim OB Eden. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2007 Oct 17;(4):CD000978. PMID: 17943748   Full text
  • Several therapies may prevent or reduce the severity of oral mucositis associated with cancer treatment.[comment]. Sutherland S. Evid Based Dent. 2006;7(4):104-5. PMID: 17187045  Note - although this record is labelled in pubmed merely a 'comment', it is more of a summary review.
  • Preventive intervention possibilities in radiotherapy- and chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis: results of meta-analyses. Stokman MA, Spijkervet FK, Boezen HM, Schouten JP, Roodenburg JL, de Vries EG. Journal of Dental Research. 85(8):690-700, 2006 Aug. PMID: 16861284 

 

Chemotherapy

  • Emerging drugs for chemotherapy-induced mucositis. Expert Opin Emerg Drugs. 2008 Sep;13(3):511-22.  Keefe DM, Sonis ST, Bowen JM. PMID: 18764726
  • The effectiveness of commonly used mouthwashes for the prevention of chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis: a systematic review. Potting CMJ, Uitterhoeve R, Scholte Op Reimer W, Van Achterberg T. European Journal of Cancer Care, 01 December 2006, vol./is. 15/5(431-439), 09615423. PMID: 17177899

 

Radiotherapy

  • Amifostine reduces side effects and improves complete response rate during radiotherapy: results of a meta-analysis. Sasse, Andre Deeke. Clark, Luciana Gontijo de Oliveira. Sasse, Emma Chen. Clark, Otavio Augusto Camara. International Journal of Radiation Oncology, Biology, Physics 2006. 64(3):784-91. PMID: 16198504   Full text 

Go to the Contents page for this AEU

document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update. 7 September 2009: Gastrointestinal symptoms in supportive and palliative care. 2: PEG feeding

Go to the Contents page for this AEU

 

Search

Following a preliminary search, we searched Pubmed for the last 10 years for systematic reviews (clinical queries filter) for:

percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG)

We did not limit to ‘palliative’ at all.

48 results were found which are tagged by medline as ‘reviews’ and potentially systematic reviews.

We selected 9 records from the list of 48 which we considered to be most relevant for our field and of sufficient quality. We assigned them to 3 categories:

  • Cancer
  • Non-malignant disease
  • General management.

 

 

Cancer

  • Complications following gastrostomy tube insertion in patients with head and neck cancer: a prospective multi-institution study, systematic review and meta-analysis. Grant DG, Bradley PT, Pothier DD, Bailey D, Caldera S, Baldwin DL, Birchall MA. Clin Otolaryngol. 2009 Apr;34(2):103-12. PMID: 19413607

 

Non-malignant disease

  • Enteral tube feeding for older people with advanced dementia. Sampson EL, Candy B, Jones L. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2009 Apr 15;(2):CD007209. PMID: 19370678   Full text 
  • Good practice in the management of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis: clinical guidelines. An evidence-based review with good practice points. EALSC Working Group. Andersen PM, Borasio GD, Dengler R, Hardiman O, Kollewe K, Leigh PN, Pradat PF, Silani V, Tomik B; EALSC Working Group. Amyotroph Lateral Scler. 2007 Aug;8(4):195-213. PMID: 17653917 
  • Enteral tube feeding for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis/motor neuron disease. Langmore SE, Kasarskis EJ, Manca ML, Olney RK. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2006 Oct 18;(4):CD004030. PMID: 17054194   Full text
    Gastrostomy feeding in cerebral palsy: a systematic review. Sleigh G, Brocklehurst P. Arch Dis Child. 2004 Jun;89(6):534-9. PMID: 15155398  
  • Interventions for dysphagia in acute stroke. Bath PM, Bath FJ, Smithard DG. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2000;(2):CD000323. PMID: 10796343   Full text

 

General management

  • A systematic review of nursing administration of medication via enteral tubes in adults. Phillips NM, Nay R. J Clin Nurs. 2008 Sep;17(17):2257-65. PMID: 18705702  
  • Meta-analysis: antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent peristomal infection following percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy. Jafri NS, Mahid SS, Minor KS, Idstein SR, Hornung CA, Galandiuk S. Aliment Pharmacol Ther. 2007 Mar 15;25(6):647-56. PMID: 17311597 
  • Systemic antimicrobial prophylaxis for percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy. Lipp A, Lusardi G. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2006 Oct 18;(4):CD005571. PMID: 17054265  Full text 

 

Go to the Contents page for this AEU

 

]]>

document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update. 7 September 2009: Gastrointestinal symptoms in supportive and palliative care. 3: Diarrhoea

Go to the Contents page for this AEU

We did a "Clinical Queries" search on PubMed to find systematic reviews published between Jan 2007 and July 2009. The search was not restricted to palliative care. We searched for diarrhea as a mesh term and diarrhoea / diarrhea as textwords. Limits applied: human and English language. This retrieved 176 results.

Search string: (diarrhea[mh] OR diarrhea[tw] OR diarrhoea[tw]) AND systematic[sb] Limits: Publication Date from 2007/01/01 to 2009/07/31, Humans, English. We excluded those records dealing only with children.

We assigned the list of selected records to 7 categories: 

  • Treatment-induced
  • Infectious
  • Malabsorption
  • Assessment
  • Faecal incontinence
  • Inflammatory
  • Functional

 

Treatment-induced

  • Emerging drugs for chemotherapy-induced mucositis. Expert Opin Emerg Drugs. 2008 Sep;13(3):511-22.  Keefe DM, Sonis ST, Bowen JM. PMID: 18764726
  • Evaluation and management of treatment-related diarrhea in patients with advanced cancer: a review. Cherny NI. J Pain Symptom Manage. 2008 Oct;36(4):413-23. Epub 2008 Apr 14. PMID: 18411014
  • Safety of multi-targeted kinase inhibitors as monotherapy treatment of cancer: a systematic review of the literature. Curr Drug Saf. 2009 Crean S, Boyd DM, Sercus B, Lahn M. May;4(2):143-54.  PMID: 19442108
  • Toxic effects and their management: daily clinical challenges in the treatment of colorectal cancer. Eng C. Nat Rev Clin Oncol. 2009 Apr;6(4):207-18. PMID: 19333227
  • The use of irinotecan, oxaliplatin and raltitrexed for the treatment of advanced colorectal cancer: systematic review and economic evaluation. Hind D, Tappenden P, Tumur I, Eggington S, Sutcliffe P, Ryan A. Health Technol Assess. 2008 May;12(15):iii-ix, xi-162. PMID: 18462574   Full text

 

Infectious

  • Probiotics, critical illness, and methodologic bias. Koretz RL. Nutr Clin Pract. 2009 Feb-Mar;24(1):45-9. PMID: 19244148
  • Recurrent Clostridium difficile infection: a review of risk factors, treatments, and outcomes. Johnson S. J Infect. 2009 Jun;58(6):403-10. Epub 2009 Apr 5. PMID: 19394704
  • Antimotility agents for the treatment of Clostridium difficile diarrhea and colitis. Koo HL, Koo DC, Musher DM, DuPont HL. Clin Infect Dis. 2009 Mar 1;48(5):598-605.  PMID: 19191646
  • Meta-analysis to assess risk factors for recurrent Clostridium difficile infection. Garey KW, Sethi S, Yadav Y, DuPont HL. J Hosp Infect. 2008 Dec;70(4):298-304. Epub 2008 Oct 31. PMID: 18951661
  • Clinical review of the management of fulminant clostridium difficile infection. Jaber MR, Olafsson S, Fung WL, Reeves ME. Am J Gastroenterol. 2008 Dec;103(12):3195-203; quiz 3204. Epub 2008 Oct 1. PMID: 18853982
  • Infection control measures to limit the spread of Clostridium difficile. Vonberg RP, Kuijper EJ, Wilcox MH, Barbut F, Tüll P, Gastmeier P; Clin Microbiol Infect. 2008 May;14 Suppl 5:2-20. PMID: 18412710
  • Probiotics for prevention of antibiotic-associated diarrhea. Doron SI, Hibberd PL, Gorbach SL. J Clin Gastroenterol. 2008 Jul;42 Suppl 2:S58-63. PMID: 18542041
  • Probiotics, prebiotics, and synbiotics. de Vrese M, Schrezenmeir J. Adv Biochem Eng Biotechnol. 2008;111:1-66. PMID: 18461293
  • Rifamycin antibiotics for treatment of Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea. Garey KW, Salazar M, Shah D, Rodrigue R, DuPont HL. Ann Pharmacother. 2008 Jun;42(6):827-35. Epub 2008 Apr 22. PMID: 18430792
  • Defining surgical therapy for pseudomembranous colitis with toxic megacolon. Berman L, Carling T, Fitzgerald TN, Bell RL, Duffy AJ, Longo WE, Roberts KE. J Clin Gastroenterol. 2008 May-Jun;42(5):476-80. PMID: 18277885
  • Probiotics for treatment of Clostridium difficile-associated colitis in adults. Pillai A, Nelson R. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2008 Jan 23;(1):CD004611. PMID: 18254055   Full text

 

Malabsorption

  • Systematic review: pancreatic enzyme treatment of malabsorption associated with chronic pancreatitis. Waljee AK, Dimagno MJ, Wu BU, Schoenfeld PS, Conwell DL. Aliment Pharmacol Ther. 2009 Feb 1;29(3):235-46. Epub 2008 Nov 8. PMID: 19035969

 

Assessment

  • Appropriateness of colonoscopy in Europe (EPAGE II). Chronic diarrhea and known inflammatory bowel disease. Schusselé Filliettaz S, Juillerat P, Burnand B, Arditi C, Windsor A, Beglinger C, Dubois RW, Peytremann-Bridevaux I, Pittet V, Gonvers JJ, Froehlich F, Vader JP; EPAGE II Study Group. Endoscopy. 2009 Mar;41(3):218-26. Epub 2009 Mar 11. PMID: 19280533

 

Faecal incontinence

  • Pharmacotherapy guidelines for the aged by family doctors for the use of family doctors - Part C Special Pharmacology. Bergert FW, Conrad D, Ehrenthal K, Fessler J, Gross J, Gundermann K, Kluthe B, Lang Heinrich W, Liesenfeld A, Loew PG, Luther E, Pchalek R, Seffrin J, Sterzing A, Wolfring HJ, Zimmermann U; Guideline Group Hesse. Int J Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2009 Apr;47(4):223-8. PMID: 19356387

 

Inflammatory

  • Omega 3 fatty acids (fish oil) for maintenance of remission in Crohn's disease. Turner D, Zlotkin SH, Shah PS, Griffiths AM. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2009 Jan 21;(1):CD006320.  Update of: Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2007;(2):CD006320. PMID: 19160277   Full text
  • Interventions for treating lymphocytic colitis. Chande N, McDonald JW, Macdonald JK. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2008 Apr 16;(2):CD006096.  Update of: Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2007;(1):CD006096. PMID: 18425936  Full text
  • Interventions for treating collagenous colitis. Chande N, McDonald JW, Macdonald JK. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2008 Apr 16;(2):CD003575. Update of: Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2006;(4):CD003575. PMID: 18425892  Full text

 

Functional

 

  • Will the history and physical examination help establish that irritable bowel syndrome is causing this patient's lower gastrointestinal tract symptoms? Ford AC, Talley NJ, Veldhuyzen van Zanten SJ, Vakil NB, Simel DL, Moayyedi P. JAMA. 2008 Oct 15;300(15):1793-805.  PMID: 18854541
  • Efficacy and tolerability of alosetron for the treatment of irritable bowel syndrome in women and men: a meta-analysis of eight randomized, placebo-controlled, 12-week trials. Rahimi R, Nikfar S, Abdollahi M. Clin Ther. 2008 May;30(5):884-901. PMID: 18555935
  • Effects of 5-hydroxytryptamine (serotonin) type 3 antagonists on symptom relief and constipation in nonconstipated irritable bowel syndrome: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. Andresen V, Montori VM, Keller J, West CP, Layer P, Camilleri M. Clin Gastroenterol Hepatol. 2008 May;6(5):545-55. Epub 2008 Jan 31. PMID: 18242143
  • Effectiveness and safety of herbal medicines in the treatment of irritable bowel syndrome: a systematic review. Shi J, Tong Y, Shen JG, Li HX. World J Gastroenterol. 2008 Jan 21;14(3):454-62. PMID: 18200670
  • Hypnotherapy for treatment of irritable bowel syndrome. Webb AN, Kukuruzovic RH, Catto-Smith AG, Sawyer SM. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2007 Oct 17;(4):CD005110. PMID: 17943840   Full text

Go to the Contents page for this AEU

document.publisher: NHS Evidence - supportive and palliative care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,MOUTH CARE AND DYSPHAGIA,NUTRITION,GASTRO-INTESTINAL,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,COLON & RECTUM,SMALL INTESTINE,INFLAMMATORY BOWEL DISEASE,GASTROENTEROLOGY & LIVER DISEASES,COMMON CLINICAL PRESENTATIONS,CHRONIC PANCREATITIS,PANCREAS,FAECAL INCONTINENCE,DIARRHOEA,INFECTIONS,ENTERAL,PSEUDOMEMBRANOUS COLITIS,CROHN'S DISEASE,PANCREATITIS,RECENT ADDITIONS,CONSTIPATION AND OTHER BOWEL PROBLEMS,SEPTEMBER 2009,THERAPEUTIC NUTRITION]]>
document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update. 7 September 2009: Gastrointestinal symptoms in supportive and palliative care. Contents and introduction

Contents

 

  • Mouth care (focus on Mucositis)

  • Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) feeding

  • Diarrhoea

 

Introduction

This week we are pleased to present the second supportive and palliative care Annual Evidence Update on symptom management in gastroenterology. The latest high quality evidence is collected together on three topics which continue to pose challenges in symptom management. These areas are: Mouth care (focussing specifically on mucositis); Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) feeding; and Diarrhoea.

One of our original 'topics' was 'Mouth care', which would have included such diverse clinical situations as candidiasis to xerostomia (dry mouth). We have therefore focused this time on just one subject - mucositis - as this conceptually, and pathophysiologically, links in with another topic of this AEU, namely chemotherapy-related diarrhoea.  Other important  mouth care subjects will be reviewed in future AEUs.

Supportive and palliative care encompass much more than cancer and terminal illness - see definitions.

We therefore embrace the symptom management (both physical and psychological) aspects of many illnesses, especially chronic diseases.
However, even with acute illnesses there may be important lessons to be learnt about symptom management which may be transferable to other conditions.  Supportive care is especially concerned with the management of adverse effects of disease therapies. Thus, the reviews included encompass a range of medical and nursing topics which would not normally be found in a 'traditional palliative care' review, eg mucositis arising from chemotherapy for bone marrow transplantation; PEG feeding in MND/ALS; diarrhoea as an adverse effect of cancer chemotherapy or in association with infectious or inflammatory bowel disease.

This update collects together the best current knowledge on the supportive care management in these areas, concentrating on systematic reviews as well as high quality reviews and randomised controlled trials within the scope of supportive and palliative care.  We have also included some expert-led consensus statements and guidelines, as although they may not meet the definition of 'systematic review', they may be more immediately applicable
in a clinical situation and they do contain detailed references.

In general, we have focused on the literature in adult disease, because the issues with respect to childhood illnesses - especially for diarrhoea - are very different from adult supportive care.

The contents of this Annual Evidence Update should be browsed in conjunction with the often much more detailed literature on the underlying conditions which are found in the specialist collection for Gastroenterology and Liver Diseases.

 

  • Sam H Ahmedzai
  • Ruth Broadhurst
  • Richard Stevens
  • Denise Brady
  • Melanie Hodson


 

]]>

document.publisher: National Library for Health: Supportive and Palliative Care Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,FAMILIES & CARERS,SERVICE PROVISION,COMMUNICATION ISSUES,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-1Annual Evidence Update: 19 January 2009. Patient and carer involvement in chronic disease. Systematic reviews

Back to the CONTENTS PAGE

 

 

Methods and search strategy

 

The following search strategy was used to retrieve references to systematic reviews on 'patient and carer involvement in chronic disease' from the Pubmed database. 

 

"patient participation"[MeSH Terms]

OR

"participation" OR "self-manag*" OR "self manag*" OR "involvement"

 

AND

((chronic OR long-term OR persistent OR "long term")

 

Limits:

Publication Date from 2000 to 2009, Humans, English, Meta analysis or review

 

AND

 

"systematic" or "meta analysis" or "meta-analysis"

 

311 records were found. Pubmed defined 292 of these as ‘reviews’. These 292 were saved as 'abstract plus' format, put into a word file, formatted to minimize the number of pages, and page numbering added. The citations were carefully analysed to determine whether a record was likely to be (a) a true systematic review or meta-analysis, and (b) of relevant subject matter. Due to the nature of the topic, the relevance of each record was not always clear. However, where there appeared to be potentially-relevant material in a review, on balance we chose to include rather than exclude it. Full text versions of the papers were not acquired or analysed.

 

32 records were included in the final Annual Evidence Update:

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Assisted Dying for the Terminally Ill Bill - First Report
document.publisher: House of Lords
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,ETHICS & LAW,EUTHANASIA]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ The Assisted Dying for the Terminally Ill Bill seeks to legalise, for people who are terminally ill, who are mentally competent and who are suffering unbearably, medical assistance with suicide or, in cases where the person concerned would be physically incapable of taking the final action to end his or her life, voluntary euthanasia. The authors have examined both the principles underlying the Bill and its practical implications if it were to become law. The authors have also looked at the experience of other countries which have enacted legislation of this nature, and have in addition made some analysis of public opinion in Britain on the subject.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Bereavement care interventions: a systematic review
document.publisher: Biomedcentral
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,DEATH,BEREAVEMENT]]>
document.body:
The authors conducted a systematic review using the terms (bereaved or bereavement) and (grief) combined with (intervention or support or counselling or therapy) and (controlled or trial or design) and also searched citations in published reports for additional pertinent studies. Eligible studies had to evaluate whether the treatment of bereaved individuals reduced bereavement-related symptoms.

74 eligible studies evaluated diverse treatments designed to ameliorate a variety of outcomes associated with bereavement. Other than efficacy for pharmacological treatment of bereavement-related depression, the authors could identify no consistent pattern of treatment benefit among the other forms of interventions.

Due to a paucity of reports on controlled clinical trails, the authors say no rigorous evidence-based recommendation regarding the treatment of bereaved persons is currently possible except for the pharmacologic treatment of depression.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: BPS 2007 conference highlight. Dr John Williams. Post-surgical pain in breast cancer.
document.publisher: British Pain Society
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,CANCER,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-1BPS 2007 conference highlight. Dr John Williams. Post-surgical pain in breast cancer.

Introduction and terminology

Chronic pain after breast surgery (CPBS) is a major public health problem. It is a common and debilitating problem affecting as many as 30% of patients after breast surgery.

It is primarily a neuropathic pain syndrome with additional musculoskeletal, physical and emotional components. Its treatment involves a combined approach of neuropathic drugs, physical and psychological therapies and preventative strategies. It is important for patients and health care professionals to recognize the prevalence of the condition, and to be aware of possible risk factors prior to surgery.

CPBS is the term used to describe a number of different chronic pain conditions. This diagnosis should only be used after excluding all other discrete diagnoses such as recurrent disease or radiation-induced neuropathy.

Sometimes the term CPBS is only used to indicate neuropathic pain problems after surgery. CPBS was originally referred to as ‘post-mastectomy pain syndrome’. However CPBS has been reported after the new minimally invasive surgical techniques, and therefore the old terminology is inaccurate. In this article I use the term CPBS, but other possible terms include:

  • chronic pain after breast cancer treatment (possibly the most accurate term as it recognises the influence of non surgical factors in the aetiology of the pain)
  • chronic pain in breast cancer survivors (popular terminology in USA)

Alternatively the term should not be used at all, and only the specific more accurate diagnosis of the pain should be used.

 

Characteristics of the pain

CPBS is characterised by persistent pain in the lateral chest wall and along the medial aspect of the upper arm of the affected side.

The pain is neuropathic in nature, with burning and dysaesthetic components, and with lancinating pain often superimposed over a dull aching pain. Secondary musculoskeletal pain may also exist and contribute to a worsening cycle of pain. Often the pain is made worse by physical activity and may become more severe as the day progresses.

 

Prevalence

From 1979 to the present day numerous epidemiological studies have consistently demonstrated the prevalence of this condition. Typically it affects approximately up to 30% of women at one year following breast surgery.

 

Diagnosis of CPBS

The diagnosis of CPBS should only be made after other possible causes of pain have been excluded. In particular it is important to exclude recurrent breast cancer.  CPBS is a difficult diagnosis to make as there are numerous other potential causes of pain after breast surgery.

A recent publication (Jung et al, 2003) described 4 different neuropathic pain problems following breast surgery:

  1. Intercostobrachial neuralgia – due to damage to or stretching of the nerve
  2. Phantom breast pain
  3. Neuroma – either macro (palpable) or micro neuromata
  4. Other nerve injury pain


Natural History

The natural history of chronic pain after breast surgery is difficult to define.  One large follow up study (Macdonald, 2005) showed a prevalence of chronic pain of 43% @ 3 years post surgery and that just over half of these patients had persistent pain at 9 years following surgery.  Ivens (1992) indicated some reduction over time.

Kroner et al (1992) evaluated patients with phantom breast sensations at 3 weeks following surgery and again at 6 years and showed a much reduced incidence at the 6 year point.

Specific risk factors for development of chronic pain after breast surgery

Many studies have assessed the impact of specific risk factors in the development of chronic pain.  The main risk factors seem to be poorly controlled acute pain, chemotherapy and preoperative stress.

 

Treatment

CPBS should be regarded as a form of neuropathic pain.  Treatment should consist of anti-neuropathic drugs in conjunction with psychological and physical therapies.

My usual first-line drugs include amitriptyline, gabapentin, tramadol, opioids and 5% lidoderm patch. A number of studies have specifically investigated different treatments for CPBS.

 

Conclusions

  1. There is a high incidence of chronic pain after breast surgery. Cancer survivor population is increasing.
  2. CPBS is a neuropathic pain problem, with associated musculoskeletal, physical and emotional components. Treatment is multidisciplinary and involves using anti-neuropathic drugs.
  3. CPBS is a model for acute to chronic pain transition. Preventative strategies include multimodal analgesics, local anaesthetics and aggressive acute pain management.

 

References

Abdullah TI, Iddon J, Barr L, Baildam AD, Bundred NJ. Prospective randomized controlled trial of preservation of the intercostobrachial nerve during axillary node clearance for breast cancer. Br J Surg 1998;85;1443-5. Link to PubMed abstract

Link to PubMed abstract

document.title: BPS 2007 conference highlight. Dr Paul Farquhar-Smith. Chemotherapy-induced neuropathic pain
document.publisher: British Pain Society
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT,CHEMOTHERAPY]]>
document.body:
111-1BPS 2007 conference highlight. Dr Paul Farquhar-Smith. Chemotherapy-induced neuropathic pain

 

  • Chemotherapy-induced neuropathic pain occurs commonly and is under-recognised and under-treated. 

 

  • It can compromise anti-cancer treatment and adversely affects quality of life and activities of daily living. 

 

  • Improvement of assessment and further research into treatment will help patients with this difficult pain.

 

References

document.title: BPS 2007 conference highlight: Dr Bill Macrae. Pain in cancer survivors following radiotherapy
document.publisher: British Pain Society
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT,RADIOTHERAPY]]>
document.body:
111-1BPS 2007 conference highlight: Dr Bill Macrae. Pain in cancer survivors following radiotherapy

 

  • Radiotherapy is undoubtedly beneficial in treating patients with breast cancer.  However there are both short term and long term side effects. 

 

  • Chronic pain is common after treatment for breast cancer: surgery, chemotherapy and radiotherapy can all contribute. 

 

  • The effects of radiotherapy can take many years to develop.  Modern methods of treatment have reduced the risk of problems significantly.
     

References

Bajrovic A, Rades D, Fehlauer F, Tribius S, Hoeller U, Rudat V, Jung H, Alberti W. Is there a life-long risk of brachial plexopathy after radiotherapy of supraclavicular lymph nodes in breast cancer patients? Radiotherapy & Oncology 2004; Vol 71: 297-301. Link to PubMed abstract

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: BPS 2007 conference highlight: Professor Henry McQuay. What have systematic reviews told us about managing pain?
document.publisher: British Pain Society
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-1BPS 2007 conference highlight: Professor Henry McQuay. What have systematic reviews told us about managing pain?

Systematic reviews can provide more or less robust information about the performance, the efficacy and the safety, of our pain interventions. They can only do that for efficacy when proper trials of adequate size, quality and validity have been done. To the extent that our management of pain is guided by evidence, then yes, systematic reviews do tell us things about managing pain.

 

The guidance they give us, however, is a bit like public health advice - it is about ‘average’ efficacy and safety. The individual clinician and patient have to determine whether or not the patient is a responder to the intervention. The systematic reviews may guide the prescriber to the ‘best’ intervention faster than would have happened before we had such reviews, but the reviews and their products are tools not rules, a help to the clinician rather than mandating treatment.

 

The lecture covered the strengths and weaknesses of the systematic review approach, including the creation of treatment algorithms from the products of the reviews, and a little bit more about defining and identifying responders.

 

Source: See page 17 of the British Pain Society's 2007 Annual Scientific Meeting registration programme - available to download as a pdf here.

 

References

Derry CJ, Derry S, McQuay HJ, Moore RA. Systematic review of systematic reviews of acupuncture published 1996-2005. Clin Med 2006 Jul-Aug;6(4):381-6. Link to PubMed abstract 

Kalso E, Edwards JE, Moore RA, McQuay HJ. Opioids in chronic non-cancer pain: systematic review of efficacy and safety. Pain 2004 Dec;112(3):372-80. Link to PubMed abstract

McQuay H, Moore A. Utility of clinical trial results for clinical practice. Eur J Pain 2007 Feb;11(2):123-4. Link to PubMed [no abstract]

Moore A, McQuay H.  Bandolier’s little book of making sense of the medical evidence.  Oxford: Oxford University Press. 2006. ISBN: 0198566042.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: BPS 2007 conference highlight: Professor Jürgen Sandkühler. The cellular mechanisms of pain memory
document.publisher: British Pain Society
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-1BPS 2007 conference highlight: Professor Jürgen Sandkühler. The cellular mechanisms of pain memory

Neuropathic and inflammatory pain may be amplified by spinal mechanisms which are triggered by impulses in nociceptive nerve fibres. A potential cellular model for afferent-induced hyperalgesia is the longterm potentiation of synaptic strength (LTP) between primary afferent C-fibres and these lamina I neurons. However, inflammation induces low level activity in primary afferents which typically induces long-lasting depressions rather than LTP. We have now identified a novel form of synaptic LTP at synapses between C-fibres and a group of spinal lamina I neurons. This form of LTP is induced by formalin or capsaicin-injections into a hind-paw or 2 Hz electrical stimulation of the sciatic nerve at C-fibre intensity. Pharmacological profile and signal-transduction pathways of this form of synaptic plasticity and inflammatory pain largely overlap, rendering a LTP a potential synaptic mechanism of pain amplification.

 

Source: See page 10 of the British Pain Society's 2007 Annual Scientific Meeting registration programme - available to download as a pdf here.

 

References

Synaptic plasticity in spinal lamina I projection neurons that mediate hyperalgesia. Ikeda H, Heinke B, Ruscheweyh R, Sandkuhler J. Science. 2003 Feb 21;299(5610):1237-40. Link to PubMed abstract

Synaptic amplifier of inflammatory pain in the spinal dorsal horn. Ikeda H, Stark J, Fischer H, Wagner M, Drdla R, Jager T, Sandkuhler J. Science. 2006 Jun 16;312(5780):1659-62. Link to PubMed abstract

Corelease of two fast neurotransmitters at a central synapse. Jonas P, Bischofberger J, Sandkuhler J. Science. 1998 Jul 17;281(5375):419-24. Link to PubMed Abstract

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: BPS 2007 conference highlight: Professor Mike Salter. Microglia and pain
document.publisher: British Pain Society
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-1BPS 2007 conference highlight: Professor Mike Salter. Microglia and pain

Glial cells were historically considered to serve primarily housekeeping roles in the nervous system. However, this view has changed radically in the last half decade, in particular for the role of microglia in pain resulting from peripheral nerve injury. In the healthy central nervous system microglia are not dormant, as once thought, but act as sentries that react rapidly to various stimuli that threaten physiological homeostasis. A growing body of evidence indicates that microglia in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord play a causal role in neuropathic pain behaviours resulting from peripheral nerve injury and specific neuron-microglia-neuron signalling has been discovered. Thus, suppressing this signalling may represent the basis for new forms of therapy for chronic pain following nerve injury.

 

Source: See page 11 of the British Pain Society's 2007 Annual Scientific Meeting registration programme - available to download as a pdf here.

 

References

Tsuda M, Shigemoto-Mogami Y, Koizumi S, Mizokoshi A et al.  P2X4 receptors induced in spinal microglia gate tactile allodynia after nerve injury.  Nature 2003; 424: 778-783. Link to PubMed abstract

Ikeda H, Tsuda M, Inoue K, Murase K.  Long-term potentiation of neuronal excitation by neuron-glia interactions in the rat spinal dorsal horn.  Eur K Neuroscience 2007; 25: 1297-1306. Link to PubMed abstract

Coull JAM, Beggs S, Boudreau D, Boivin D et al.  BDNF from microglia causes the shift in neuronal anion gradient underlying Neuropathic pain.  Nature 2005; 438: 1017-1021. Link to PubMed abstract

Tsuda M, Inoue K, Salter MW. Neuropathic pain and spinal microglia: a big problem from molecules in ‘small glia’.  Trends in Neuroscience 2005; 28: 101-107. Link to PubMed abstract

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: British Pain Society Cancer Pain Committee
document.publisher: British Pain Society
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,CANCER,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,POLICY,PAIN MANAGEMENT,UNITED KINGDOM]]>
document.body:
111-1British Pain Society Cancer Pain Committee

Dr Jon Raphael (chair)
Dr Joan Hester (BPS)
Prof Sam Ahmedzai (APM)
Dr Martin Johnson (RCGP)
Ms Janette Barrie ( Nursing)
Dr John Williams (Pain Management)
Prof Marie Fallon (Palliative Medicine)
Dr Paul Farqhuar-Smith (Pain Management)
Dr Rebecca Haines (Psychology)
Ms Heather Wallace (Patient representative)
 
Assistance from:
Mr Brian Simpson (Neurosurgery)
Dr Peter Hoskins ( Bone oncology)
 

There are several documents/guidelines on cancer pain management; however, these do not help address the place of specialist pain services adequately. It is known that collaboration between palliative care and pain specialist clinics is limited and as a result access to such specialist services is poor.

 

This led to a plan to prepare a document on behalf of the British Pain Society (BPS) in consultation with the Association of Palliative Medicine (APM) and the Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP). The document has the aim of producing guidelines on the place of such specialist pain services to aid clinicians in palliative care, pain management, oncology and general practice. It also aims to promote better collaboration between palliative and pain specialists in the treatment of cancer pain to raise standards of practice.

 

So as not to reproduce previous guidelines, this document aims specifically to outline areas of practice where pain specialists could be useful in treating patients with cancer pain. Examples of this would include interventions in cancer pain syndromes, acute postoperative pain management in cancer patients, breakthrough  pain, non-cancer pain management in patients with cancer and pain management in those dependent on opioids to name a few.  The document will also comment upon education and provision of pain specialist services for cancer pain management. 

 

Return to the National Knowledge Week homepage

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Chronic heart failure - systematic reviews in 2007
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION]]>
document.body:
111-1Chronic heart failure - systematic reviews in 2007

Over the last year some key systematic reviews have been published in the field of supportive care in chronic heart failure.  In this evidence update we have included the major systematic reviews, especially those with a meta-analysis covering a range of topics. These have included several reviews from the Cochrane Library. There were several Cochrane Reviews on anthracyclines and how to minimise their effect on cardiac function, thereby decreasing the risk of causing CCF. A key conclusion from this is to give the infusion over at least 6 hours to decrease the peak plasma anthracycline concentration.

 

There are also several systematic reviews looking at the pharmacological management of heart failure. These confirmed that in heart failure angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors are beneficial and that beta-blockers decrease the risk of developing atrial fibrillation. A systematic review of antidiabetic agents in patients with diabetes and heart failure showed metformin to be the safest and most beneficial drug.

 

A Cochrane Review confirmed that oral anticoagulation decreased mortality in certain groups of patients with heart failure (e.g. atrial fibrillation), but we need to await the results of further studies to see if this is generalisable to heart failure patients who are in sinus rhythm. Another suggests that digitalis is beneficial in patients who have chronic heart failure without atrial fibrillation.

 

The benefits of cardiac resynchronization therapy and left ventricular assist devices have also been systematically reviewed.

 

Other systematic reviews have compared the relationship between diseases, such that worsening renal function leads to a worse prognosis from heart failure, and that heart failure has a negative effect on cognitive function as well as causing an increased risk of strokes.

 

 

The full list of 25 reviews is below:

 

List of reviews

 

[Note: Mainly systematic reviews, but the list also includes a few good quality non-systematic reviews]
