document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Conference highlights: British Pain Society, Annual Scientific Meeting, Liverpool 2008
document.publisher: National Library for Health: Supportive and Pallliative Care Specialist Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-1Conference highlights: British Pain Society, Annual Scientific Meeting, Liverpool 2008

Professor Anthony Dickenson. Plenary session.

Top-down processing of pain - pain, the brain and spinal gains

Pain arises from peripheral and central processes. There is clear evidence from both preclinical and clinical studies that both peripheral and central hyper excitability play important roles in determining the level of pain perceived. Rightly, much emphasis has been put on spinal cord mechanisms in central excitability such as wind-up and long-term potentiation but it is also clear that spinal excitability can be regulated by descending pathways from the brain.

These originate from predominantly monoamine systems which are additionally implicated in control of emotions, fear, anxiety, thermo-regulation and the sleep cycle and so may mediate these pain induced co-lmorbidities and provide a neuronal link between affective statesand the level of pain. Furthermore, they are likely targets for antidepressants used in pain states.

Much of the early work in this area concentrated on descending inhibitions, now known to be predominanty noradrenergic , and failure of descending inhibitions has been reported in patients. However, pain could equally be increased by enhanced descending facilitations and data is accumulating in animal models of neuropathy and bone cancer on exactly this. Spinal neurones project through the parabrachial/cuneiform area, an area activated in humans in hyperalgesic states, to the amyglada and hypothalamus where they engage systems related to the affective, autonomic and aversive aspects of pain. The pathways relay on 5HT positive and other neurones in the brainstem rostroventromedial medulla (RVM). 

The final arm is descending serotoninergic facilitory pathway returning back to the spinal cord and then terminating on excitatory 5HT3 receptors in the spinal cord. Interestingly, these 5HT facilitations are not required for either wind-up or long-term potantiation, reinforcing the idea that these are intrinsic spinal events but act alongside them. Interestingly this receptor is the only ion channel out of the >20 receptors for these monoamines.

Finally, bsed on the changes in these controls after nerve injury and the ability of gabapentin and pregabalin to modulate neuropthic pain, we have shown that the RVM and this 5HT3 mediated descending pathway plays a major role in the state-dpendent actions of this class of drug.

These excitatory influences are likely to contribute to the development and maintenance of altered excitability in the spinal cord, and furthermore, form a link between emotional states and levels of pain and when dysfunctional, could contribute to many pains including those where there are mood and sleep disturbances such as fibromyalgia.

 

Professor Jeffrey S. Mogil

Plenary session. Nature and nurture of chronic pain

Painnoted is asscoaiated with interindividual variability, including in the propensity to develop chronically painful pathologies after injury or infection.Genetic linkage mapping efforts in mice and targeted genetic association studies in humans are beginning to identify thosde genes underlying much of the variability in these traits. In our laboratory, we have recently uncovered a number of genes associated with thermal and inflammatory nociception. These efforts may lead to novel clinical treatments for pain and/or facilitate the patient-centered, individualized treatment of pain using current pharmaceuticals. In addition, we are now paying greater attention to the identification of environmental factors that affect pain behaviour in the mouse. We have very recently observed modulation of pain in the mouse by purely social factors. These data can be interpreted as providing evidence for the existence of empathy for pain in this sub primate species.

 

Professor Ralf Baron

Plenary session. Neuropathic Pain

Neuropathic pain syndromes, i.e., pain afte a lesion or disease of the peripheral or central nervous system, are clinically characterized by spontaneous pain (ongoing, paroxyms) and evoked pains (hyperalgesia, allodynia). A variety of distinct pathophysiological mechanisms in the peripheral and central nervous system operate in concert: In some patients the nerve lesion triggers molecular changes in nociceptive neurons that become abnormally sensitive and develop pathological spontaneous activity (up-regulation of sodium channels and receptors, e.g., vanilloid TRPV1-, menthol-sensitive TRPM8- or a-receptors. These phenomena may lead to spontaneous pain, shooting pain sensations as well as heat hyperalgesia, cold hyperalgesia and sympathetically maintained pain. Spontaneous activity in damaged non-nociceptive A-fibers may lead to paresthesias. All these changes may also occur in uninjured neurons driven by substances released by adjacent dying cells. The hyperactivity in nociceptors in turn induces secondary changes (hyperexcitability) in processing neurons in the spinal cord and brain. This central sensitization causes input from mechanoreceptive A-fibers to be preceived as pain (mechanical allodynia). Neuroplastic changes in the central descending pain modulating systems (inhibitory or facilitatory) may lead to further hyperexcitability. Other patients have severe spontaneous pain in combination with profound sensory loss but no hyperalgesia or allodynia. The pain is due to spontaneous activity in deafferented central neurons. The medical management of neuropathic pain consists of five main classes of oral medication (antidepressants, (reuptake blockers), anticonvulsants, with Na-blocking action, anticonvulsants with Ca-modulating actions, tramadol and opioids) and several categories of topical medications for patients with cutaneous allodynia and hyperalgesia (capsaicin and local anaesthetics). In many cases an early combination of compunds effecting different mechanisms is useful. At present existing trials only provide general pain relief values for specific aetiologies, which in part may explain the failure to obtain complete pain relief in neuropathic pain conditions. In general, the treatment of neuropathic pain is still unsatisfactory. Therefore, a new hypothetical concept was proposed in which pain is analyzed on the basis of underlying mechanisms. The increased knowledge of pain-generating mechanisms and their translation into symptoms and signs may in the future allow a dissection of the mechanisms that operate in each pateint. If a systematic clinical examination of the neuropathic pain patient and a precise phenotypic characterization is combined with a selection of drugs acting at those particular mechanisms, it should ultimately be possible to design optimal treatments for the individual patient.

 

Katie Urch,  Sam H Ahmedzai, W. Paul Farquhar-Smith

Workshop: Treating cancer pain - time for a new direction?

  • 22 years of the WHO analgesic ladder: reaching maturity or senility. Prof Sam H Ahmedzai
  • Developments in the science of cancer pain. Dr Katie Urch
  • Management of the WHO ladder 'failures' - interventional treatment of cancer pain. Dr W. Paul Farquhar-Smith

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Conference highlights: Palliative Care Congress, Glasgow, 2008
document.publisher: National Library for Health: Supportive and Pallliative Care Specialist Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-1Conference highlights: Palliative Care Congress, Glasgow, 2008

See the full programme here

 

Tuesday 29th April
 
Time: 1115. Concurrent Symposium. Pain

John Welsh - Breakthrough pain - time for a rethink?

John Currie - Pain control 

Abstract:

Most pain related to cancer can usually be well controlled with opiates as the final stage of the analgesic ladder. The palliative team really comes into its own when these standard techniques fail and “the drugs don’t work.” The pain may be mediated by different pathways particularly if the pain becomes neuropathic. The main pathway in this process is the N-methyl D-aspartate (NMDA) system. Specific agents are now available to control this type of pain. These drugs are usually combined with the opiate and the doses can be adjusted for optimal pain control and minimum side effects. Some pains require more invasive techniques and this can be co-ordinated by the palliative team. In this way, pain control can be tailored to each particular patient. Regular assessment by the team will also allow forward planning to keep ahead of any exacerbations of pain as the disease progresses.
 

Time: 1630. Concurrent Abstracts. Free Papers 5 - Pain

Dying without pain: evaluating the impact of nurses prescribing morphine in Uganda - Barbara Jack

Pain and pain management in older people with cancer - Mike Bennett

Israel seven years of opioid consumption trends for chronic pain treatment (2000-2006) - Pesach Shvartzman

 

 
Wed 30th April

Time: 0800. Masterclass. Opioids for pain control – exploring the molecular basis of their powers

Elaine Cachia

George Stefano


This Masterclass session will enable one of the leading researchers globally in the molecular biology of opioids, George Stefano, to share his deep insights into the world of opioids and their cellular actions. The session will start with a clinical case presentation by Elaine Cachia, specialist registrar in palliative medicine. She will introduce a case of a lady with sickle cell disease whose recurrent admissions for acute painful crisis led to escalating doses of morphine, fentanyl and other analgesic drugs. As she was spending more and more time in hospital, it emerged that fewer and fewer of her pains could be explained by sickle cell crises. Rather, there was evidence of opioid tolerance, opioid-induced hyperalgesia and spontaneous pain. The situation was brought under control by a regime of ketamine and methadone. Prof Stefano will discuss the actions of opioids from the perspective of his world-class laboratory studies which have clarified their powerful beneficial actions as well as their major adverse effects. Understanding the role of opioids in pain signalling as well as their multiple other biological effects in the body can help us to appreciate the role they should play, alongside other pain targeting mechanisms, in modern pain management.

 

Time: 0850. Concurrent Workshop. Pain in Children - what is the difference?

Richard Hain

Abstract

The session is an overview of how children in pain differ from adults. It is intended for an audience more used to dealing with adults but who find themselves sometimes having to advise on or to care for children. It will cover physiology, diagnosis, assessment and management of pain in children, briefly outlining some of the myths surrounding the subject and some of the techniques that have now developed in the evolving specialty of paediatric palliative medicine.

 

 

Time: 1020. Plenary. Lab to Bedside II. Opioids - ancient mechanisms and modern implications for symptom management

George Stefano

Abstract

An evidence-based model of cellular morphine expression and function, including novel µ3 opiate receptor subtype coupling to nitric oxide (NO) production, demonstrates the presence of morphinergic signaling in animal cells. Similar morphinergic processes are found in human and invertebrate tissues, demonstrating conservation during evolution. Furthermore, the µ3 opiate receptor/ NO coupled regulatory pathway exists and is functionally competent in human multi-lineage progenitor cells (MLPC) prepared from umbilical cord blood. Real-time PCR analysis of extracted RNA from undifferentiated human MLPC indicated selective expression of a µ3-like opiate receptor-encoding RNA, in the absence of traditional µ1 material. Complementary microarray analysis of extracted RNA indicated that traditional mu, delta, and kappa opioid receptor gene expression is not detected in both undifferentiated and differentiated MPLC. The data provide compelling evidence in support of both the evolutionary primacy and primordial regulatory role of morphine/µ3 opiate receptor/NO in embryogenesis.

 

Jason Boland

Abstract

This paper addresses the clinical features and research on opioid-induced bowel dysfunction (OBD), starting with the epidemiology and symptoms. The current clinical evidence for the inherent constipating effects of different opioids using data from clinical trials show that of all the currently available drugs, fentanyl is associated with the least constipation and also nausea. The poor evidence base for oral laxatives and rectal preparations reveals that these are at best palliative, ie they may increase bowel movements but do not treat the underlying physiological changes. There is now emerging evidence on the latest approach, namely the use of peripherally acting opioid antagonists which attempt to reverse the pathophysiology caused by therapeutic opioids. While early attempts with oral normal release naloxone gave mixed results, modified release naloxone and the new generation of peripherally acting mu-opioid antagonists including alvimopan and methylnaltrexone shows greater promise.

 

Time: 1750. Symposium. Cancer pain management – update for 2008

Jon Raphael

Sam Ahmedzai

Abstract

Cancer pain management has made significant strides in the past 20 years since the introduction of the WHO analgesic approach, based on the 3-step ladder. However, cancer pain is still very prevalent and some surveys have shown a worsening, not improving situation even in the UK. Clearly guidelines have to reviewed in the light of advancing science and improvements in treatments available. The British Pain Society has started a review of cancer pain management in conjunction with the Association for Palliative Medicine. The aim is to produce a joint document with a fresh look at this age-old problem. It will include state of the art reviews on pain assessment, cancer pain mechanisms, the role of cancer-directed treatments and palliative treatments and the multidisciplinary approach to treating cancer pain at all stages of the disease. In this session, Jon Raphael who chairs the BPS working group producing the document and Sam Ahmedzai who leads from the APM side, will present the current work. We hope to engage congress participants in discussion about the document and how it could be incorporated into everyday pain and palliative care practice.

 

Thursday 1st May

Time: 1130. Concurrent Symposium. Advances in anti-cancer treatment: taking the rough with the smooth

Noelle O’Rourke

Abstract

Advances in anti-cancer therapy: taking the rough with the smooth
The past decade has seen incremental improvements in cancer survival across a range of tumour types.  More than half of all cancer patients can now achieve long term cure of their disease and the plethora of new treatment options in development promises further improvements.  This presentation is in two parts.

The first section will give a brief overview of major advances in anti-cancer therapy.  This includes the evolving technology in radiation treatment enabling image-guided radiotherapy (IGRT), intensity modulated treatment (IMRT), new techniques in brachytherapy (short range radiation) and the wider use of 3D stereotactic techniques.  Research in radiobiology and cancer biology has led to innovative scheduling of radiation and chemotherapy with increasing use of concurrent chemoradiation for a number of tumours. Advances in imaging with wider access to PET scanners have improved initial staging and later assessment of tumours on treatment.  Interventional radiology offers options for stenting and for radiofrequency ablation of tumours, which can both contribute to improved cancer control even in late stage disease.  Novel compounds in development in oncology focus on three major areas: angiogenesis inhibitors, signal transduction inhibitors and cell cycle kinase inhibitors.  In all the emphasis is increasingly on targeted therapy with favourable toxicity profiles, often orally available and individualized on the basis of a specific patient’s tumour biology.

The second section of this presentation is a personal reflection on the objectives of cancer treatment.  It will focus on how we measure treatment outcome and how we weigh up the factors of efficacy and toxicity.  It will examine the need to individualize therapy based on patient preference and how this can be achieved.


 

See the full programme here

 

 

]]>

document.title: COPD - systematic reviews in 2006-07
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ RESPIRATORY,STAFF USE,CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,RESPIRATORY DISEASES,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION,CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD),KNOWLEDGE UPDATES]]>
document.body:
111-1COPD - systematic reviews in 2006-07

Over the last 12 months there has been several important systematic reviews published relating to supportive and palliative care in chronic respiratory disease. The scale of the problem is emphasised by a recent systematic review with a meta-analysis showing the global prevalence of COPD to be 7.6% (this percentage was even higher when diagnosis is based on spirometry).

 

In a review of scales to measure breathlessness the Numeric Rating Scale, Chronic Respiratory Questionnaire dyspnoea subscale, Cancer Dyspnoea Scale and modified Borg seemed most suitable for use in palliative care, although further studies are needed.

 

There were several reviews on the management of chronic respiratory disease, including evidence that pulmonary rehabilitation is beneficial for patients with chronic lung diseases. A Cochrane database review showed the benefit (including reduced mortality) of using antibiotics in patients having COPD exacerbations with purulent sputum. There was a Cochrane review of Cochrane systematic reviews assessing the role of systemic corticosteroids in COPD, assessing the risk/benefit ratio in different situations, it concluded that in acute exacerbations, systemic corticosteroids are beneficial, but the optimum dose, route and duration need further studies.

 

For inhaled corticosteroids the benefit outweighed the risk in the treatment of patients with moderate to severe COPD. Anticholinergics, such as Tiotropium, reduced COPD exacerbations and improved quality of life and symptoms. A review of Heliox in COPD patients receiving non-invasive ventilation showed no change in arterial carbon dioxide or respiratory rate. A systematic review with meta-analysis evaluating the long-term effect of beta2-agonists in COPD showed that they increased respiratory deaths. This is thought to be due to the tolerance that develops to their bronchodilator and bronchoprotective effects. 

 

The full list of 20 review articles is below:

 

 

List of reviews 

 

[Note: Mainly systematic reviews, but the list also includes a few good quality non-systematic reviews]

 

Adams SG, Smith PK, Allan PF, Anzueto A, Pugh JA, Cornell JE. Systematic review of the chronic care model in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease prevention and management. Archives of Internal Medicine.  167(6):551-61, 2007 Mar 26.

 

Arandjus C,  Black PN,  Poole PJ, Wood Baker R, Steurer-Stey C.   Oral bacterial vaccines for the prevention of acute exacerbations in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and chronic bronchitis. Respiratory Medicine.  100(10):1671-81, 2006 Oct.

 

Azarpazhooh A,  Leake JL, Systematic review of the association between respiratory diseases and oral health. Journal of Periodontology.  77(9):1465-82, 2006 Sep.

 

Balser E,  Neher JO,  Safranek S, Taraday J. Clinical inquiries: When are antibiotics indicated for acute COPD exacerbations? Journal of Family Practice.  55(12):1079-80, 2006 Dec.

 

Barr RG, Bourbeau J, Camargo CA,  Ram FS. Tiotropium for stable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease: A meta-analysis. Thorax.  61(10):854-62, 2006 Oct.

 

Bausewein C,  Farquhar M,  Booth S, Gysels M,  Higginson IJ. Measurement of breathlessness in advanced disease: a systematic review. Respiratory Medicine.  101(3):399-410, 2007 Mar.

 

Colebourn CL,  Barber V,  Young JD. Use of helium-oxygen mixture in adult patients presenting with exacerbations of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease: a systematic review. Anaesthesia.  62(1):34-42, 2007 Jan.

 

Dorman S,  Byrne A,  Edwards A. Which measurement scales should we use to measure breathlessness in palliative care? A systematic review. Palliative Medicine 2007;21(3):177-91.

 

Gartlehner G,  Hansen RA,  Carson SS,  Lohr KN. Efficacy and safety of inhaled corticosteroids in patients with COPD: a systematic review and meta-analysis of health outcomes. Comment in: J Fam Pract. 2006 Sep;55(9):756; PMID: 17009435 Annals of Family Medicine.  4(3):253-62, 2006 May-Jun.

 

Guo R,  Pittler MH,  Ernst E. Herbal medicines for the treatment of COPD: a systematic review. European Respiratory Journal.  28(2):330-8, 2006 Aug.

 

Halbert RJ,  Natoli JL,  Gano A,  Badamgarav E,  Buist AS.  Mannino DM. Global burden of COPD: systematic review and meta-analysis. European Respiratory Journal.  28(3):523-32, 2006 Sep.

 

Peters J,  Pickvance S,  Wilford J,  MacDonald E,  Blank L. Predictors of Delayed Return to Work or Job Loss with Respiratory Ill-Health: A Systematic Review. Journal of Occupational Rehabilitation 2007 Jun;17(2):317-26.  

 

Puhan MA, Vollenweider D, Latshang T, Steurer J, Steurer-Stey C. Exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease: when are antibiotics indicated? A systematic review. Respiratory Research.  8:30, 2007.

 

Ram FS. Use of theophylline in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease: examining the evidence. Current Opinion in Pulmonary Medicine.  12(2):132-9, 2006 Mar.

 

Ram FS, Rodriguez-Roisin R,  Granados-Navarrete A,  Garcia-Aymerich J,  Barnes NC, Antibiotics for exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews.  (2):CD004403, 2006.

 

Ries AL,  Bauldoff GS,  Carlin BW,  Casaburi R,  Emery CF, Mahler DA,  Make B,  Rochester CL,  Zuwallack R,  Herrerias C. Pulmonary Rehabilitation: Joint ACCP/AACVPR Evidence-Based Clinical Practice Guidelines. Chest 2007 May;131(5 Suppl):4S-42S.

 

Salpeter SR,  Buckley NS. Systematic review of clinical outcomes in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease: beta-agonist use compared with anticholinergics and inhaled corticosteroids. Clinical Reviews in Allergy & Immunology.  31(2-3):219-30, 2006 Oct-Dec.

 

Taylor NF,  Dodd KJ,  Shields N,  Bruder A. Therapeutic exercise in physiotherapy practice is beneficial: a summary of systematic reviews 2002-2005. Australian Journal of Physiotherapy.  53(1):7-16, 2007.

 

Wagner PD. Skeletal muscles in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease: deconditioning, or myopathy? Respirology.  11(6):681-6, 2006 Nov.

 

Wood-Baker R, Walters J. Walters EH. Systemic corticosteroids in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease: an overview of Cochrane systematic reviews. Respiratory Medicine. 101(3):371-7, 2007 Mar.

 

Back to the National Knowledge Week contents page

document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES,ALZHEIMER’S DISEASE]]>
document.body:
111-1Dementia: Some background reading

Written by Sharon Scott, Palliative Care Nurse Specialist Dementia Project, at St Christopher’s Hospice Sydenham, London.

 

Below is some suggested background reading on palliative care and dementia. This is a personal selection which complements the comphrehensive material on dementia in the NLH Later Life Specialist Library.

 

Documents from the National Council for Palliative Care


National Council for Palliative Care
Exploring palliative care for people with dementia. A discussion document. London: NCPC, 2006.

 

Blight A, Sutton L.
Progress with dementia. Moving forward. Addressing palliative care for people with dementia. London: NCPC, 2007.

 

http://www.ncpc.org.uk/palliative_care.html

 

Systematic review on pain in dementia

Zwakhalen SMG, Hamers JPH, Abu-Saad HH, Berger MPF.
Pain in elderly people with severe dementia: a systematic review of behavioural pain assessment tools
BMC Geriatrics 2006 (epub); 6 (3)

http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2318/6/3


BMJ review on pain in dementia

Scherder E, Oosterman J, Swaab D, Herr K, Oooms M, Ribbe M, Sergeant J, Pickering G, Benedetti F.
Clinical review: recent developments in pain in dementia.
BMJ  2005;330  (26 February):461-464 (26 February)

http://www.bmj.com//cgi/content/full/330/7489/461

 

Portal with useful links to elderly people with dementia

http://www.cityofhope.org/prc/elderly.asp

In particular, the following is useful in assessing pain:

Assessing pain in the nonverbal or cognitively impaired:
http://www.cityofhope.org/prc/pdf/Assessing%20Pain%209-06.pdf

 

End of life assessment for people with dementia and associated disorders

Volicer L, Hurley AC, Blasi ZV.
Scales for Evaluation of End-of-Life Care in dementia
Alzheimer Disease & Associated Disorders.2001; 15 (4): p194-200

(This describes a validated  tool for end of life care)

http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/entrez?cmd=Retrieve&db=PubMed&list_uids=11723370&dopt=Citation

 

Working with carers

Silerberg E.
Introducing the 3-A grief intervention model for dementia caregivers: Acknowledge, assess and assist.
Omega  2007;54 (3): p215-235.

 

Residential care homes

Volicer L.
End of life for people with advanced dementia in residential care settings. Chicago: Alzheimer’s Association 2005.
http://www.alz.org/national/documents/endoflifelitreview.pdf

 

In addition

Aminoff-Bechor-Zvi, Adunsky, A.
Dying dementia patients: Too much suffering, too little palliation.
American Journal of Hospice & Palliative Medicine,  2005, 22  (5)  p.344-348. Link to PubMed abstract.

(This journal changed its name from American Journal of Hospice & Palliative Care to American Journal of Hospice & Palliative Medicine in 2005. It could appear under either title that year)  

 

Dementia Knowledge Week. Palliative Care / End of life Care

http://www.library.nhs.uk/laterlife/ViewResource.aspx?resID=262127

 

Author's masters thesis

Assessment of cognitive impairment in palliative care patients: the utility of the clock drawing test.  (Unpublished 2005). An abstract is available:

Scottt S, Henderson M. Assessing cognitive impairment in palliative care patients: the utility of the clock drawing test (abstract)
Palliative Medicine  2006;20 (3): p271.

(Palliative Medicine is available via an Athens password provided by the NHS for eligible clinicians)

document.title: Dialysis decision-making and advance planning – an evidence guide for palliative professionals
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,SERVICE PROVISION,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,RENAL DISEASES,KIDNEY DISEASES,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,HAEMODIALYSIS,PERITONEAL DIALYSIS,STARTING PERITONEAL DIALYSIS,STARTING HAEMODIALYSIS]]>
document.body:
111-1Dialysis decision-making and advance planning – an evidence guide for palliative professionals

Written by Helen Noble, Barts and The London NHS Trust, Whitechapel and City University, London


Introduction

Palliative care in end-stage renal disease (ESRD) is increasingly important as the numbers with ESRD increase. This increase includes disproportionately more sicker and older patients who may not fare well on dialysis, with adverse impact on their quality of life (1). This article identifies the evidence (and lack of it) on dialysis decision-making; for those who withdraw from dialysis and for the increasing numbers who opt not to have dialysis.

 

Making dialysis decisions - the doctor’s perspective

Discontinuation of dialysis is a common cause of death in ESRD patients in the UK and the USA (2-4). Differences in prevalence of dialysis discontinuation may be attributed to differences in referral patterns, dialysis strategies, and variable attitudes of physicians and patients as well as variations in the way dialysis withdrawal is reported (5). Dialysis withdrawal is not always given as the cause of death especially if the patient had high co-morbidity (6), so is under recognised as a cause of death.

 

A review of dialysis discontinuation by Murtagh et al (7) indicates that discontinuation is an increasingly common event prior to death for those with ESRD. Several studies have attempted to understand how patients are selected for dialysis, their prognosis on dialysis, and subsequent dialysis withdrawal practices (1;8-15). These are primarily quantitative in nature and use questionnaires (9;13;16;17), retrospective data analysis (14;15;18), and surveys (12).  All focus on professional practice and add to the evidence on staff decision-making, especially nephrologists. Lambie et al studied the associations between nephrologists’ opinions, availability of dialysis, patient characteristics and comorbidities, and withdrawal rates, in 6 countries including France, Germany, Italy, Spain, UK and the USA. They found wide disagreement over when to start dialysis for patients with advanced age, dementia and other comorbidities, and when to withdraw dialysis for all patients (15). Differences within and across countries probably reflect variations in access to dialysis as well as the practice of withdrawal. Disparities in practice are common, with some nephrologists accepting all patients for dialysis believing that refusal equates to passive euthanasia (13), and some reporting little instruction in medical ethics and management of life sustaining treatments (19), highlighting an obvious need for education in this area.

 

Making dialysis decisions - the patients’ perspective

There is little published evidence on the patient component of decision making. Renal patients have only infrequently had their perspective reported. Withdrawal from dialysis results in death within days, so is a decision with rapid and serious consequences (5). It has been claimed that ‘withholding or withdrawing life-supporting treatment is one of the most ethical issues for medicine in the late 20th century’ (20). Alongside this, palliative care for patients with ESRD is a neglected aspect of nephrology (21).

 

Calvin highlights the fact that although there is a general lack of knowledge concerning end-of-life treatment preferences of patients undergoing haemodialysis, patients (when prompted) tend to focus on living rather than dying (22). Grounded theory was used to explore decisions among haemodialysis patients and their end-of-life treatment decisions and a substantive theory of ‘personal preservation’ was developed consisting of three phases: knowing the odds for survival, beating the odds and being responsible and taking chances (22).

 

There are 3 other recent studies (23-25). Ashby et al (23) examined the experiences of patients opting not to have dialysis, or withdrawing from dialysis treatment, taking into account the social and personal impact of this decision. Themes identified included poor quality of life, pain and suffering, a desire not to be a burden, and doctor-patient issues (prognostic uncertainty and a sense of abandonment). The authors recommend a pro-active and open approach towards end of life issues, and suggest that the clinical and health promoting principles of palliative care be integrated into dialysis practice. They also recognize the need for clinical guidelines related to end of life care, advance directives, peer mentoring, and clinical and health promoting palliative care initiatives.

 

Studies by Fujimaki et al (24) and Chan et al (25), retrospectively reviewed patients who had ‘refused’ the offer of dialysis. Motivation for refusal included not wishing to attend the hospital frequently, feeling ‘too old’ for dialysis, that it would be more ‘natural’ to die without dialysis, and for family reasons. These papers are of interest but the small numbers and retrospective design limit their findings. A review by Germain et al highlights how little we really know about how renal patients die and the urgent need for further study (4). It also promotes the concept of ‘conservative management’ programmes to ensure appropriate support for those who refuse dialysis.

 

Advance planning

Most work on advance directives in ESRD originates in the United States (26-30) - it focuses on the role of advance directives in dialysis withdrawal decisions but not on those who have opted not to start dialysis. Evidence indicates that patients prefer to have discussions regarding end of life care with their families/carers rather than health professionals (31).

 

In a study by Sehgal et al, American, German and Japanese nephrologists were asked for their views on advance directives (32). Family preference to stop dialysis increased the willingness of all 3 groups to stop dialysis, although American nephrologists were more likely to do so than German and Japanese nephrologists. The presence of an advance directive requesting that dialysis be stopped as well as a family preference to stop led to almost all nephrologists saying that they would stop dialysis, although a significant minority of the German and Japanese nephrologists would still continue dialysis.

 

Practice across countries in relation to advance directives varies considerably. Further study is needed to elucidate this, and to understand patient attitudes towards advance directives. The renal population opting not to embark on dialysis are rarely offered the opportunity for advance planning. We need to know if and how advance planning may be of help to this group as death approaches.

 

Conclusion

The treatment of ESRD has raised many ethical concerns. Whether to commence dialysis and when to stop are two questions that are often difficult to answer, and with limited evidence to clarify them. As services offering palliative care to those with ESRD evolve (33;34), these dilemmas will continue. There is considerable need for decision-making and advance planning to be better informed by evidence, so that care to patients and their families can be improved.

 

References

(1)  Smith C, Silva-Gane M, Chandra S, Warwicker P, Greenwood R, Farrington K. Choosing not to dialyse: evaluation of planned non-dialytic management in a cohort of patients with end-stage renal failure. Nephron Clinical Practice 2003;95(2):917-30.

 

(2)  Cohen LM, Germain MJ. The psychiatric landscape of withdrawal. Seminars in Dialysis 2005 Mar;18(2):147-53.

 

(3)  Ikaheimo R, Kervinen M, Karhapaa P, Tryyki R, Lehto S, Ryynanen OP, et al. Discontinuation of dialysis treatment: experience of a single dialysis centre. Scandinavian Journal of Urology & Nephrology 2005;39(5):417-22.

 

(4)  Germain M, Cohen L, Davison S. Withholding and withdrawal from dialysis: What we know about how our patients die. Seminars in Dialysis 2007;20(3):195-9.

 

(5)  Birmele B, Francois M, Pengloan J, Francais P, Testou D, Brillet G, et al. Death after withdrawal from dialysis: the most common cause of death in a French dialysis population. Nephrol Dial Transplant 2004;19(3):686-91.

 

(6)  Mailloux LU, Bellucci AG, Napolitano B, Mossey RT, Wilkes BM, Bluestone PA. Death by withdrawal from dialysis: a 20-year clinical experience. J Am Soc Nephrol 1993 Mar;3(9):1631-7.

 

(7)  Murtagh F, Cohen LM, Germain M. Dialysis Discontinuation: Quo Vardis?  Advances in Renal Medicine, 2007; 14 (4): 379-401.

 

(8)  Bosshard G, Fischer S, van der HA, Miccinesi G, Faisst K. Intentionally hastening death by withholding or withdrawing treatment. Wiener Klinische Wochenschrift 2006 Jun;118(11-12):322-6.

 

(9)  Clement R, Chevalet P, Rodat O, Ould-Aoudia V, Berger M. Withholding or withdrawing dialysis in the elderly: the perspective of a western region of France. Nephrology Dialysis Transplantation 2005;20(11):2446-52.

 

(10)  Joly D, Anglicheau D, Alberti C, Nguyen AT, Touam M, Grunfeld JP, et al. Octogenarians reaching end-stage renal disease: cohort study of decision-making and clinical outcomes. J Am Soc Nephrol 2003 Apr;14(4):1012-21.

 

(11)  Sekkarie MA, Moss AH. Withholding and withdrawing dialysis: the role of physician specialty and education and patient functional status. American Journal of Kidney Diseases 1998 Mar;31(3):464-72.

 

(12)  McKenzie J, Moss A, Feest TG, Stocking C, Siegler M. Dialysis decision making in Canada, the United Kingdom and the United States. American Journal of Kidney Diseases 1998;31(1):12-8.

 

(13)  Pollini J, Teissier M. A difficult dilemma to resolve: aged patients refused for treatment by iterative hemodialysis. Ethical problem or medical choice? Reflections apropos of a questionnaire-inquiry. Nephrologie 1990;11(5):341-7.

 

(14)  Chandra S, Schulz J, Lawrence C, Greenwood R, Farrington K. Is there a rationale for rationing chronic dialysis? A hospital-based cohort study of factors affecting survival and morbidity. BMJ 1999;318:217-23.

 

(15)  Lambie M, Rayner H, Bragg-Gresham J, Pisoni R, Andreucci V, Canaud B, et al. Starting and withdrawing haemodialysis - associations between nephrologists' opinions, patient characteristics and practice patterns (data from the Dialysis Outcomes and Practice Patterns Study). Nephrol Dial Transplant 2006;21:2814-20.

 

(16)  Bosshard G, Fischer S, van der HA, Miccinesi G, Faisst K. Intentionally hastening death by withholding or withdrawing treatment. Wiener Klinische Wochenschrift 2006 Jun;118(11-12):322-6.

 

(17)  Sekkarie MA, Moss AH. Withholding and withdrawing dialysis: the role of physician specialty and education and patient functional status. American Journal of Kidney Diseases 1998 Mar;31(3):464-72.

 

(18)  Joly D, Anglicheau D, Alberti C, Nguyen AT, Touam M, Grunfeld JP, et al. Octogenarians reaching end-stage renal disease: cohort study of decision-making and clinical outcomes. J Am Soc Nephrol 2003 Apr;14(4):1012-21.

 

(19)  Holley J, Foulks C, Moss A. Nephrologists' reported attitudes about factors influencing recommendations to initiate or withdraw dialysis. J Am Soc Nephrol 1991;1(12):1284-8.

 

(20)  Neu S, Kjellstrand C. Stopping long-term dialysis. An empirical study of withdrawal of life-supporting treatment. New England Journal of Medicine 1986;314(1):14-20.

 

(21)  Gunda S, Smith S, Thomas M. National Survey of Palliative Care in end-stage renal disease in the UK. Nephrol Dial Transplant 2004;20:392-5.

 

(22)  Calvin A. Haemodialysis patients and end-of-life decisions: a theory of personal preservation. Journal of Advanced Nursing 2004;46(5):558-66.

 

(23)  Ashby M, op't HC, Kellehear A, Kerr PG, Brooks D, Nicholls K, et al. Renal dialysis abatement: lessons from a social study. Palliative Medicine 2005;19(5):389-96.

 

(24)  Fujimaki H, Kasuya Y, Kawaguchi S, Hara S, Koga S, Takahashi T, et al. Refusal of initiation of dialysis by elderly patients with chronic renal failure. Nippon Ronen Igakkai Zasshi 2005;42(4):417-22.

 

(25)  Chan C, Noble H, Lo S, Kwan T, Lee S, Sze W. Palliative care for patients with end-stage renal disease: experiences from Hong Kong. International Journal of Palliative Nursing 2007;13(7):310-4.

 

(26)  Sehgal A, Galbraith A, Chesney M, Schoenfeld P, Charles G, Lo B. How strictly do dialysis patients want their advance directives followed? Jama 1992 Jan 1;267(1):59-63.

 

(27)  Sehgal AR, Weisheit C, Miura Y, Butzlaff M, Kielstein R, Taguchi Y. Advance directives and withdrawal of dialysis in the United States, Germany, and Japan. Jama 1996 Nov 27;276(20):1652-6.

 

(28)  Rutecki GW, Rodriguez L, Cugino A, Jarjoura D, Hastings F, Whittier FC. End of life issues in ESRD. A study of three decision variables that affect patient attitudes. ASAIO Journal 1994 Jul;40(3):798-802.

(29)  Hines SC, Glover JJ, Babrow AS, Holley JL, Badzek LA, Moss AH. Improving advance care planning by accommodating family preferences. Journal of Palliative Medicine 2001;4(4):481-9.

 

(30)  Holley JL, Hines SC, Glover JJ, Babrow AS, Badzek LA, Moss AH. Failure of advance care planning to elicit patients' preferences for withdrawal from dialysis. American Journal of Kidney Diseases 1999 Apr;33(4):688-93.

 

(31)  Holley JL. Palliative care in end-stage renal disease: Focus on advance care planning, hospice referral and bereavement. Seminars in Dialysis 2005;18:154-6.

 

(32)  Sehgal AR, Weisheit C, Miura Y, Butzlaff M, Kielstein R, Taguchi Y. Advance directives and withdrawal of dialysis in the United States, Germany, and Japan. Jama 1996 Nov 27;276(20):1652-6.

 

(33)  Murtagh F, Murphy E, Shepherd KA, Donohue, Edmonds PM. End-of-life care in end-stage renal disease: renal and palliative care. British Journal of Nursing 2006;15(1):8-11.

 

(34)  Noble H, Chesser A. Developing a Renal Supportive Care Service for patients opting not to dialyse. End of Life Journal in Press 2007.

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Epidemiology and prognosis in advanced chronic kidney disease: Implications for palliative care
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ RENAL DISEASES,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION,CONDITIONS,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,KIDNEY DISEASES,CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
111-1Epidemiology and prognosis in advanced chronic kidney disease: Implications for palliative care

Written by Neil Sheerin, Professor of Nephrology, School of Clinical Medical Sciences, Newcastle University.

 

Introduction

The prevalence of diagnosed severe renal disease is increasing rapidly. Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) stages 3-5 (estimated glomerular filtration rate <60mls/min or less) affects 8.5% of the UK population [1]. Consequently the dialysis population (stage 5 CKD) in the UK is rising by 5% per annum [2]. One major factor is the increasing age of the population as the prevalence of CKD rises dramatically with age [3], 1 in 500 males aged 75-85 years now being on dialysis2. As well as the increasing age of the population, the high prevalence of co-morbidities associated with CKD, for example diabetes mellitus, is also impacting on the epidemiology of CKD [4], [5].

 

 

Availability and impact of dialysis


Maintenance dialysis for CKD became available in the UK in the 1960’s.  Until the 1980’s availability of dialysis was very limited and older patients or patients with significant co-morbidity were frequently not considered for treatment. Fortunately this has changed and now neither age nor co-morbidity excludes a patient from dialysis. However, nephrologists in the 21st century face a different challenge; how do we best manage incident CKD patients who are now increasingly aged and have greater associated co-morbidity?

 

There is a significant treatment burden associated with dialysis. Invasive surgical procedures are required, treatment is usually three times per week for the rest of the patient’s life, and each treatment often takes most of a day. Patients also remain very symptomatic, despite dialysis. So dialysis is often poorly tolerated, particularly in older patients with co-morbidity, the exact patient group with highest prevalence of stage 5 CKD.

 

 

Dialysis decision-making


Nephrologists therefore need to consider whether dialysis is the correct treatment for all patients with CKD 5 [6]. There are two distinct scenarios. Firstly, the patient who presents acutely with advanced renal failure with life threatening complications such as hyperkalaemia or fluid overload. In this situation (without definite contra-indication such as advanced malignancy, severe co-morbidity, or technical difficulty in delivering dialysis), dialysis should be initiated. If there is uncertainty about appropriateness of treatment, this can be reviewed once the patient’s condition has been stabilised.

 

The second scenario is of a patient with slowly progressive CKD. GFR falls with age by 1-2 mls per minute per year after the age of 40 years, even in healthy individuals. Many patients with CKD stage 5 may only lose GFR at this or a slightly higher rate. Therefore, a patient with stage 5 CKD (eGFR <15ml/min) may have a dialysis-free life expectancy of several years, ,even though an argument could be made for initiating dialysis at this point. Therefore, a critical question is whether all patients benefit from dialysis, particularly those with a shorter life expectancy due to age and/or significant co-morbidity.

 

 

Evidence on survival with or without dialysis


There have been no prospective randomised trials assessing the benefit of dialysis in this group and it is the opinion of the author that such a study is unlikely to occur, and we have to rely on observational studies. Smith et al report survival of 38 patients who, after multi-disciplinary assessment, were recommended palliative treatment rather than dialysis [7]. In this cohort, 10 subsequently chose to have dialysis and 18 followed a palliative pathway. Choosing to dialyse did not significantly alter survival. A second study considered all patients over the 75 years with stage 5 CKD managed in specialist nephrology care. 77 patients (60%) were established on a treatment pathway that did not include dialysis [8]. These patients had significantly worse survival than those patients on a pathway that included dialysis, suggesting that overall elderly patients do benefit from dialysis, at least in terms of survival. However, it is impossible to exclude a selection bias, with fitter patients choosing dialysis. Importantly in this study if the patients with higher co-morbidity were considered in isolation choosing dialysis offered no survival benefit, which concurs with the experience of other renal units [9]. As well as co-morbidity predicting survival [10], functional capacity should also be assessed when considering whether a patient will benefit from dialysis, as this is also a good indicator of survival in stage 5 CKD [11].

 

 

Implications


So what does this mean for nephrologists and palliative care physicians?  Older patients with co-morbidity can be given choice whether or not to dialyse without a major adverse effect on survival. Experience suggests that 15-20% of all stage 5 CKD patients will choose not to dialysis. This is patient group with a high symptom burden equivalent or greater than that of patients with malignant disease [12], an unpredictable disease trajectory and therefore needing significant medical and social input.

 

The suggestion that older patients with significant co-morbidity benefit gain only marginal benefit, if at all, from dialysis identifies a second group of patients that have significant palliative care needs, namely those that do start dialysis. These patients continue to have a large symptom burden because: dialysis will not alleviate all symptoms of renal failure, dialysis itself will add to the symptom burden and many symptoms may relate to other co-morbidities not affected by dialysis [13]. It is vital that we do not ignore palliative needs in this patient group because they are being actively treated and remember that dialysis is itself a palliative treatment for renal failure and not a cure. If we consider all patients over 75 years of age, irrespective of co-morbidity, 40-50% will die in the first year after starting dialysis [14]. With such a high mortality and no robust tool to predict which patients will die, a case could be made for considering the palliative needs, for example symptom control, resuscitation status and preferred place of care, for all older incident dialysis patients. Generally this is not done well by nephrologists with limited expertise and resources allocated to this important element of patient care.

 

 

Dialysis withdrawal


Withdrawal from dialysis is an increasingly common cause of death of our patients [15] and in New England one-in three deaths follow the decision to stop dialysis [16]. This is a complex decision, and patients and carers require support not only in making the decision to stop but in planning the remainder of their life. This is an area where the skills of palliative care teams are critical in ensuring a good death for the patient. It is important that this input is not limited to after any decision is made, but instead palliative care services are involved throughout the process. There are different considerations for those patients who stop dialysis compared to those that do not start. The survival after dialysis withdrawal is much shorter (median survival 8 days[17]). Patients will lose residual renal function whilst on dialysis and therefore become rapidly uraemic on cessation. Although this is a critical and relatively predictable phase of a patient’s management the evidence would suggest that it is phase that is not managed well [16].

 

 

Future developments


The number of patients who have both nephrology and palliative care needs are increasing and this increase is likely to continue [4]. It is vital that links between these two specialities develop to provide optimum patient care. In addition, it has to be recognised that these patients have very significant medical needs and meeting these needs is not cheap. The system for funding dialysis treatment of stage 5 CKD is well established but no equivalent exists for non-dialysis treatment. As data accumulates to suggest that non-dialysis treatment is a realistic, perhaps more appropriate, option for some patients, this is a situation that must change.

 

 

References


1. Stevens PE, O'Donoghue DJ, de Lusignan S, et al. Chronic kidney disease management in the United Kingdom: NEOERICA project results. Kidney international 2007;72(1):92-9.

 

2. Ansell D, Feest T, Hodsman A, et al. UK Renal Registry: The Ninth Annual report; 2006.

 

3. Coresh J, Astor BC, Greene T, Eknoyan G, Levey AS. Prevalence of chronic kidney disease and decreased kidney function in the adult US population: Third National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey. Am J Kidney Dis 2003;41(1):1-12.

 

4. Krishnan M, Lok CE, Jassal SV. Epidemiology and demographic aspects of treated end-stage renal disease in the elderly. Seminars in dialysis 2002;15(2):79-83.

 

5. Roderick P, Davies R, Jones C, Feest T, Smith S, Farrington K. Simulation model of renal replacement therapy: predicting future demand in England. Nephrol Dial Transplant 2004;19(3):692-701.

 

6. Burns A. Conservative management of end-stage renal failure: masterly inactivity or benign neglect? See Smith et al., pp. c40-c46. Nephron Clin Pract 2003;95(2):c37-9.

 

7. Smith C, Da Silva-Gane M, Chandna S, Warwicker P, Greenwood R, Farrington K. Choosing not to dialyse: evaluation of planned non-dialytic management in a cohort of patients with end-stage renal failure. Nephron Clin Pract 2003;95(2):c40-6.

 

8. Murtagh FE, Marsh JE, Donohoe P, Ekbal NJ, Sheerin NS, Harris FE. Dialysis or not? A comparative survival study of patients over 75 years with chronic kidney disease stage 5. Nephrol Dial Transplant 2007;22(7):1955-62.

 

9. Dasgupta I, Rayner HC. Dialysis versus conservative management of elderly patients with advanced chronic kidney disease. Nature clinical practice 2007;3(9):480-1.

 

10. Wong CF, McCarthy M, Howse ML, Williams PS. Factors affecting survival in advanced chronic kidney disease patients who choose not to receive dialysis. Renal failure 2007;29(6):653-9.

 

11. Chandna SM, Schulz J, Lawrence C, Greenwood RN, Farrington K. Is there a rationale for rationing chronic dialysis? A hospital based cohort study of factors affecting survival and morbidity. BMJ (Clinical research ed 1999;318(7178):217-23.

 

12. Murtagh FE, Addington-Hall J, Higginson IJ. The prevalence of symptoms in end-stage renal disease: a systematic review. Advances in chronic kidney disease 2007;14(1):82-99.

 

13. Solano JP, Gomes B, Higginson IJ. A comparison of symptom prevalence in far advanced cancer, AIDS, heart disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and renal disease. Journal of pain and symptom management 2006;31(1):58-69.

 

14. Kurella M, Covinsky KE, Collins AJ, Chertow GM. Octogenarians and nonagenarians starting dialysis in the United States. Annals of internal medicine 2007;146(3):177-83.

 

15. US Renal Data System: USRDS annual data report. Am J Kidney Dis 2007;49 (Suppl. 1):s1-s235.

 

16. Germain MJ, Cohen LM, Davison SN. Withholding and withdrawal from dialysis: what we know about how our patients die. Seminars in dialysis 2007;20(3):195-9.

 

17. Chambers JE. End of life care. In: Chambers JE, Germain MJ, Brown E, eds. Supportive care for the renal patient. Oxford: Oxford Press; 2004:255-64.


 

]]>

document.title: History of euthanasia debates in the United States and Britain
document.publisher: Annals of Internal Medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,POLICY,ETHICS & LAW,HUMANITIES,EUTHANASIA]]>
document.description: Journal article providing a historical perspective on euthanasia.
document.body: <![CDATA[ "The arguments propounded for and against euthanasia in the 19th<SUP> </SUP>century are identical to contemporary arguments.Such similarities<SUP> </SUP>suggest four conclusions: Public interest in euthanasia 1) is<SUP> </SUP>not linked with advances in biomedical technology; 2) it flourishes<SUP> </SUP>in times of economic recession, in which individualism and social<SUP> </SUP>Darwinism are invoked to justify public policy; 3) it arises<SUP> </SUP>when physician authority over medical decision making is challenged;<SUP> </SUP>and 4) it occurs when terminating life-sustaining medical interventions<SUP> </SUP>become standard medical practice and interest develops in extending<SUP> </SUP>such practices to include euthanasia.<SUP>"</SUP>]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Introduction from the National Council for Palliative Care's Policy Unit
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ RESPIRATORY,PUBLICATIONS,CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE,SERVICE PROVISION,MOTOR NEURONE DISEASE,VARIANT CREUTZFELDT-JAKOB DISEASE (VCJD),ALZHEIMER’S DISEASE,LYMPHOEDEMA,POLICY,CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD),UNITED KINGDOM,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,RESPIRATORY DISEASES,NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,RENAL DISEASES,HAEMATOLOGIC AND LYMPHATIC DISEASES,PARKINSON'S DISEASE,MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS,HUNTINGTON'S DISEASE,REPORTS]]>
document.body:
111-1Introduction from the National Council for Palliative Care's Policy Unit

Recent years have seen the extension of palliative and end of life care beyond its traditional focus of meeting the needs of people with cancer to covering all conditions and across all settings. This is reflected through all recent national policy such as the National Service Framework for Long Term Neurological Conditions and the NICE Guidance on Dementia. To therefore support all those involved in palliative care including policy makers, service planners and providers, commissioners, service users and carers address this change in focus the National Council for Palliative Care (NCPC) set up the policy unit.

 

The NCPC is the umbrella body for all who commission, provide or use palliative care services across all settings in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. The NCPC policy unit provides practical policy solutions and has groups of experts and key partners/ stakeholders looking at:

  • The needs of older people which is a cross cutting group covering all areas of health and social care including housing and care homes;
    • With a subgroup looking specifically at the needs of people with dementia;
  • The needs of people with neurological conditions;
  • The needs of people with heart and renal conditions;
  • The needs of people with chronic respiratory disease;
  • The needs of people with cancer.

Each group provides guidance, events and solutions/ examples of good practice for addressing palliative care needs. Full details are available at:

http://www.ncpc.org.uk/policy_unit/index.html

 

Examples of recent work include:

  • Focus on Neurology
  • Progress with Dementia
  • End of Life Care: A Commissioning Perspective
  • Population Based Needs Assessment
  • A Fresh Approach: Palliative Care and Chronic Respiratory Disease Event 4th December 2007
  • Deactivation of Internal Cardiac Defibrillators
  • Specialist Palliative Care Workforce Survey
  • Specialist Palliative Care activity data
  • Data or Die: Information Needs in the Brand New World of Healthcare Event 22nd November 2007
  • Artificial Nutrition and Hydration
  • Changing Gear: Managing the Last Days of Life.

This work and the importance NCPC places on meeting everyone’s palliative care needs regardless of diagnosis or setting of care mean we are very happy to work with NLH in this week long awareness campaign.

 

Lucy Sutton
National Policy Lead
The National Council for Palliative Care

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Introduction from the National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION,POLICY,CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD),ALZHEIMER’S DISEASE,LYMPHOEDEMA,MOTOR NEURONE DISEASE,VARIANT CREUTZFELDT-JAKOB DISEASE (VCJD),PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,RESPIRATORY DISEASES,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES,CONDITIONS,RENAL DISEASES,PARKINSON'S DISEASE,HAEMATOLOGIC AND LYMPHATIC DISEASES,UNITED KINGDOM,HUNTINGTON'S DISEASE,MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS]]>
document.body:
111-1Introduction from the National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care

Welcome to the second National Knowledge Week run by the National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care. The first NKW was on the subject of 'Pain' and details can be found here.

 

The focus of this NKW is on the much broader topic of 'Palliative and supportive care in non-cancer diseases.' There are three main drivers for choosing this subejct. First, as palliative and supportive have developed over the past 20 years in the context of cancer care, a considerable knoweldge base has been accumulated which has clearly benefited enormous number of cancer patients and their carers - albeit, mainly in the more advanced stages of the disease. But in recent years, research and clincial experience have moved apace in many areas of chronic disease management, such as heart failure, chronic respiratory disease, neurological conditions. We have worked with specialists to search and review the literature in these fields, and the results will be presented this week in the form of Annual Evidence Updates. However, it soon became clear to us that the growth of robust evidence, in the form of systematic reviews and meta-analyses, is still limited in these areas. We hope that this resource will direct and inspire others to fill in the gaps of our knowledge.

 

Second, the National Council for Pallaitive Care has in recent years taken on the challenge of extending the scope of palliative and supportive care beyond cancer very seriously. We are delighted therefore to be working in partnership with NCPC this week on highlighting what progress has occured under their leadership. For more details of NCPC's involvement, see Lucy Sutton's article.

 

Third, and probably most importantly, the sheer size of the growing burden of chronic diseases provides a moral and public health imperative for us all to engage more energetically in this issue. The UK Government has shown its committment through the End of Life Care strategy, which will be announced later this year. But all those who care for patients suffering the physical, psyschosocial, spiritual and other consequences of chronic and life-limiting diseases need to become more engaged in bringing the benefits of an evidence-based palliative and supportive care approach to these patients and families. We hope that this National Knowledge Week will help more individuals and teams to be more productive and rewarded through this work.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Introduction to bereavement services
document.publisher: National Library for Health Palliative & Supportive Care Specialist Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,DEATH,SERVICE PROVISION,PROFESSIONS,BEREAVEMENT SERVICE STAFF,SERVICE TYPE,BEREAVEMENT SERVICES,BEREAVEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-1Introduction to bereavement services

1. Definition of topic

“Most bereavement services are based on the assumption that loss through death challenges coping abilities and that supportive interventions may facilitate post-death adaptation, reduce complicated grief reactions and promote wellbeing”  (Field et al. 2004). 

 

2. Guidance/Evidence available 

 

Guidance

Improving supportive and palliative care for adults with cancer - the manual

Chapter 12 covers guidance on services for families and services and carers, including bereavement services. However, it refers to the type of support needed for bereaved people but does not consider the shape of the service.

When a patient dies: advice on developing bereavement services in the NHS

This outlines services that should be implemented in the immediate aftermath of a death but does not delineate a service which provides a bereavement service providing ongoing support over a number of months or years.

 

Evidence

A synthesis of psychological interventions for the bereaved

This study, retrieved from the DARE database, comments on a literature review which looks at bereavement interventions. Authors concluded that, overall the interventions were largely methodologically flawed, rarely specified what theory of bereavement they were testing, and showed surprisingly weak effect sizes. 

Bereavement care interventions: a systematic review

This literature review published by Biomed Central, comes to a similar conclusion to that above. Due to a paucity of reports on controlled clinical trails, no rigorous evidence-based recommendation regarding the treatment of bereaved persons is currently possible except for the pharmacologic treatment of depression. The authors postulated the following five factors as impeding scientific progress regarding bereavement care interventions: 1) excessive theoretical heterogeneity, 2) stultifying between-study variation, 3) inadequate reporting of intervention procedures, 4) few published replication studies, and 5) methodological flaws of study design.

Support for women/families after perinatal death

This Cochrane review also concludes that no information is available from randomised trials to indicate whether there is or is not a benefit from providing specific psychological support or counselling after perinatal death.

 

Discussion

It is perhaps not surprising that evidence for a benefit from bereavement services is difficult to assess since: (a) the population is very diverse. Bereaved inviduals range from young children to the elderly; (b) bereaved inviduals have a myriad of relationships with the person who has died and with those with whom they grieve; (c) the length of time since bereavement varies considerably, should someone be referred to a service; (d) bereaved people come from every possible cultural, ethnic and religious group. Studies on both child and adult bereavement services in the UK indicate that the type of service provision varies considerably.  Evaluation of services is especially problematic as the extent of bereavement support can be provided/integrated into standard care. For example, in the case of perinatal death, hospital ward staff often offer support which is specific to bereavement, but is not regarded per se as a bereavement service.  However, surveys of services provide evidence of what is happening in various areas in the UK - examples include the following references.

 

References

  • Rolls L, Payne S. 2003, Childhood bereavement services: a survey of UK provision, Palliative Medicine 17(5):423-432.  (Available via NHS Core Content with an Athens password).
  • Rolls L, Payne S. 2004, Childhood bereavement services: issues in UK service provision Mortality 9(4):300-328.
  • Field D, Reid D, Payne S, Relf, M. 2004, Survey of UK hospice and specialist palliative care adult bereavement services. International Journal of Palliative Nursing 10(12):569-576.
  • Reid D, Field D, Payne S, Relf M. 2006, Adult bereavement in five English hospices: types of support. International Journal of Palliative Nursing 12(9):430-437.

 

Standards

There have been other attempts to develop standards for the provision of bereavement services. However, at this stage for the NHS in England users are referred to the Guidance section above. The resources below should be read as an introduction to the subject.   

  • http://www.grief.org.au/projects.html

(The library at St Christopher’s Hospice has some standards that were created a few years ago. They have not been updated but may be useful as a guide to examining relevant issues in the creation of new ones.  Email: d.brady@stchristophers.org.uk )

 

Conferences

Abstracts can be downloaded from these recent conferences:

7th International conference on grief and bereavement in contemporary society 12-15 July 2005, Kings College, London 

[To see abstracts arranged by author, see this web page]

 

Abstracts from the 9th EAPC conference in Aachen, Germany 2005, 3rd EAPC Research Forum in Stresa, Italy 2004, 8th EAPC conference in The Hague, Netherlands, 2003 and 4th EAPC Research Forum in Venice, Italy, 2006.

[Select the category 'grief, bereavement & support' on this page to see all results for this topic from all these conferences]

 

Literature search

A search was also conducted on the databases provided by the NLH to its users.  It should be noted that here the quality of the research has not yet been critically appraised in detail.  However, the results presented provide helpful background to those researching the provision of bereavement services. 

 

The search was conducted using the terms bereavement and service evaluation, using all the databases available on NHS core content.  The term bereavement was searched as a subject heading (in PsycInfo the subject heading used was grief). In cases where the term service evaluation was unavailable as a thesaurus term, an appropriate alternative term was used.  However, if there did not appear to be any appropriate other term, the term bereavement service$ was used. 


Excluding services for children and adolescents, 86 items were identified as being of potential use to anyone seeking material on this subject.  Most items are post 1996, though a search on one database yielded earlier items.  Some of the items below are available in full text to NHS users.  

 

The titles are listed first:

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Introduction to end-stage renal disease in palliative and supportive care
document.publisher: National Library for Health Palliative & Supportive Care Specialist Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ UNITED KINGDOM,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,POLICY,SERVICE PROVISION,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,RENAL DISEASES,KIDNEY DISEASES,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS,END-OF-LIFE CARE]]>
document.body:
111-1Introduction to end-stage renal disease in palliative and supportive care

Definitions

Chronic kidney disease (CKD) differs somewhat from other advanced diseases in that there is a specific measure of disease severity (glomerular filtration rate - GFR) which can be used as an indicator of how advanced the disease is. When estimated GFR falls below 15 mL per minute per 1.73 m body surface area, the CKD patient has reached Stage 5, the most advanced stage of chronic kidney disease [1]. At this point, renal replacement therapy (in the form of dialysis or renal transplant) must be considered if the patient is to survive in the long term, although a small proportion of patients with slow decline in renal function may not develop symptoms of uraemia (and so need renal replacement) for weeks, months or (rarely) years after first reaching Stage 5. 

End-stage renal disease (ESRD) is irreversible decline in kidney function, severe enough to be fatal in the absence of dialysis or transplantation [2] (i.e. it refers to the time when renal replacement is actually needed).

 

Which renal patients need palliative care?

Patients whose palliative and supportive care needs should be considered are those with Stage 5 CKD who:

• Decline renal replacement therapy (dialysis or transplant) through their own preference
• Are advised against renal replacement therapy because the burden of frequent dialysis is felt to outweigh likely survival and quality of life benefits (a complex and difficult decision likely to apply more often to those with poorer prognoses)
• Have been on dialysis but are now withdrawing or about to withdraw from dialysis
• Are ON dialysis but with a poor prognosis, often because of co-morbid conditions (especially cardiac disease)

 

Context of end of life care in renal disease

Renal deaths account for just 1-2% of all deaths [3, 4], although this is an underestimate - other causes of death frequently intervene or co-exist in the final days making death registration an imprecise record. But numbers reaching ESRD are increasing steadily (by between 2-8 % annually [5, 6]), and this increase is projected to continue in parallel with the ageing of the general population and the growing prevalence of diabetes mellitus [7]. Many patients will have one or more co-morbidities [5, 6], and may well die from causes other than their renal disease.

As with all non-cancer conditions, understanding of survival and illness trajectory (and how these differ from cancer) is important to estimate the best timing for and triggers into palliative care (general, renal and specialist palliative care, as needed), the resources needed for palliative and end-of-life provision, and to facilitate advance care planning. It is also important to understand palliative needs, including symptom prevalence, psychological needs, social and spiritual needs, as well as which interventions are most effective.

 

Guidance/evidence available

Guidance: see what is under this tab in the Library

Evidence: see what is under this tab in the Library

Characteristics of this population: Most patients with ESRD needing palliative care are older people, with high levels of co-morbidity [5,6]; they have variable and often complex needs, with symptoms which are often unaddressed [8]. A systematic literature review of symptom prevalence in ESRD identified evidence mainly from dialysis populations, but illustrates the high prevalence of symptoms experienced by these patients [9].

Dialysis withdrawal: Recent reviews of the evidence in those withdrawing from dialysis identify mean survival from withdrawal as 8-10 days, with a range of 1-44 days [10, 11],  but also highlight the dearth of evidence on palliative needs. Retrospective review suggests palliative needs may be considerable [12]. In one of the few studies prospectively assessing symptoms in those withdrawing from dialysis, Cohen and colleagues show that a significant minority have distressing symptoms in the last 24 hours, although most deaths were viewed as peaceful by relatives [13,14].

Conservative (non-dialytic) management: Conservative management has only emerged as a specific management option relatively recently, although services are rapidly developing for this group [15]. There has been little evidence about the palliative needs of those managed without dialysis, although this is gradually changing and recent studies are beginning to show that the symptom burden is as high as that of cancer patients [16, 17, 18]. Some preliminary evidence about survival is also emerging, with 1- and 2-year survival (from first reaching stage 5 CKD) of 68% and 47% respectively [19, 20].

Wider evidence on ESRD: There is a rich seam of research evidence about ESRD that can be usefully extrapolated to palliative and end of life care, although only limited indication of this can be provided here. For instance, the psychological and social impacts of ESRD are known to be considerable, with extensive demands on patient and family, and complex transitions to be negotiated [21, 22, 23]. Communication, especially in relation to dialysis decision-making and advance planning, is key [24, 25], yet presents many challenges [26, 27]. Patients mostly want families to be actively involved in communication, but patient and family preferences may differ [28]. Provision of social and family support is likely to improve outcomes [29, 30], but needs particular resources and models of care. These findings suggest that the patient-centred (rather than disease-centred) approach of palliative care, with attention to psychological, social and spiritual (as well as physical) needs may have much to offer patients with ESRD and their families.

Clinical and policy developments: There is growing recognition within nephrology and palliative circles of the needs of these ESRD patients, with recent publication of the first text book on renal supportive care [31], and national recognition of palliative and end-of-life needs in the National Service Framework for Renal Diseases [32] and the Royal College of Physicians report on the Changing Face of Renal Medicine [33]. A renal version of the Liverpool Care Pathway is under development nationally [34], and clinical guidelines on opioid use in ESRD managed without dialysis have been published [35]. As this is a rapidly changing area of clinical and research practice, resources and evidence are likely to continue to evolve quickly.

 

 

References

 

1. http://www.kidney.org/professionals/kdoqi/guidelines_ckd/p4_class_g1.htm Accessed 6 Aug 2007.

 

2. Levey AS, Eckhardt K-U, Tsukamoto Y, Levin A et al. Definition and classification of chronic kidney disease: A position statement from Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO). Kidney International (2005) 67, 2089–2100; doi:10.1111/j.1523-1755.2005.00365.x

3. Heron MP, Smith BL. Deaths: Leading causes for 2003. National Vital Statistics reports; 55 (10). Hyattsville, MD: Center for Health Statistics, 2007.

 

4. Mortality statistics – Review of the Registrar General on Deaths in England & Wales, 2004. Series DH1 no 37. Office for National Statistics, London, UK. 2006.

 

5. Ansell D, Feest T, Rao R, Williams A, Winearls C. UK Renal Registry Report 2005. Bristol: UK Renal Registry; 2006.

 

6. U.S. Renal Data System, USRDS 2006 Annual Data Report: Atlas of End-Stage Renal Disease in the United States, National Institutes of Health, National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, Bethesda, MD, 2006.

 

7. El Nahas AM, Bello AK. Chronic kidney disease: the global challenge. The Lancet, 2005; 365: 331-40.

 

8. Davison, S. N. Pain in Hemodialysis Patients: Prevalence, Cause, Severity, and Management. American Journal of Kidney Diseases; 2003: 42(6): 1239-47.

 

9. Murtagh FEM, Addington-Hall J, Higginson IJ. The prevalence of symptoms in end-stage renal disease: a systematic review. Advances in Chronic Kidney Disease, 2007 January; 14 (1): 82-99.

 

10. Germain, M.J, Cohen LM, Davison SN. Withholding and withdrawal from dialysis: what we know about how our patients die. Semin.Dial. 20.3 (2007): 195-99.

 

11. Murtagh FEM, Cohen LM, Germain M. Dialysis Discontinuation: Quo Vadis? Advances in Chronic Kidney Disease, 2007 (in press).

 

12. Chater, S., et al. "Withdrawal from dialysis: a palliative care perspective." Clin.Nephrol. 66.5 (2006): 364-72.

 

13. Cohen, L. M., et al. "Dying well after discontinuing the life-support treatment of dialysis." Archives of Internal Medicine. 160.16 (2000): 2513-18.

 

14. Cohen, L. M., et al. "Dialysis discontinuation and palliative care." American Journal of Kidney Diseases. 36.1 (2000): 140-44.

16. Murtagh  FEM, Addington-Hall J, Edmonds PM, Donohoe P, Carey I, Jenkins KJ, Higginson IJ. Symptoms in advanced renal disease – a cross-sectional survey of symptom prevalence in stage 5 chronic kidney disease managed without dialysis. Journal of Palliative Medicine, 2007; 10 (6): (in press)

19. Smith C, Silva-Gane M, Chandna S, Warwicker P, Greenwood R, Farrington K. Choosing not to dialyse: evaluation of planned non-dialytic management in a cohort of patients with end-stage renal failure. Nephron Clinical Practice 2003;95 (2):c40-c46.

21. Devins GM, Binik YM, Hutchinson TA, Hollomby DJ, Barre PE, Guttmann RD. The emotional impact of end-stage renal disease: importance of patients' perception of intrusiveness and control. International Journal of Psychiatry in Medicine 1983;13(4):327-43.
