document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Introduction to policy in palliative and supportive care
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,POLICY,SERVICE PROVISION,UNITED KINGDOM,INTERNATIONAL]]>
document.body:
111-1Introduction to policy in palliative and supportive care

1. Definition of topic

Policy is important and should be considered by all involved in the commissioning, provision and delivery of all aspects of palliative and supportive care. Although sometimes it may be difficult to see its relevance to practice, clear examples of the need to keep abreast of policy to inform practice and service development are evident. For example, when considering the recent White Paper Our Health, Our Care, Our Say (England, 2006) this is already leading to the development of an end of life care strategy which will directly affect all involved in palliative care by the formation of end of life care networks, rapid response teams and hospice at home services.

 

By the very nature of the field, policy development in palliative and supportive care involves a range of stakeholders from the voluntary sector, NHS, primary care, secondary care, care homes, housing, social care, users, carers. It is important that all of these stakeholders are involved in policy development so policy can truly reflect the complex nature of palliative and supportive care planning, delivery, commissioning and provision.

 

There are different types of policy documents but typically they are likely to do one or both of the following:

  • set out an agreed formal policy position
  • analyse data and points of view and put forward proposals

Examples of the former would be National Service Frameworks or guidance from the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence. These set out the policy of statutory organisations and, as such, are the basis for practice and service development in public services.

 

Examples of the latter would include documents from think tanks or pressure groups such as the Kings Fund, DEMOS or the National Council for Palliative Care. These documents are usually intended to influence the development of policy by Government or statutory agencies and may or may not therefore become incorporated into the delivery of public services.

 

Policy documents in relation to palliative care may cover a wide range of issues including:

  • clinical issues
  • organisational issues
  • wider social and demographic issues

Clinical issues relate to practical aspects of how care is delivered, including any protocols or guidance relating to communication, drugs and technologies.

 

Organisational issues include the funding and commissioning of services and co-ordination between service providers. Palliative care is unusual in the extent to which the voluntary sector provides and funds services. This may be one reason why organisational issues generate significant discussion in the palliative care context.

 

Wider social and demographic issues may include the implications of changes in society for the delivery of services. For example this might be the ageing population, the increase in chronic illness and co-morbidity or the implications of cultural difference for service provision.

 

2. Guidance/Evidence available


Guidance:
http://www.library.nhs.uk/palliative/SearchResults.aspx?catID=9096&tabID=288

Evidence:
http://www.library.nhs.uk/palliative/SearchResults.aspx?catID=9096&tabID=289&

 

Further information

The National Council for Palliative Care have a policy unit and policy groups formed of all key stakeholders to develop policy. Updates on all key aspects are available at:

http://www.ncpc.org.uk/policy_unit/index.html

 

Information on the work of the Policy team at Help the Hospices is available at:

http://www.helpthehospices.org.uk/policy/index.asp 

 

References

Dept of Health: Publications policy and guidance.

'Reference' section of the Library: http://www.library.nhs.uk/palliative/SearchResults.aspx?catID=9096&tabID=290

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Introduction to the 19 Jan 2009 AEU
document.publisher: National Library for Health: Supportive and Palliative Care Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,FAMILIES & CARERS,COMMUNICATION ISSUES]]>
document.body:
111-1Introduction to the 19 Jan 2009 AEU

Back to the CONTENTS PAGE

 

The first Annual Evidence Update on 'Patient and carer involvement in chronic disease' was published on 19 January 2009. It collects together the best current knowledge on self care in chronic disease management.  Key resources from a small sample of chronic conditions, together with the End of Life Care setting are placed within the general theme of user involvement in health services.

User involvement in healthcare has become firmly established in the UK and has been actively encouraged by the Department of Health in the care of longterm conditions.  The NICE guidance (2004) on supportive and palliative care for adults with cancer helpfully distinguished between “user involvement in decision-making about a person’s own treatment or care and participation in the development of services for all patients.”  The guidance further clarified –

 

“User involvement means enabling people who use – or may use – services to voice their experiences and influence broader care.

They may participate in:

  • service planning to ensure that services meet the needs of patients and carers
  • the evaluation of services
  • mutual support with other patients and carers through selfhelp and support groups and individual peer-to-peer support schemes.”

The NICE guidance identified the following objectives of user involvement with respect to supportive and palliative care in cancer –

 

“The objectives are to ensure that:

  • user involvement is valued as an integral aspect of service planning and delivery
  • the views of patients and carers are obtained, taken into account and acted upon by those developing and evaluating cancer services
  • patient and carer led activity is recognised and supported as an integral part of cancer care.”

One area where user involvement has been very active is in cancer research, with the importance attached to the National Cancer Research Network (NCRN) Consumer Liaison Group and its representatives in each of the disease-site research groups. In many of the UK cancer networks there are consumer research panels, and probably the well-established one is in North Trent.

However, supportive and palliative care now extends far beyond cancer and embraces the patients and families coping with many longterm and progressive conditions including chronic respiratory, cardiac and renal disease; longterm fatal neurological conditions; and most recently, supportive care has acquired a role in the aftercare of patients who are ‘survivors’ of cancer, but have longterm ‘late effects’ of the disease and its treatments. [See the NHS Cancer Surviorship website and Macmillan's Survivorship pages]

In this year’s Annual Evidence Update we are focusing on just a few of these areas but in future updates we will expand the scope and also, given the spurt in research in user involvement, we will bring out evidence for the place of user involvement from clinical studies.

 

 

Back to the CONTENTS PAGE

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Kidney disease outcomes quality initiative
document.publisher: National Kidney Foundation (USA)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,SERVICE PROVISION,AUDIT,OUTCOME MEASURES,SERVICE DEVELOPMENT,RENAL DISEASES,ACCESS TO PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
The Kidney Disease Outcomes Quality Initiative or KDOQI provides evidence-based clinical practice guidelines developed by volunteer physicians and health care providers for all stages of chronic kidney disease and related complications, from diagnosis to monitoring and management.

KDOQI expands the Dialysis Outcomes Quality Initiative or DOQI, a project begun by the US National Kidney Foundation in 1997 and recognized throughout the world for improving the care of dialysis patients.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Knowledge outline: Breakthrough pain in cancer patients
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PAIN MANAGEMENT,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CANCER,CONDITIONS]]>
document.body:
111-1Knowledge outline: Breakthrough pain in cancer patients

Definition

Breakthrough pain has been defined as “an abrupt, short lived and intense pain that ‘breaks through’ the around the clock analgesia that controls persistent pain.” (Bennett, 2005) It is usually related to background pain and is typically of rapid onset, severe in intensity, and generally self-limiting with an average duration of 30 minutes (Zeppetella 2003).

Three types of breakthrough pain are described:

  1. Incident pain: commonest and related to movement/coughing
  2. Idiopathic/ spontaneous pain: no identifiable cause; lasts longer than incident pain
  3. End of dose failure: prior to scheduled dose of analgesia; gradual onset.  Often not regarded as true breakthrough pain (Payne, 2007)

Prevalence in patients with cancer has been reported as 65% (Caraceni, 1999), but it affects non-cancer and cancer patients. It is a poor prognostic indicator (Bruera 1995) and can have adverse effects such as decreased functioning, increased anxiety and depression and longer stays in hospital. (Portenoy 1999, Fortner 2002)

 

Management

Portenoy suggested 3 principles for management: implementing primary therapies (surgery, radiotherapy, chemotherapy), optimising around the clock medication, specific pharmacological interventions (Portenoy, 1997). Pharmacological management should be tailored to the type of breakthrough pain:

  1. Incident pain: pre-emptive use of a short acting opioid 30 minutes before activity (McCarberg, 2007). The current European Association for Palliative Care (EAPC) recommendation is to use the same as the four-hourly dose of normal-release morphine (approximately 16% of the daily dose) when necessary (Hanks 2001). A recent Cochrane review of opioids for breakthrough pain concluded that it is appropriate to titrate the dose of rescue medication (Zeppetella, 2006)
  2. Idiopathic/ spontaneous: peak intensity can occur in 3-5 minutes and episodes usually last for under 30 minutes, so analgesics with a delayed onset are not helpful for this type of pain. A recent Cochrane review found that oral transmucosal fentanyl citrate (OTFC) was shown to be “an effective treatment for breakthrough pain. When compared to placebo and morphine, participants gave lower pain intensity scores and higher pain relief scores for OTFC at all time points. Global assessment scores also favoured OTFC”. (Zepetella, 2006)
  3. End of dose failure: alter the around the clock medication to increase the dose or shorten the dosing interval ( McCarberg, 2007)

More than 4 episodes of breakthrough pain a day should suggest that the current management of the baseline/persistent pain should be reviewed (Coluzzi, 1998).

Non-pharmacological management includes physical therapy, education about limitations and exacerbating factors and patient counselling to reduce anxiety (McCarberg, 2007).


 

References

Bennet, D.  Consensus panel recommendations for the assessment and management of breakthrough pain. Part 1 assessment. Pharmacy and Therapeutics 2005;30:296-301. [no PubMed abstract]

Bruera E, Scholler T, Wenk R, MacEachern T, Marcellino S, Hanson J, et al. A prospective multi-center assessment of the Edmonton staging system for cancer pain. Journal of Pain Symptom Management 1995;10:348-355. Link to PubMed abstract

Caraceni A, Portenoy RK. An international survey of cancer pain characteristics and syndromes. IASP Task Force on Cancer Pain. International association for the study of pain. Pain 1999; 82:263-74. Link to PubMed abstract

Coluzzi PH. Cancer pain management: newer perspectives on opioids and episodic pain. Am J Hosp Palliat Care. 1998 Jan-Feb;15(1):13-22. Link to PubMed abstract

Coluzzi PH, Schwartzberg L, Conroy JD, Charapata S, Gay M, Busch MA, Chavez J, Ashley J, Lebo D, McCracken M, Portenoy RK. Breakthrough cancer pain: a randomized trial comparing oral transmucosal fentanyl citrate (OTFC) and morphine sulfate immediate release (MSIR). Pain 2001;91(1-2):123-130. Link to PubMed abstract

Fortner BV, Okon TA, Portenoy RK. A survey of pain-related hospitalisations, emergency department visits, and physicians office visits reported by cancer patients with and without history of breakthrough pain. Journal of Pain 2002;3:38-44. Link to PubMed abstract
 
Hanks GW, de Conno F, Cherny N, Hanna M, Kalso E, McQuay HJ, et al. Morphine and alternative opioids in cancer pain: the EAPC recommendations. British Journal of Cancer 2001;84:587-593. Link to PubMed abstract

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Knowledge outline: Mechanisms of pain
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ VISCERAL PAIN,BONE PAIN,NEUROPATHIC PAIN,PAIN MANAGEMENT,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE]]>
document.description: Produced as part of the National Knowledge Week for 'Pain in palliative and supportive care' Apr-May 2007.
document.body:
111-1Knowledge outline: Mechanisms of pain

Nociception is normally transmitted by action potentials along unmyelinated C and thinly myelinated A delta fibres in response to a stimulus at receptors in peripheral nerves. These primary pain neurones end centrally in the superficial lamina of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord where they synapse with the second order neurone. The second order neurone which forms the ascending pathway decussates higher up on its way to relay in the thalamus.

 

Neuroimaging has highlighted several cortical areas critical for different aspects of pain processing. The primary and secondary sensory cortices in the post central gyrus are responsible for the localisation of pain. The amygdala as part of the limbic system convey the emotional response to the stimulus. The anterior cingulate cortex has a role in interpreting the intensity of the input and the pre frontal cortex brings the pain to our consciousness making it a sensation or symptom.

 

Pain has been traditionally divided into nociceptive and neuropathic types, with acute and chronic describing duration rather than the underlying molecular pathophysiology. The entity of “cancer pain” embraces all of these classifications.

 

Peripheral sensitisation is primarily caused by prostanoid and cytokine release at the site of injury. Peripheral nerve sensitivity and synaptic transmission in the dorsal horn are subject to the excitatory influence of sodium and calcium channels. Inhibitory control is mediated via opioid and GABAA receptors, activating potassium and chloride channels respectively.

 

Central sensitisation is the cumulative response to a sequence of events, starting in the dorsal horn synapses, which leads to the well known clinical picture of hyperalgesia and allodynia. Crucial to this process are the NMDA receptor channels and the generation of nitric oxide. Synaptic transmission is also under the influence of inducible COX.

 

It is now clear from both animal and clinical studies that paradoxically opioids, which are heavily used in pain management, can cause hyperalgesia through the same NMDA mechanism. This can explain one of the main limitations of opioids, namely the development of tolerance.

 

Descending pathways from the PAG can modulate dorsal horn activity via serotonergic and noradrenergic mechanisms which may be inhibitory or excitatory. Another emerging inhibitory control is mediated via cannabinoid CB1 receptors.

 

Cancer pain has previously been regarded as “unique” but it is possible to understand it in the light of these recently described molecular mechanisms, which are ultimately mediated by the chronic inflammatory response. Most cancer pain may in fact be regarded as mixed inflammatory/neuropathic, regardless of the actual anatomical lesion. For example, the mechanisms underlying malignant bone pain have recently been elucidated. We now know that the central cortex of the bone is heavily innervated and these nerves are activated at a very early stage of metastatic bone disease.

 

As we further elucidate the mechanisms of pain at molecular, cellular and anatomical levels, we stand to develop more pharmacologically rational treatments with greater efficacy and less toxicity.

 

References

Angst MS, Koppert W, Pahl I, Clark DJ, Schmelz M. Short term infusion of the µ-opioid receptor agonist remifentanil in humans causes hyperalgesia during withdrawal. Pain 2003, vol106; 49-57. Link to PubMed abstract

Apkarian AV, Bushnell MC, Treede RD, Zubieta JK. Human brain mechanisms of pain perception and regulation in health and disease. European Journal of Pain 2005, vol 9; 463-484. Link to PubMed abstract

Chu LF, Clark DJ, Angst MS. Opioid tolerance and hyperalgesia in chronic pain patients after one month of oral morphine therapy: a preliminary prospective study. Journal of Pain 2006, vol 7; 43-48. Link to PubMed abstract

Fields H. State-dependent opioid control of pain. Nature Reviews Neuroscience 2004, vol 5; 565-575. Link to PubMed (no abstract)

Gordon-Williams RM, Dickenson AH. Central neuronal mechanisms in cancer-induced bone pain. Current Opinion in Supportive and Palliative Care 2007, vol 1; 6-10. Link to journal homepage [no PubMed entry yet]

Holdcroft A, Power I. Management of pain. British Medical Journal 2003, vol 326; 635-639. Link to PubMed (no abstract)

Mach DB, Rogers SD, Sabino MC, Luger NM et al. Origins of skeletal pain: sensory and sympathetic innervation of the mouse femur. Neuroscience 2002, vol 113; 155-166. Link to PubMed abstract

Mantyh PW, Clohisy DR, Koltzenburg M, Hunt SP. Molecular mechanisms of cancer pain. Nature Reviews Cancer 2002, vol 2, 201-209. Link to PubMed abstract

Mao J. NMDA and opioid receptors: their interactions in antinociception, tolerance and neuroplasticity. Brain Research Reviews 1999, 30; 289-304. Link to PubMed abstract

Stahl SM. Mechanisms of action of alpha2delta ligands: voltage sensitive calcium channels (VSCC) modulators. Journal of Clinical Psychiatry 2004, vol 65; 1033-1034. Link to PubMed abstract

 

Return to the National Knowledge Week homepage

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Knowledge outline: Medical management of cancer and chronic pain
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CANCER,CONDITIONS,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT,NEUROPATHIC PAIN,BONE PAIN,VISCERAL PAIN,MEDICINES]]>
document.description: Produced for the National Knowledge Week on 'Pain in palliative and supportive care' 30 Apr-6 May 2007
document.body:
111-1Knowledge outline: Medical management of cancer and chronic pain

The optimal control of chronic pain in cancer and many non-malignant diseases relies on the understanding of the underlying pathophysiology and molecular mechanisms involved.  Thus medical management starts with the diagnosis of the cause of the pain by clinical assessment and imaging. 

 

The ideal mode of palliation (symptom control) is removal or minimisation of the cause, ie disease-directed therapies. For example in malignant bone pain we may use surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy and/or bisphosphonates. In infection, antimicrobials or surgical drainage of an abscess could be the first priority.

 

Alongside disease directed therapy, we now have a host of pharmacological and non-pharmacological medical therapies, which should be used on an individual basis depending on the clinical situation.

 

Since 1986 the prevailing model for the management of cancer – and latterly some forms of chronic non-malignant – pain has been the WHO 3-step analgesic ladder.  This guideline was born of a need for a simple, public health tool, especially for developing countries with little access to opioids.  It was not, in the modern sense, evidence-based.  The WHO approach relies heavily on the use of opioids, and in particular, oral morphine – with optional use of so-called ‘adjuvants’.  Several recent pain surveys and critical reviews have shown that in spite of 21 years of the WHO model, unrelieved cancer pain and ‘opiophobia’ is still as prevalent; and the adjuvant drugs are frequently under-employed.

 

Used alone and in high doses, opioids are prone to cause multiple troublesome adverse effects and other problems such as tolerance and hyperalgesia.  The long-term use of opioids for chronic pain has had mixed reception, when toxicities such as endocrine and immune suppression are included.  Indeed, the current trend of ‘opioid switching’ may be, in part, driven by the need to move between incompletely cross-tolerant opioids to minimise their inherent toxicities.

 

We now understand that opioids differ in terms of receptor binding affinities, pharmacokinetics and their physicochemical properties. This means certain opioids will have advantages over others due to differing side-effect profile, routes of administration, development of tolerance, and propensity for immunomodulation.   Modern technologies for administration including transdermal, oral transmucosal and spinal delivery bring advantages in terms of reduced side-effects and/or convenience for many patients.

 

Endogenous and therapeutic opioids exert their powerful analgesic effect primarily by the activation of G-protein coupled receptors on neurones, which open potassium channels to hyperpolarise their membranes.  But these are not the only ‘magic bullets’ to target pain signal transmission.  The ‘adjuvants’ are now shown to work via other neuronal and synaptic receptors and ion channels, which may be as important as the opioid ones. 

 

Thus, voltage-gated calcium channels can be blocked by gabapentin or pregabalin.  Sodium channels, which in turn activate calcium channels, can be blocked by local anaesthetics and older generation anti-epileptics such as carbamazepine.  Other drugs work by modulating noradrenergic and serotonergic transmission and re-uptake, eg tricyclic antidepressants and SNRIs (also tramadol). NSAIDs and COX inhibitors may exert antinociceptic action by dampening down not only peripheral sensitisation of nerve endings but also spinal synaptic transmission.  GABAA receptors and possibly CB1 receptors reduce neuronal excitability, which can be exploited therapeutically by benzodiazepines, alcohol or cannabinoids. 

 

In most forms of chronic pain, post-synaptic NMDA receptors are opened and these cause calcium influx, nitric oxide induction, neuronal excitability and gene expression leading to neuronal plasticity, central sensitisation, hyperalgesia and allodynia.  Specific NMDA channel blockers such as ketamine and dextro-isomers of many opioids, notably methadone, can attenuate these destructive changes.

 

Depending on the pathophysiology, it may therefore make good pharmacological sense to combine analgesics.  Rather than the WHO approach which treats ‘adjuvants’ as optional, there is increasing evidence of the benefit of routinely combining opioids with these other pharmacological agents for synergistic effects, with the prospect of reduced toxicity.  There is even emerging evidence that combining different opioids (with differing receptor binding/modulating properties) may lead to similar advantages.  The concept of multi-drug regimens working simultaneously on different cellular targets is not new, as the modern management of cancer, rheumatoid arthritis or heart failure show.

 

The medical management of pain can use non-pharmacological options, eg hypnosis or distraction therapies which act via the pre frontal cortex to decrease perception/sensation of pain.  Acupuncture may work by causing release of endogenous opioids. 

 

In summary, modern cancer and chronic pain medical management should be multi-modal, using multiple pharmacological and other neuro-modulating approaches, to achieve analgesia with minimal side-effects and maximal patient convenience. 


 

References

Ahmedzai SH. Window of opportunity for pain control in the terminally ill. Lancet. 2001 Apr 28;357(9265):1304-5. Link to PubMed [no abstract]

Ahmedzai SH, Boland J.  The total challenge of cancer pain in supportive and palliative care. Current Opinion in Supportive and Palliative Care 2007; 1: 3-5. Link to full text [no PubMed entry yet]

Ballantyne JC, Mao J. Opioid Therapy for Chronic Pain. N Engl J Med 2003;349:1943-53. Link to PubMed [no abstract]

Bell RF, Wisløff T, Eccleston C and Kalso E. Controlled clinical trials in cancer pain. How controlled should they be? A qualitative systematic review. British Journal of Cancer 2006. Link to PubMed abstract

British Pain Society. Recommendations for the appropriate use of opioids in persistent non-cancer pain. The Pain Society 2004. Link here

Clark AJ, Ahmedzai SH, Allan LG, Camacho F, et al. Efficacy and safety of transdermal fentanyl and sustained-release oral morphine in patients with cancer and chronic non-cancer pain. Curr Med Res Opin. 2004 Sep;20(9):1419-28. Link to PubMed abstract

Davies PS, Galer BS. Review of lidocaine patch 5% studies in the treatment of postherpetic neuralgia. Drugs 2004; 64 (9): 937-947. Link to PubMed abstract

Davis MP. What is new in neuropathic pain? Support Care Cancer 2007. Link to PubMed abstract

Ferreira SL, Kimura M, Teixeira MJ. The WHO analgesic ladder for cancer pain control, twenty years of use. How much pain relief does one get from using it? Support Care Cancer (2006) 14: 1086–1093. Link to journal homepage [no PubMed entry yet]

Finnerup NB, Ottob M, McQuay H, Jensen TS, Sindrup SH.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Knowledge outline: Pain in HIV disease
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,INFECTIOUS DISEASES,PAIN MANAGEMENT,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,VISCERAL PAIN,BONE PAIN,NEUROPATHIC PAIN,HIV/AIDS]]>
document.body:
111-1Knowledge outline: Pain in HIV disease

Mechanisms

HIV disease has been transformed from a uniformly fatal illness to that of a chronic illness with antiretroviral therapy.  Because of this, peripheral neuropathies have become the most common neurological complications in HIV infection. They may be caused by the HIV itself or by its treatment and may in turn limit future treatment options.

 

The commonest forms of HIV-associated neuropathies (HIV-N) are the distal sensory polyneuropathies (DSP) and antiretroviral toxic neuropathies (ATN).  These are disorders characterized mostly by sensory symptoms that include spontaneous or evoked pain that follow a subacute or chronic course. Combined use of dideoxynucleosides  and stavudine (d4T) lead to so called d-type neuropathies which, in association with immune-mediated mechanisms triggered by HIV infection, are critical to the development of distal sensory polyneuropathy.

 

The neuropathy which HIV itself can cause is a slowly progressive painful neuropathy, whereas the neuropathy in patients receiving nucleoside analog reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) therapy (AZT, ddC, ddI, and d4T) is a distal symmetric small fibre axonal neuropathy that has a sudden onset of intense burning discomfort in both feet, sparing the hands.  NRTIs are associated with a three-fold increase in peripheral neuropathy in AIDS patients. They start at about the 10th week of treatment, and reach severe intensity over a period of days. This is an important source of morbidity in HIV-infected individuals, as the severely debilitating side-effect may force abbreviation or even discontinuation of NRTI therapy

 

Mechanisms of toxic and metabolic peripheral neuropathy are usually due to second messenger signaling pathways (i.e. protein kinase A, protein kinase C, extracellular signal-regulated kinases or nitric oxide). However nucleoside analogues principally interfere with Ca 2+, caspase signaling and mitochondrial electron transport inducing mitochondrial toxicity (rather than the second messenger signaling pathways), with an enhanced risk with pre-existing mitochondrial defects.  Newer nucleoside analogues with less interaction with the DNA polymerase may have reduced impact on peripheral nerves and may therefore be associated with less peripheral neuropathy

 

Chemokines and their receptors are expressed by neurons and glia throughout the nervous system; they have a variety of roles in addition to their immune function, producing a number of effects on synaptic transmission and on neuronal survival.  One of the mechanisms of HIV induced neuropathy is due to gp120 acting directly on nociceptors, activating DRG chemokine receptors which could be responsible for the increased pain sensitivity. Furthermore, an indirect action of gp120 is mediated by spinal microglia and astrocytes also may contribute to the increased pain state. In HIV neuropathy, changes in C-fiber function are restricted to a decrease in conduction velocity changes in ionic currents, especially the voltage gated ion channels.

 

Pathological changes

Markers of neuropathy such as intra-epidermal nerve fibre density from skin biopsies may be valuable tools in the detection and monitoring of distal sensory polyneuropathy. Reduction in fibre density, increased frequency of fibre varicosities and fibre fragmentation are prominent features of skin biopsies from patients with HIV-N.

 

Virological activity is associated with severity of neuropathic pain in distal sensory polyneuropathy. Enhanced viral suppression from antiretroviral agents may actually improve or decrease the frequency of certain types of neuropathy.

 

Pathological features of DSP and ATN include axonal degeneration of long axons in distal regions, loss of unmyelinated fibers, and macrophage infiltration in peripheral nerves and dorsal root ganglia. Marked activation of macrophages as well as the effect of pro-inflammatory cytokines appears to be the main immunopathogenic factors in DSP. General immune activation, which is a feature of HIV-1 infection, also contributes, as do nutritional defects which can lead to small fibre sensory neuropathy. Immune activation in the gut and subsequent development of AIDS enteropathy can lead to nutritional defects that in turn cause sensory neuropathy.  Interference with DNA synthesis and mitochondrial abnormalities produced by nucleoside antiretrovirals have been hypothesized as pathogenic factors involved in ATN.


 
Opportunisitic infections, mostly associated with cytomegalovirus or herpes zoster virus infection can produce characteristic clinical features such as mononeuritis multiple or radiculopathies.

 

Common causes in the post-HAART (highly active antiretroviral therapy) era include peripheral neuropathy in association with isoniazid administration for TB; or co-infection with hepatitis B or C which can induce peripheral neuropathy with or without a vasculitis associated with cryoglobulinaemia.

 

Management

Increased and improved surveillance for HIV-associated neuropathy will allow earlier interventions to improve quality of life and prevent severe toxicities. If the neuropathy is caused by HIV itself, HAART may help.  However, d4T and ddI/ddC should be avoided in the initial regimen.  In established neuropathy, specialist opinion should be sought as to altering the drug regimen.

 

Palliative treatment consists of the reduction of pain with opioids and non-opioid neuro-modulating agents (such as gabapentin and pregabalin). In practice amitriptyline is still often used though it may be less effective.

 

References

Wallace VC, Blackbeard J, Pheby T, Segerdahl AR, et al. Pharmacological, behavioural and mechanistic analysis of HIV-1 gp120 induced painful neuropathy. Pain. 2007 Apr 11; [Epub ahead of print] Link to PubMed abstract

Bhangoo SK, Ren D, Miller RJ, Chan DM, Ripsch MS, Weiss C, McGinnis C, White FA. CXCR4 chemokine receptor signaling mediates pain hypersensitivity in association with antiretroviral toxic neuropathy. Brain Behav Immun. 2007 Feb 8; [Epub ahead of print] Link to PubMed abstract

Joseph EK, Levine JD. Mitochondrial electron transport in models of neuropathic and inflammatory pain. Pain. 2006 Mar;121(1-2):105-14. Link to PubMed abstract

Chen X, Levine JD. Mechanically-evoked C-fiber activity in painful alcohol and AIDS therapy neuropathy in the rat. Mol Pain. 2007 Feb 23;3:5. Link to PubMed abstract

Verma S, Estanislao L, Simpson D.  HIV-associated neuropathic pain: epidemiology, pathophysiology and management. CNS Drugs. 2005;19(4):325-34. Link to PubMed abstract

Kieburtz K, Simpson D, Yiannoutsos C, Max MB et al. A randomized trial of amitriptyline and mexiletine for painful neuropathy in HIV infection. AIDS Clinical Trial Group 242 Protocol Team. Neurology. 1998 Dec;51(6):1682-8. Link to PubMed abstract

Hahn K, Arendt G, Braun JS, von Giesen HJ et al. A placebo-controlled trial of gabapentin for painful HIV-associated sensory neuropathies J Neurol. 2004 Oct;251(10):1260-6. Link to PubMed abstract

 

Return to the National Knowedge Week homepage

]]>

document.title: Knowledge outline: The role of the pain clinic
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION,NEUROPATHIC PAIN,BONE PAIN,VISCERAL PAIN,PAIN CLINICS,PLACE OF CARE]]>
document.description: Produced for the National Knowledge Week on 'Pain in palliative and supportive care' Apr-May 2007.
document.body:
111-1Knowledge outline: The role of the pain clinic

It is predicted that the number of people in Britain over 65 years will have grown by 25% from 9.4 million in 1992 to 11.8 million by 2020. Cancer and non-cancer pain is increasingly prevalent in the over-65 age group, and chronic pain is estimated to occur in 70-90% of patients with advanced cancer.

 

Pain clinics, like palliative medicine, embrace a multidisciplinary ethos, which is a prerequisite for the complex and multi-system nature of symptoms that arise. Both disciplines help to manage the character, distress and impact of persistent pain. Both services aim to manage symptoms rather than effect cure. Recognition of this agenda helps specialists, patients and carers focus positively on symptom management.

 

UK pain clinics have developed, since the early 1960s, from those run by single-handed enthusiasts to the current multi-disciplinary clinics. Pain management specialists, predominantly anaesthetic-trained, work alongside professions allied to health. The synthesis of the diverse knowledge base of the team members coupled with the interventional skills of anaesthetists has created a wide range of effective treatment modalities in palliative pain management.

 

Different models of pain-palliative care services exist in the UK, which are influenced by local service organisation, skill mix and historical referral structures.  Pain clinics range from those which are fully integrated with palliative medicine - assessing patients simultaneously - to clinics with parallel or separate assessment. It is imperative that patient assessment be linked through established communication mechanisms.

 

Patients are often referred to a pain clinic with troublesome drug side-effects, or inadequate pain control.  Frequently however, there are also unspoken fears of addiction, of reporting pain and anxiety because of their implications as well as fear of loss of control. Professionals provide the environment in which these fears and concerns can be shared. They assess and design acceptable treatments in partnership with patients. Communication is vital, patients should be encouraged to share their fears, feel listened-to and enter agreed treatment strategies with their full understanding.

 

Good assessment is the key to understanding the cause of the pain and treatment options. Not all pain in cancer is cancer-related. Some pain may have developed because of the primary disease; others are secondary to treatment; or they may arise through unrelated causes. The character, severity and pattern of symptoms help direct the specialist’s examination, investigations and treatment planning. There is increasing evidence for earlier palliative intervention with strong opioids and invasive procedures.  For example, good evidence supports neurolytic celiac plexus blocks for pancreatic cancer leading to better symptom control with reduced systemic analgesia.

 

Pain clinics aim to be patient-centred, but the structures for dealing with family and carers are less well-developed than in hospice care. The carer’s role is often relegated to that of providing transport and emotional support. However, carers may become a key part of the process - providing reinforcement of advice and information and helping with non-pharmacological strategies of pain control. For them too, the pain clinic offers a calm environment, clear information and a point of reference for future contact.

 

Pain specialists convey rationale for investigations, positive clinical findings, treatment options and possible risks; and help set realistic goals. In partnership with other professionals and with patients and carers, they engender agreed plans, objectives and time frames which build continuity and trust.  Barriers still exist in the evaluation of the adequacy of cancer pain management, patient compliance with medication and awareness of the treatment options that a pain clinic can offer. Education about the advances in pain medicine, the need for earlier and individualised treatment regimes, coupled with improved patient information on medication and side-effects may help towards breaking down these barriers.

 

References

Imperial Cancer Research Fund. The cancer problem. Imperial Cancer Research Fund. 1999.

Portenoy RK, Lesage P. Management of cancer pain. Lancet 1999; 353: 1695-1700. Link to PubMed abstract

Marinangeli F et al. J Pain Sypmtom Manage 2004; 22: 1975-1992. [abstract]

Goudas L, Carr DB, Bloch R, Balk E, Ioannidis JPA, Terrin N, Gialeli-Goudas M, Chew P, Lau J. Management of cancer pain, AHRQ Evidence Reports, No 35. Rockville, MD: AHRQ, 2001. Link to full text

Yan BM, Myers RP. Neurolytic celiac plexus block for pain control in unresectable pancreatic cancer. Am J Gastroenterol. 2007; 102(2): 430-8. Link to PubMed abstract

Russell PB, Aveyard SC, Oxenham DR. An assessment of methods used to evaluate the adequacy of cancer pain management. J Pain Symp Manage. 2006; 32(6): 581-8. Link to PubMed abstract

 

Return to the National Knowledge Week homepage

]]>

document.title: Lymphoedema / chronic oedema – a neglected area?
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SERVICE PROVISION,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,LYMPHOEDEMA,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,HAEMATOLOGIC AND LYMPHATIC DISEASES]]>
document.body:
111-1Lymphoedema / chronic oedema – a neglected area?

Written by Dr Vaughan Keeley, Consultant in Palliative Medicine, Derby Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust.


 

Introduction

Lymphoedema is a chronic incurable condition where there is an accumulation of fluid, fibrosis and fat in the tissues as a result of failure of lymphatic drainage.  It has long been thought to be an uncommon and untreatable problem.  Therefore, until recently, there has been little investment in the development of lymphoedema services (Lymphoedema Framework, 2007) and relatively little research has been carried out into its aetiology and treatment (Williams et al, 2005).

 

Prevalence

A study of chronic oedema in SW London has recently revealed that it is much more common than previously thought with a prevalence, of 1.33/1000 population similar to that of venous leg ulcers (Moffatt et al, 2003).  In addition, prevalence increases with age (5.4 / 1000 in those aged >65 years and 10.3 / 1000 in those >85 years).

 

Lymphoedema or chronic oedema?

Pure lymphoedema can be classified as:
a) Primary  - due to an abnormality of development of the lymphatics.
b) Secondary - where the lymphatics are damaged by an extrinsic process e.g. surgery, radiotherapy, trauma or infection. (International Society of Lymphology, 2003)

 

However, in many clinical situations, the aetiology of the oedema is more complex e.g. in leg oedema arising from immobility in a variety of chronic medical conditions such as neurological weakness, arthritis, respiratory diseases and obesity.  In this situation the oedema is both lymphatic and venous in origin (lymphovenous oedema) due to failure of the muscular pump which normally aids lymphatic and venous flow in mobile individuals.

 

Hence, the term “chronic oedema”, which covers the range of aetiologies and describes oedema of at least 3 months duration, is clinically relevant (Moffatt et al, 2003).

 

New research in primary lymphoedemas

Primary lymphoedemas are relatively uncommon conditions.  They may present at birth or shortly afterwards, with another peak of incidence around puberty but some patients do not develop swelling until later on in life.  The aetiology of primary lymphoedemas is poorly understood but in recent years new discoveries have identified gene mutations in some inherited forms of primary lymphoedema. 

Milroy’s disease, a primary lymphoedema of the lower limbs which presents at or shortly after birth and has an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, has been found to be due to a mutation in the gene for Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor Receptor 3 (VEGFR3) (Karkkainen et al, 2000).  The pathology is thought to be a distal hypoplasia of the lymphatics (Bollinger et al, 1983) and the phenotype of families with this gene mutation is largely confined to these lymphatic abnormalities (Brice at al, 2005).

A rarer form of inherited primary lymphoedema, lymphoedema-distichiasis, characterised by pubertal onset of leg oedema together with a double row of eyelashes (distichiasis), has been found to be due to a mutation in the FOXC2 gene.  (FOXC2 is a transcription factor involved in a variety of developmental pathways) (Fang et al, 2000).  The pathology in this situation seems to be an abnormality in the development of lymphatic (and venous) valves, resulting in reflux (Rosbotham et al, 2000).  Patients with lymphoedema-distichiasis may have other abnormalities including varicose veins, ptosis, congenital heart disease and cleft palate (Brice et al, 2002). 

A better understanding of the pathology of primary lymphoedemas may lead to improved treatments in the future.

 

Conclusions

Lymphoedemas and chronic oedemas comprise a variety of conditions with different aetiologies and pathologies.  Full assessment and diagnosis can facilitate the choice of appropriate treatment (see next section).

 

References

Bollinger A et al (1983).  Aplasia of superficial lymphatic capillaries in hereditary and connatal lymphoedema (Milroy’s disease).  Lymphology 16: 27-30.

Brice G et al (2002).  Analysis of the phenotypic abnormalities in lymphoedema-distichiasis syndrome in 74 patients with FOXC2 mutations or linkage to 16q 24.  J. Med. Genet. 39: 478-483.

Brice G et al (2005).  Milroy disease and the VEGFR-3 mutation phenotype.  J. Medical Genetics 42: 98-102.

Fang J et al (2000).  Mutations in FOXC2 (MFH-1), a forkhead family transcription factor, are responsible for the hereditary lymphoedema-distichiasis syndrome.  Am. J. Hum. Genet. 67: 1382-8.

International Society of Lymphology (2003).  The Diagnosis and Treatment of peripheral lymphoedema: a consensus document.  Lymphology 36: 84-91.

Karkkainen MJ et al (2000).  Missense mutations interfere with VEGFR-3 signalling inn primary lymphoedema.  Nature Genetics 25: 153-9.

Lymphoedema Framework (2007).  Template for Management: developing a lymphoedema service.  London: MEP Ltd.

Moffatt CJ, Franks PJ, Doherty DC et al (2003).  Lymphoedema: an underestimated health problem.  Q J Med 96: 731-738.

Rosbotham JL et al (2000).  Distichiasis-lymphoedema: clinical features, venous function and lymphoscintigraphy.  Br. J. Dermatol. 142: 148-152.

Williams AF, Franks PJ, Moffatt CJ (2005).  Lymphoedema: estimating the size of the problem.  Palliat Med 19: 300-313.

 

]]>

Back to the CONTENTS PAGE

 

The following guidance, papers and reviews were all published within the last 12 months and although they are written primarily for healthcare professionals involved in the care of patients with lymphoedema, they may also be of considerable interest to patients and carers themselves.

 

 

Guidance

 

1. Liposuction for Chronic Lymphoedema

Compression Therapy

Dermatologic Surgery, June 2008, vol./is. 34/6(773-8; discussion 778-9), 1524-4725. Damstra RJ, Brouwer ER, Partsch H. [Link to Pubmed abstract]

Journal of Medical Engineering & Technology, May 2008, vol./is. 32/3(179-88), 0309-1902. Morris RJ. [Link to Pubmed abstract]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Message from Joan Hester, President of the British Pain Society
document.publisher: National Library for Health
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-1Message from Joan Hester, President of the British Pain Society

Welcome to this review of the 2007 Annual Scientific Meeting of the British Pain Society, held in Glasgow.  The scientific programme, organised by Dr Paul Watson, once again gave us the seamless organisation and variety of content we have come to expect.

The British Pain Society is the largest multidisciplinary professional organisation in the field of pain within the UK. Our membership comprises medical pain specialists, nurses, physiotherapists, scientists, psychologists, occupational therapists and other healthcare professionals actively engaged in the diagnosis and treatment of pain and in pain research for the benefit of patients.

The British Pain Society Lecture was given by Professor Henry McQuay, whose infinite originality and clarity of thought, delivered with a modicum of common sense, has inspired and delighted members for many years. 

Professor McQuay is the master of systematic reviews.  What have they told us about managing pain?  They have certainly told us that pain management is difficult; that there are no quick fixes, no easy answers. 

Imaging may in the future teach us that chronic pain is a neurodegenerative disorder; but the power of the empathic healthcare professional in helping the pain sufferer should not be underestimated.

For more information about the British Pain Society and for details of the Annual Scientific Meeting programme in full, visit its website.

 

 

Comment from Specialist Library for Palliative and Supportive Care:


On each of the following days of our National Knowledge Update on Pain, we will feature highlights from the Annual Scientific Meeting. 

Apart from the thought-provoking lecture on systematic reviews by Professor McQuay (Oxford) referred to by Joan Hester above, we will feature keynote lectures on cellular mechanisms of pain memory (Professor Jürgen Sandkühler – Vienna); and the role of microglia in pain (Professor Mike Salter – Ontario). 

Of the many excellent workshops, we have focused on one reviewing current knowledge on mechanisms and management of pain in cancer survivors, with contributions from Dr John Wiliams (London), Dr Bill Macrae (Dundee) and Dr Paul Farquhar-Smith (London). 

We are also delighted to feature the work of the Expert Patients Programme in the field of chronic pain, through their representatives at the conference, Pete Moore and Dianne Wright.

 

Return to the National Knowedge Week homepage

]]>

The inability to recruit and retain subjects for clinical trials has implications for integrity of data, data analysis, success of the project, and the cost of conducting such projects in the future."]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Methodology - National Knowledge Week 22-26 Oct 2007
document.publisher: National Library for Health
document.topics: <![CDATA[ NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES,RESPIRATORY DISEASES,CONDITIONS,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,ALZHEIMER’S DISEASE,LYMPHOEDEMA,MOTOR NEURONE DISEASE,VARIANT CREUTZFELDT-JAKOB DISEASE (VCJD),CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD),SERVICE PROVISION,HAEMATOLOGIC AND LYMPHATIC DISEASES,PARKINSON'S DISEASE,RENAL DISEASES,INFORMATION SERVICES AND LIBRARIES,SERVICE TYPE,HUNTINGTON'S DISEASE,MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS]]>
document.body:
111-1Methodology - National Knowledge Week 22-26 Oct 2007

The main aim of this National Knowledge Week was to highlight the best current palliative and supportive care evidence across several 'non-cancer' topics at once. We also sought to engage as many clinicians and other experts in the development of the Library's resources in these areas as possible. The amount and depth of expert participation in this enterprise - developing the 'community of practice' - is, arguably, just as important as the completed information products themselves. Not least because it is these networks of people who will go on to produce the updated versions in the months and years that follow - be that within NLH or in other knowledge services.

 

For these reasons, we were obviously not able to provide as much detail in each area as we could have done had we been concentrating on a single topic all week. However, we hope that this introduction will be the start of more detailed activity in the Library on each of these topics. The aim is that this would culminate in a more extensive Annual Evidence Update for each topic in 2008.

 

A mix of methods was used in each topic. The development of the Library is a research exercise in itself, so we are always keen to find the best ways to approach the tasks in hand. Different contributors require different amounts of help or advice from the Library's project team.

 

The method used to produce the two pieces by Jason Boland is perhaps nearest to the model of how the National Library for Health is encouraging Library teams to proceed. Here, a clinician works closely with an NLH information specialist (me in this case) to search for (i) a list of systematic reviews in a given topic which have been published in a given time period, and then (ii) provides a critical analysis of those results arriving at a final list of useful good quality resources.  

 

However, other approaches - where contributors proceed largely in their own way with little interference from the project team except for the briefest of directions and a small editorial function - can also produce excellent results. In the real world, clinicians and experts work in their own ways, with their own colleagues and in their own workplaces and networks. We sought to facilitate that rather than being too strict about conforming to a single method.

 

We hope that the exercise was useful in itself and that more experts in the field will be inspired to get involved with the production of Annual Evidence Updates in future. There are many areas we have not yet covered in great detail. The reason for this is often the lack of stimulus from an interested expert in the field. So if you would like to see us cover your area of expertise, do get in touch:

 

You can do this by joining the email discussion list. See this page:

http://www.library.nhs.uk/palliative/Page.aspx?pagename=EMAIL

 

Or you can email me direct:

  • Richard Stevens, Information Specialist

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: National Knowledge Week on pain in palliative and supportive care 2007: Methodology for the Annual Evidence Update
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-1National Knowledge Week on pain in palliative and supportive care 2007: Methodology for the Annual Evidence Update

Search strategy

To find the resources for this Annual Evidence Update, we used the PubMed Clinical Queries filter to find systematic reviews for pain in palliative and supportive care.

We searched for the articles published in the years 2000-2006 inclusive. 2007 literature will be covered in the 2008 Annual Evidence Update.

Our detailed search strategy (in the format returned from PubMed via email) was as follows:

 

Search (palliative[All Fields] OR supportive[All Fields] OR (("hospices"[TIAB] NOT Medline[SB]) OR "hospices"[MeSH Terms] OR ("hospice care"[TIAB] NOT Medline[SB]) OR "hospice care"[MeSH Terms] OR hospice[Text Word]) OR terminal[All Fields]) AND systematic[sb] AND English[lang] AND "humans"[MeSH Terms] AND "pain" [MeSH Terms] Limits: English, Publication Date from 2000 to 2006, Meta-Analysis, Review, Bibliography, Humans 

 

 

Inclusion criteria

An article was included in our list if:

  1. It concerned a topic within the remit of supportive and palliative care.
  2. Its abstract stated explicitly that it was a systematic review, or we judged that it was likely to be one.
  3. It was not an opinion or consensus piece - even when this was from a reputable organisation.
  4. It was the most up to date Cochrane review in PubMed. Previous versions of the same review were not included.

 

Appraisal

The clinical members of the team (Jason Boland and Sam H Ahmedzai) appraised the abstracts of each retireved article to decide whether to include them in this Annual Evidence Update. Richard Stevens designed and carried out the search and other information management tasks.

 

Results

The search produced 93 records. Of these, 37 were included in our list.

 

 

Return to the National Knowledge Week homepage

 

]]>

document.title: National Knowledge Week on pain in palliative and supportive care 2007: Sources of knowledge on pain in palliative and supportive care within the Specialist Library
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-1National Knowledge Week on pain in palliative and supportive care 2007: Sources of knowledge on pain in palliative and supportive care within the Specialist Library

The NHS National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care contains information covering both supportive care and palliative medicine – the diagnosis and management of symptoms irrespective of the aetiology and prognosis, using a patient-centred model of care. The Library includes evidence for both pharmacological and non-pharmacological methods of pain management.

When you select 'Pain Management' in the category tree, your search will return different types of resources which are displayed under five different 'tabs' reflecting the level of evidence. Content is displayed for one tab at at time. Click on each tab to display its contents. Note that there may be more than one page of results. Altogether there are over 180 items listed.

The tabs are as follows:


Guidance and pathways - resources from the Dept of Health/NHS/other central government agencies and other reputable specialist organisations to guide diagnostic and management decisions.

Content here:

http://www.library.nhs.uk/palliative/SearchResults.aspx?catID=9100&tabID=288


 

Evidence – best available systematic reviews and research from well established databases which include a level of quality appraisal such as Cochrane and DARE.

Content here:

http://www.library.nhs.uk/palliative/SearchResults.aspx?catID=9100&tabID=289


 

Reference - websites, expert comment, reports and other resources which may inform and enhance practice/knowledge.

Content here:

http://www.library.nhs.uk/palliative/SearchResults.aspx?catID=9100&tabID=290&

 

 

The following two tabs are under development. If you would like to suggest items for inclusion here, please use the Contact Us form.


Education (this section is in development) - CPD resources include talks/tutorials to aid lifelong professional learning.


Patient information - (this section is in development). 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: NHS Do Once and Share Programme: Assessment of chronic pain in older children and adults – developing an evidence-based standardised set of measures
document.publisher: National LIbrary for Health: Supportive and Palliative Care Specialist Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-1NHS Do Once and Share Programme: Assessment of chronic pain in older children and adults – developing an evidence-based standardised set of measures

Introduction

The Pain Assessment project is part of the NHS Do Once and Share (DOaS) programme which is working to engage and enable clinicians, healthcare providers and patients to share their knowledge, skills and experience in order to:

• ensure the best available knowledge is easily accessible
• minimise duplication and wasted time
• provide an agreed, best practice, national approach to care
• make optimum use of new IT systems and services being delivered by NHS Connecting  for Health.

DOaS tries to facilitate the collaboration between clinicians, patient representatives and a large range of stakeholder groups on this complex subject.  The end result of the DOaS project is a set of recommendations and sample assessment methods for the whole spectrum of pain assessment in this disparate group.

 

Background

There is a plethora of chronic pain assessment methods and scales that are used across a wide range of care settings. Specialist pain scoring systems are used, for example, in cancer service, pain clinics, arthritis care and nursing homes. There are also different tools for children and older people, including those with dementia. Each service uses different measures which can reduce effective communication. There should be some standardisation so that the best evidence-based measures are used consistently across services.

 

Aims

To describe the best practice in the assessment of chronic pain in adults and older children and to make recommendations for a standardised approach for use in the UK National Health Service. The project was part of an NHS programme to engage and enable clinicians, healthcare providers and patients to share their knowledge, skills, and experiences.

 

Methods

A systematic extensive search of the literature was performed. Two national stakeholder events have taken place. The project has sought opinions from a wide range of experts, patient representatives and professional bodies. All key documents and feedback from the events have been posted on the National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care website. An email discussion page was set up to facilitate discussion around this topic.

 

Results

The literature search and its subsequent sifting have yielded a wealth of measurement tools for the assessment of chronic pain in the target populations. The stakeholder events and the email consultation exercise gave the project team much valuable feedback on choice and appropriateness of the tools. The email consultation with stakeholders also generated several strands of robust discourse about the role of holistic pain assessment in people with chronic pain and the appropriate ways of tapping into the global distress and suffering experienced by them.

Resulting from these discourses, we have assembled a model or protocol for holistic chronic pain assessment that provides a strategic framework, which is consistent across the whole spectrum of patients, into which specific measures could be placed according to age group, diagnosis group, cognitive functioning level and other patient or environmental variables.  The proposed protocol consists of three key stages: Detect – Observe – Longterm.  The acronym for this model is DOL, which is the root for the Latin word dolor meaning pain.

 

Conclusions

  • The assessment of chronic pain is complex and clearly requires a wide range of measures.
  • The project has for the first time produced a comprehensive classification and sets of logical recommendations for health and social care professionals, clinicians and researchers.
  • These now need to be widely consulted and incorporated into clinical data management systems.
  • The DOL protocol needs to be tested, audited and validated in clinical settings.
  • Although members of British Pain Society (BPS) worked with the project team during all phases of consultation, it has not officially endorsed this report.
  • It is hoped that specific parts of this project’s report and recommendations will be taken up by the BPS, as part of its ongoing programme of projects, and further developed and delivered for use in the NHS.
  • The final report and all the appendices are available to download from the files area of the Palliative and Supportive  Care Specialist Library:

 http://www.library.nhs.uk/palliative/Page.aspx?pagename=doas

 

Acknowledgements: Helen Hood, Senior Project Manager. Annie McIntosh, Interim Project Manager.

 

The project team

  • Clinical Lead: Sam H Ahmedzai, Professor of Palliative Medicine at the University of Sheffield.
  • Project Manager: Nisar Ahmed, Research Associate, University of Sheffield. Email: n.ahmed@sheffield.ac.uk
  • Information Manager: Richard Stevens, Research Associate, University of Sheffield. Email: r.j.stevens@sheffield.ac.uk
  • Project Secretary: Pauline Hutchinson. Email: spcsg-conferences@sheffield.ac.uk
  • 'Do Once and Share' Programme Senior Project Manager: Helen Hood, Service Implementation, NHS Connecting for Health.
  • Strategic Health Authority Lead: Rose Hand, Head of Clinical Engagement - NPfIT, NHS Yorkshire & The Humber SHA.
  • Annie McIntosh, Senior Consultant, Healthlogic Solutions, was Acting Project Manager until August and continues to support the project in an advisory capacity.

Funding: The project was commissioned by the National Library for Clinical Rules and Tools (NLCRT) through the ‘Do Once and Share’ Programme.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Pain in palliative and supportive care: The next 12 months
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-1Pain in palliative and supportive care: The next 12 months

This article brings to a conclusion the daily series of knowledge outlines, evidence reviews and conference highlights that together formed the first National Knowledge Week on Pain.  In this week from 30 April to 4 May 2007, the Specialist Library for Palliative and Supportive Care has posted up 20 articles, with altogether 147 references from the world literature.  Anyone trying to read all of these could easily spend the next few weeks being totally immersed in a world of pain!  Given that the 37 systematic reviews we featured on Day 1 only, themselves covered hundreds of original research papers, the reader would emerge as a living encyclopaedia of pain mechanisms and management.

 

Clearly the purpose of a National Knowledge Week is not to convert people into ‘walking wikipedia’.  Rather, the aim of these weeks – and of the Specialist Libraries themselves – is to bring into focus, in a handful of webpages, the doorways to knowledge that the internet can provide.  These pages are meant to be dipped into, browsed, and individual papers accessed for detailed information as and when the need occurs.  Since nearly all the references have direct PubMed links to abstracts or whole articles, a curious reader can go from puzzlement to enlightenment in seconds. But a repository of knowledge, such as we have compiled on these webpages, would be out of date within months - such is the speed at which internet-based publishing and systematic reviewing proceeds.  So we cannot afford to keep the Pain section of the Specialist Library for Palliative and Supportive Care static.  We will be regularly appending further articles – systematic reviews, meta-analyses, original research papers, guidelines, consensus documents, educational material and patient information. These webpages representing the National Knowledge Week on Pain will be updated too en bloc, in a year’s time when the accumulated new knowledge is once again sifted, quality-checked and summarised.

 

We hope to witness important developments in the field of pain in palliative and supportive care in the coming year. Our collaboration with the British Pain Society will allow us to bring readers up to the minute news of its SIGs, working groups and the documents they publish.  We await eagerly, for instance, the Cancer Pain document that Jon Raphael describes above. The next BPS Annual Scientific Meeting will be held in Liverpool on 15-18 April 2008.  We will be there again to bring you highlights of the 2008 National Knowledge Week on Pain, which will run in one year’s time.

 

Other conferences which are coming up this year, from which we will bring breaking news of pain research and reviews, include the congresses of the European Association for Palliative Care in Budapest (6-9 June 2007) and the Multinational Association for Supportive Care in Cancer in St Gallen (28-30 June 2007).

 

If there are other conferences or events which present new knowledge or reviews of recent research that you would like us to feature, please contact us about them.  Also, if you know of high quality educational material or patient information on pain – areas in which our Specialist Library is currently weak - then do let us know.

 

We are always looking for colleagues to help us with reviewing of the literature – not only of pain, but the dozens of other categories of knowledge in our taxonomy (see navigation bar to the left of this webpage).  We issue helpers with guidance on how to rate articles and those who contribute, can become part of our team of ‘Specialist Library for Palliative and Supportive Care editors’.

 

We hope you have found this in-depth look at pain in palliative and supportive care to be informative and challenging and – most of all – to tempt you to come back for more!

 

Sam H Ahmedzai
Jason Boland
Richard Stevens
The National Knowledge Week on Pain team

 

We would like to acknowledge our grateful thanks to the following for their original contributions or BPS conference abstracts:

Dr David Dockrell (Sheffield)
Dr Donald Graham (Doncaster)
Dr Paul Farquhar-Smith (London)
Dr Joan Hester (London)
Dr Bill Macrae (Dundee)
Pete Moore (Witham)
Dr Laura McTague (Sheffield)
Prof Henry McQuay (Oxford)
Dr Jon Raphael (London)
Prof Mike Salter (Toronto)
Prof Jürgen Sandkühler (Vienna)
Dr John Williams (London)
Di Wright (Bury St Edmunds)

 

Return to the National Knowledge Week homepage

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Palliative care for motor neurone disease
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ SERVICE PROVISION,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,MOTOR NEURONE DISEASE,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES]]>
document.body:
111-1Palliative care for motor neurone disease

Nigel Sykes FRCP FRCGP, St Christopher's Hospice, London.

 

Background

Motor Neurone Disease/Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (MND/ALS) is the most common degenerative condition of the motor nervous system occurring in adult life. Nonetheless, its incidence of 2 per 100,000 per year means that it is an unfamiliar entity for most healthcare professionals.

 

The disease causes progressive loss of voluntary motor function throughout the body with a mixed picture of flaccidity and spasticity,although the pattern of progression varies. MND/ALS is not, as originally thought, a purely motor nerve condition but in up to about 30% of cases is associated with cognitive impairment that can amount to a fronto-temporal dementia (1), particularly where bulbar weakness has been present at the disease onset (2).

 

MND/ALS is steadily progressive and remains incurable. Overall lifeexpectancy is about three years but is tending gradually to increase. Some 5 to 10% of cases are familial, leaving the vast majority to be idiopathic in origin. The precise mechanism of nerve damage remains elusive, rendering the search for therapies frustrating. Only one drug, riluzole, has so far demonstrated an ability to alter the course of the disease. Riluzole has been approved in the UK by NICE but systematic review evidence indicates that although well tolerated it prolongs survival by only about two months (3) and economic analysis elsewhere has suggested marginal cost-effectiveness (4).

 

User experiences

All treatment for MND/ALS is palliative. Prompt diagnosis and optimal symptom management improves life quality not only for patients but also their relatives, and may increase survival time (5). News of the diagnosis is a devastating blow and the quality of the communication between professionals, patients and families at this time has a lasting effect on subsequent perceptions of care (6). The needs of people affected by MND/ALS and of those close to them extend well beyond the competence of any one profession or discipline, and a recent cross-sectional study has concluded that a multidisciplinary approach to care enhances the provision of aids and appliances and, quite separately, improves MND/ALS patients' quality of life (7).     

 

Symptoms

MND/ALS causes numerous symptoms. It is not always appreciated that 50-70% will have pain, largely related to the effects of immobility. Alongside physiotherapy the use of drugs, including opioids, in accordance with the WHO analgesic guidelines originally developed for cancer has been recommended (8). Spasticity is a specific cause of pain which will respond to a range of muscle relaxants such as baclofen and tizanidine (9), but careful dose adjustment is necessary to avoid impairing mobility by making the limbs too flaccid. Exercise programmes may also help (10).

 

Dysphagia due to bulbar weakness causes distress in eating and additional muscle weakness through impaired nutrition. A gastrostomy placed early (endoscopically or radiologically) can forestall these problems and is associated with lengthened survival.  Early placement is also advisable because the procedure is more hazardous if respiratory function has declined to a FVC under 50% of that expected (11). Together with facial muscle weakness, dysphagia gives rise to drooling. This upsetting symptom usually responds at least partially to an anticholinergic agent, but both irradiation and botulinum toxin injection of the salivary glands have been used successfully in resistant cases.

 

The predominant cause of death in people with MND/ALS is respiratory failure secondary to progressive weakness of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles. Tracheostomy ventilation can prolong life indefinitely to the point of disease progression that leaves patients 'locked in' and unable to communicate. Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) can lengthen survival and improve sleep, breathlessness and overall quality of life (12) but is under-used in the UK. NIPPV is less well tolerated by MND/ALS patients with pronounced bulbar symptoms (13) and cannot sustain adequate ventilation beyond a certain point of muscular weakness.  Whether or not NIPPV has been used, the appropriate use of opioids, sedatives and anti-secretory medication (for instance as set out in the Motor Neurone Disease Association's Breathing Space Kit (14)) means that the frequent media allegation that MNDALS patients 'choke to death' is without foundation (15).

 

References

1. Robinson KM, Lacey SC, Grugan P, Glosser G, Grossman M, McCluskey LF. Cognitive functioning in sporadic amyotrophic lateral sclerosis: A six month longitudinal study. Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery & Psychiatry, 2006; 77:668-670.

2. Gibbons SC, Snowden JS, Thompson JC, Happe F, Richardson A, Neary D. Inferring thought and action in motor neuron disease.
Neuropsychologia, 2007; 45: 1196-1207.

3. Miller RG, Mitchell JD, Lyon M, Moore DH. Riluzole for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis/motor neuron disease. Cochrane Database Systematic Reviews, 2002, no.2, p. CD001447.

4. Messori A, Trippoli S, Becagli P, Zaccara G. Cost effectiveness of riluzole in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. PharmacoEconomics, 1999; 16: 153-163.

5. Andersen PM, Borasio GD, Dengler R, Hardiman O, Kollewe K, Leigh PN, Pradat PF, Silani V, Tomik B. Good practice in the management of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis: clinical guidelines. Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. 2007; 8: 195-213.

6. Hugel H, Grundy N, Rigby S, Young CA. Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. 2006; 7: 161-166.

7. van den Berg JP, Kalmijn S, Lindeman E, Veldink JH, de Visser M, van der Draaff MM, Wokke JH, van den Berg LH. Multidisciplinary ALS care improves quality of life in patients with ALS. Neurology, 2005; 65: 1264-1267.

8. Miller RG, Rosenberg JA, Gelinas DF, Misumoto H, Newman D, Sufit R. Practice parameter: the care of the patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (an evidence-based review): report of the Quality Standards Subcommittee of the American Academy of \neurology: ALS Practice Parameters Task Force. Neurology, 1999; 52: 1311-1323.

9. Andersen PM, Borasio GD, Dengler R, Hardiman O, Kollewe K, Leigh PN, Pradat PF, Silani V, Tomik B. EFNS task force on management of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis: guidelines for diagnosing and clinical care of patients and relatives. European Journal Neurology,2005; 12: 921-938.

10. Ashworth NL, Satkunam LE, Deforge D. Treatment for spasticity in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis/motor neuron disease. Cochrane Database Systematic Reviews, 2006, no.1, p. CD004156.

11. Chio A, Finocchiaro E, Meineri P et al. Safety and factors related to survival after percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy in ALS. Neurology, 1999; 53: 1123-1125.

12. Piepers S, van den Berg JP, Kalmijn S, van der Pol WL, Wokke JH, Lindeman E, van den Berg LH. Effect of non-invasive ventilation on survival, quality of life, respiratory function and cognition: a review of the literature. Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. 2006; 7: 195-200.

13. Lo Coco D, Marchese S, Pesco MC, La Bella V, Piccoli F, Lo Coco A. Non-invasive positive-pressure ventilation in ALS: predictors of tolerance and survival. Neurology, 2006; 67: 761-765.

14. http://www.mndassociation.org/for_professionals/information/breathing_space.html (accessed 17th October 2007).

15. Neudert C, Oliver D, Wasner M, Borasio GD. The course of the terminal phase in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. J Neurology, 2001; 248: 612-616.

 

Key texts

Mitsumoto H, Przedborski S, Gordon PH (eds.). Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. New York: Taylor and Francis, 2006.

Oliver D, Borasio GD, Walsh D (eds.). Palliative Care in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (2nd edition). Oxford: University Press, 2006.

 

 

]]>
