document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Palliative care input and advance decision making in patients with long-term neurological conditions
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES,CONDITIONS,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,MOTOR NEURONE DISEASE,VARIANT CREUTZFELDT-JAKOB DISEASE (VCJD),ALZHEIMER’S DISEASE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION,PARKINSON'S DISEASE,HUNTINGTON'S DISEASE,MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS]]>
document.body:
111-1Palliative care input and advance decision making in patients with long-term neurological conditions

Patients with rapidly progressing and advanced stages of long-term neurological conditions (LTNC) need access to specialist palliative care services at an appropriate time in their illness and in a location near to their homes. Their care needs to address issues of advance planning for end-of-life problems, counselling and psychological support for patients and families, information giving and appropriate reviews of medication and therapies. A new project aims to address some of the needs of these patients in the day care facility of Barnsley Hospice (The Limes). The year long project will receive funding from St. James’s Place Foundation in association with Help the Hospices’ “Care beyond Cancer” programme and will be evaluated.

 

The Limes currently offers day care facilities to a population of 218,062 [1].  The majority of our patients have cancer despite access being open to all on a needs rather than diagnosis basis, although this is gradually changing (6% non cancer in 2005-2006, 16% non cancer in 2006-2007 [2]) .  We are keen to extend access further and have concentrated on working with heart failure specialist nurses locally. This new initiative is specifically aimed at those with neurological conditions. There will be funding for medical input in order to fully assess the patients and have the necessary expertise to manage some problems, which may be unfamiliar to those nurses and allied health professionals trained in palliative care mostly for cancer patients. Of course there will be many symptoms common to all patients faced with a life limiting illness and we hope to show that we can manage these effectively, in collaboration with neurological colleagues. We are hoping to reach patients and their carers with motor neurone disease (MND), progressive supra nuclear palsy (PSP), Huntington’s disease (HD), Parkinson’s disease (PD), progressive forms of multiple sclerosis (MS) and multiple system atrophy (MSA).

 

The need for palliative care in neurological conditions

There is much evidence to support a lack of palliative care input for some of these patients. NICE clinical guidelines on Parkinson’s disease state “The needs in the palliative care stage of Parkinson’s disease are not always identified or satisfied. In later stages of PD there may be a need to withdraw dopaminergic drugs …..and increasing sensitivity to unwanted effects…. . Care needs to be supported by good care planning since many problems can be predicted or avoided with appropriate strategies.” Recommendations include “People with PD and their carers should be given the opportunity to discuss end-of-life issues with appropriate healthcare professionals.” [3]

 

The National Service Framework for Long-term Conditions points out the relevance: “People of all ages who are in the advanced stages of long-term neurological conditions may need specialised palliative care services. Palliative care services take a whole-person centred approach, respect patient autonomy and favour open and sensitive communication. They can also support a person’s family and carers in bereavement.” [4]

 

A postal survey of consultants working in the fields of neurology, rehabilitation and palliative medicine has explored the interface between the three specialities and highlighted the need for more collaborative working. Although response rates to the survey were low, it demonstrated that 86% of palliative medicine consultants, 68% of neurologists and 72% of rehabilitation consultants perceived gaps in the provision of palliative care services for people with LTNC. Co-ordination between the three areas was also lacking. Commenting on the survey, the authors conclude “There are many exciting opportunities for these three specialities to work together and by doing so to learn from each other in order to improve the experience of patients and their families who live out their lives with a long-term neurological condition”. [5], [6]

 

The National Council for Palliative Care has established a Neurological Conditions Policy Group to identify the palliative care needs of people with LTNCs, map and assess current provision and identify good practice and service models. The group first met in 2005 and the learning to date has just been published [7].  The group has amassed a great deal of information and now intends to be involved in training and to continue to inform and influence the implementation of the End of Life Care Strategy. The key message is about collaborative working between palliative care and other specialists and working alongside primary care.

 

Advance care planning in LTNCs

Advance care planning (ACP) does not only include advance decisions about refusal of treatment in anticipation of a time when capacity is lost; it encompasses discussions about preferred place of care, particular personal concerns and wishes, appointment of a lasting power of attorney, artificial hydration and nutrition, resuscitation and hospital admissions. It will inevitably lead to questions about prognosis and likely symptoms at the end of life. Time is needed time to explore fears and address psychological, social and spiritual aspects of the illness. Personal discussions with specialist nurses (working with MND, PSP, HD and PD patients and carers) indicate that there is a great deal of awareness about these issues and a willingness to engage in relevant conversations but a lack of structure to this and often a lack of time or an appropriate quiet environment. The opportunity to use a day hospice environment to specifically address the issues, then document and share them with the other health care professionals concerned will be of great benefit to some patients and carers. An introduction to these ideas and to the hospice itself could occur at any time in the patient’s illness, right from diagnosis. The timing will be very individual and patient or carer centred rather than being dictated by the stage of the disease or prognosis.

 

The aims of ACP include the increase of patient control at the end of life, better use of palliative care and an increased likelihood that death will occur in the place of choice. It should also improve communication within families and take away some of the burden a family feels when having to make decisions at a time of incapacity. Not everyone facing a life limiting illness will wish to consider such discussions and the amount of control and decision making will be very individual. The new Mental Capacity Act has raised the profile of some of these issues in the public arena recently, but there is still a lack of open discussion about death and dying in the United Kingdom. A very useful guide to ACP for health and social care staff is available to download on the NHS end of life care website [8].

 

There appears to be more general acceptability and research evidence on the use of ACP in North America. A study of 47 bereaved family caregivers of patients with Parkinson’s disease in Oregon demonstrated that difficulty in communication was rated more troublesome by them than difficulties with physical problems (such as eating). 83% of carers recognised the goal of care was comfort in the last month of life, rather than extending life. 48% of the patients were described as unable to make any decisions in the last four weeks. 87% had a health care proxy and 92% had a living will. Pain was very prevalent and perceived as under treated, especially in the 47% not receiving hospice care [9]. This highlights the high prevalence of some form of advance planning in but also demonstrates the need for effective palliative care interventions in PD despite this. A more comprehensive and collaborative approach is needed.

 

There is an excellent discussion of palliative care in Parkinson’s disease in a paper by Lisette Bunting-Perry in the Journal of Neuroscience Nursing. A model for individual patient care is examined from diagnosis to bereavement and there is a much emphasis on advance care planning. She states “Advance care planning is the cornerstone of palliative care. The patient's ability to achieve autonomy in the context of a chronic, progressive neurologic disease is paramount in developing a longitudinal care plan. ACP is a collaborative, continuous process that starts at the time of diagnosis and continues throughout the course of chronic disease. Healthcare providers frequently struggle to determine when to initiate discussions about ACP out of concern for implying that the patient is at the end of life. The ACP process spans the continuum of care for the patient with early, moderate, and advanced PD”. [10]

 

Overcoming professionals’ reluctance to initiate end of life discussions has long been a problem. Palliative care has always encompassed this area but it can appear more difficult when approaching those with a LTNC such as PD or HD, rather than those with a more predictable illness trajectory such as cancer or MND. An advance care planning interview schedule was developed by a team from Royal Free and University College Medical School in London and its acceptability was qualitatively studied.  Twenty two people (patients and carers) were interviewed about the acceptability and structure of the schedule. It was clear that although some had to “face up to things they wouldn’t otherwise discuss”; others acknowledged these issues were there at the back of their minds. A further phase II randomised trial of offering ACP has been undertaken.

 

As in all aspects of patient care, an individual approach is essential. By carefully collaborating with the general practitioners, neurologists, specialist nurses and therapists who provide the care for patients with long-term neurological conditions in Barnsley, we hope to be able to offer a facility for advance care planning and increase our outreach to non cancer patients in general as a result. Similar approaches are being followed in other areas. More information on the acceptability of this approach and the impact on the outcomes of patient care in this country are needed.

 

References

1. ONS Census 2001.

2. Minimum Data Set Project, National Council for Palliative Care  National Institute for Clinical Excellence. Clinical Guidance: Parkinson's disease: diagnosis and management in primary and secondary care. NICE June 2006.

3. Department of Health. The National Service Framework for Long-term Conditions. DH: 2005.

4.Turner-Stokes L, Sykes N, Silber E, Khatri A, Sutton L and Young E. From diagnosis to death: exploring the interface between neurology, rehabilitation and palliative care in managing people with long-term neurological conditions. Clinical Medicine 2007;7:2.

5. The National Council for Palliative Care: National Survey: Neurological Conditions. NCPC June 2006.

6. The National Council for Palliative Care: Addressing Palliative Care for People with Neurological Conditions. NCPC October 2007.

7. Department of Health. Advance Care Planning: A guide for Health and Social Care Staff. DH: February 2007. www.endoflifecare.nhs.uk

8. Goy E, Carter J, Ganzini L. Parkinson’s disease at the end of life: caregiver perspectives. Neurology 7 Aug 2007; 69 (6): 611-2.

9. Bunting-Perry L. Palliative Care in Parkinson ’s Disease: Implications for Neuroscience Nursing. Journal of Neuroscience Nursing. April 2006; 38 (2):106-113.

10. Barnes K, Jones L, Tookman A, King M: Acceptability of an advance care planning interview schedule: a focus study group. Palliative Medicine 2007; 21: 23-28.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Patient and carer involvement in End of Life Care: A literature review
document.publisher: National Library for Health: Supportive and Palliative Care Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,FAMILIES & CARERS,DEATH,COMMUNICATION ISSUES,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-1Patient and carer involvement in End of Life Care: A literature review

Back to the CONTENTS PAGE

 

The literature review used selected terms considered pertinent to user involvement. Initially a search in both Cinahl and Medline was conducted and was limited to the years 2005-2008 (see details below). A scoping study had previously captured relevant material up to the end of 2004 (Payne et al) The search was further narrowed by type of publication (slightly different depending on the subject headings used in each database but included meta analysis, review, clinical trials, randomised control trials and systematic reviews). These terms were combined with appropriate terms related to palliative and end of life care. This was conducted on the NLH interface.

Cochrane and EBM reviews were searched using the Ovid interface and user involvement and consumer participation were used as keywords. In addition the evidence section of the NLH specialist library was searched to provide information on documents that could provide a view of the subject on a broader basis. Material relevant to the broader area of citizenship involvement were also found in this library. The catalogue of the library at St Christopher’s Hospice was also searched. 

David Oliviere (DO) compiled a separate short annotated reference list of particular relevance to his work in user involvement. This is mainly material that could be elusive   in the health care database search as it includes book chapters and books and policy documents.  These are included in a separate list of references.

Beyond DO’s reference list, Denise Brady (DB) selected material likely to be of interest to the health professional involved in user involvement from the searches described above and, DO, in turn, selected material that he considered might be useful  for palliative care health professionals. He has incorporated some of this material in the following list of references. The following are his comments and his very brief selection from the literature search:

This literature search underlines the fact that user involvement is a term that can be interpreted in many ways. Themes arising from the literature review included the following: discussion of users as co-researchers (eg Gysels M et al 2008, Perkins P, et al 2007); Wright DN et al 2006); patient satisfaction (eg Brumley R et al 2007);  involvement in communication about prognosis  towards the end of life (eg Clayton JM et al 2007); treatment decisions near the end of life (Schofield P et al 2006); narratives of users’ experiences (eg Bingley et al  2006, Harris FM et al 2008 ); patient information (eg Johnson et al 2008)  as well as user involvement (which we have mainly interpreted as service development issues).

The literature review did not extend to particular illnesses though one item on motor neurone disease indicated how users would wish to be involved in service development and one research article provided insights on the benefits to both users and health professionals on user involvement (Down et al 2005 and Fudge et al 2008).  Another study of colon cancer patients indicated that involving users in the provision of written information for patients was helpful to all users (Carney L et al 2006). A further  document indicated how users can be involved in guideline development (NICE 2004).  These provide further theoretical and clinical knowledge on how user involvement could be developed in palliative care services.

In addition, user involvement in palliative care can be contextualised by examining literature in social care where it has its roots eg in the mental health and disability fields (Carr 2004, Doel et al 2007, Shaping our lives et al 2007). 

 

  • Bingley AF, McDermott E, Thomas C, Payne S, Seymour JE, Clark D (2006) Making sense of dying: a review of narratives written since 1950 by people facing death from cancer and other diseases. Palliative Medicine 20(3):183-195.

 

  • Brumley R, Enguidanos S, Jamison P, Seitz R, Morgenstern N, Saito S, McIlwane J, Hillary K, Gonzalez J (2007)  Increased satisfaction with care and lower costs: results of a randomized trial of in-home palliative care Journal of the American Geriatrics Society 55(7): 993-1000.

 

  • Carney L, Jones L,  Braddon F, Pullyblank AM, Dixon A (2006)  A colorectal cancer patient focus group develops an information package. Annals of the Royal College of Surgeons  88(5):447-449.

 

  • Carr S (2004) Has service user participation made a difference to social care services? London: Social Care Institute for Excellence
    http://www.scie.org.uk/publications/positionpapers/pp03.pdf (accessed 8/1/09).

 

  • Clayton JM, Butow PN, Tattersall MHN, Devine RJ, Simpson JM, Aggarwal G, Clark KJ, Currow DC, Elliott LM, Lacey J, Lee PG , Noel MA (2007) Randomized controlled trial of a prompt list to help advanced cancer patients and their caregivers to ask questions about prognosis and end-of-life care
    Journal of Clinical Oncology 25(6):715-723.

 

  • Doel M, Carrol C, Chambers E, Cooke J, Hollows A, Laurie  L, Maskrey L, Nancarrow S. (2007) Participation: finding what difference it makes. Social Care Institute for Excellence.
    http://www.scie.org.uk/publications/resourceguides/rg07/files/rg07.pdf
    (accessed 10/1/08).

 

  • Down K, Hughes R, Sinha A, Higginson IJ, Leigh PN (2005) Involving users in shaping motor neurone disease services. York: Jospeh Rowntree Foundation.

 

  • Fudge N, Wolfe CDA, McKevitt, C (2008) Assessing the promise of user involvement in health service development: ethnographic study BMJ 336 (7639 Feb 9):313-317.

 

  • Gysels M, Shipman C, Higginson IJ (2008) “I will do it if it will help others” motivations among patients taking part in qualitative studies in palliative care. Journal of Pain and Symptom Management 35(4): 347-355.

 

  • Harris FM, Kendall M, Bentley A, Maguire R, Worth A, Murray S, Boyd K, Brown D, Kearney N, Sheikh A (2008) Researching experiences of terminal cancer: a systematic review of methodological issues and approaches European Journal of Cancer Care 17(4): 377-386.

 

  • Johnson HM, Nelson A (2008). The acceptability of an information leaflet explaining cardiopulmonary resuscitation policy in the hospice setting: a qualitative study exploring patients’ views. Palliative Medicine  22(5): 647-652.

 

  • NICE (Patient Involvement Unit), Jarrett L  (2004) A report on a study to evaluate patient/carer membership of the first NICE guideline development groups. London: NICE. 
    http://www.nice.org.uk/niceMedia/pdf/PIU_Evaluation_report_270704.pdf
    (accessed 7/1/09).

 

  • Payne, S, Gott, M, Small, N, Oliviere, D, Sargeant, A, Young, E (2005) User involvement in palliative care: a scoping study. Sheffield: University of Sheffield.

 

  • Perkins P, Barclay S, Booth S (2007) What are patients’ priorities for palliative care research? Focus group study. Palliative Medicine 21(3):219-225.

 

  • Schofield P, Carey M, Love A, Nehill C, Wein S (2006) 'Would you like to talk about your future treatment options'? Discussing the transition from curative cancer treatment to palliative care Palliative Medicine 20(4): 397-406.

 

  • Shaping Our Lives, National Centre for Independent Living and University of Leeds Centre for Disability Studies (2007). Developing social care: service users driving culture change
    London: SCIE.

http://www.scie.org.uk/publications/knowledgereviews/kr17.pdf
(accessed 8/1/09).

 

  • Wright DN, Hopkinson JB, Corner JL, Foster CL (2006) How to involve cancer patients at the end of life as co-researchers. PalliatIve Medicine 20(8): 821-827.

 

CINAHL SEARCH

(palliative AND care).ti,ab
exp PALLIATIVE CARE/
(terminal AND care).ti,ab
TERMINAL CARE/ OR HOSPICE CARE/
(terminally AND ill).ti,ab

hospices.ti,ab

(end AND of AND life).ti,ab

10 [Limit to: Publication Year 2005-2008]

(patient AND education).ti,ab

(patient AND information).ti,ab

MEDLINE SEARCH

8.exp HOSPICES/
9.(end AND of AND life).ti,ab
10.1 OR 2 OR 3 OR 4 OR 5 OR 6 OR 7 OR 8 OR 9
11. 10 [Limit to: Publication Year 2005-2008
12.(user AND involvement).ti,ab
13.exp CONSUMER PARTICIPATION/ OR exp PATIENT PARTICIPATION/
14.PATIENT EDUCATION AS TOPIC/
15.12 or 13 or 14
16. 15 AND 29 [Limit to: Publication Year 2005-2008]
17. 16 [Limit to: (Publication Types Clinical Trial, All or Controlled Clinical Trial or Meta Analysis or Randomized Controlled Trial or Review) and Publication Year 2005-2008]

(Items in capitals are subject headings/MESH headings)

 

Denise Brady (Librarian), David Oliviere (Director of Education and Training), Education Centre, St Christopher’s Hospice

January 2008

 

Back to the CONTENTS PAGE

document.title: Plasma concentration profiles of ketamine and norketamine after administration of various ketamine preparations to healthy Japanese volunteers
document.publisher: John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PAIN MANAGEMENT,NEUROPATHIC PAIN,MEDICINES]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ "Ketamine is known to provide analgesic effects without an anesthetic when administered in a low dose. We previously reported that a tablet containing ketamine had analgesic effects in patients with neuropathic pain. In the present study, we compared the plasma concentration profiles of the enantiomers of ketamine and its active metabolite, norketamine, up to 8 h after the administration of 20 mg of ketamine by injection, after the administration of two tablets containing 25 mg of ketamine, after the administration of two sublingual tablets containing 25 mg of ketamine, after the insertion of a suppository containing 50 mg of ketamine, and after the application of a nasal spray containing 25 mg of ketamine to three healthy volunteers."]]>

document.title: Promoting excellence: end-stage renal disease workgroup recommendations to the field
document.publisher: Robert Wood Johnson Foundation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,FAMILIES & CARERS,SERVICE PROVISION,AUDIT,OUTCOME MEASURES,SERVICE DEVELOPMENT,RENAL DISEASES,QUALITY OF LIFE,ACCESS TO PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE SERVICES]]>
document.body:
111-1Promoting excellence: end-stage renal disease workgroup recommendations to the field

In 1997, The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation launched a national program Promoting Excellence in End-of-Life Care with a mission of improving care and quality of life for dying Americans and their families.

The End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) Workgroup worked to improve supportive care and quality of life for dialysis patients from Spring 2000 - Spring 2002. Chaired by Alvin Moss, MD (Director of the West Virginia University Center for Health Ethics and Law), this workgroup consisted of 23 members including nurses, social workers, nephrologists, and kidney transplant recipients. To accomplish its goals, the workgroup divided into three subgroups -- Education, Quality of Life, and Quality of Dying.

]]>

The files listed below are available for promotional use in libraries, education centres, research units, hospices, staff rooms and other locations as desired.

Hard copies of these are also available from us whenever we attend a conference, exhibition or other event.

Please check the content of each file carefully before you print. Some items are longer and/or use more colour than others, so may not be appropriate for your printing facilities or your requirements.

document.title: The effects of single-session music therapy interventions on the observed and self-reported levels of pain control, physical comfort, and relaxation of hospice patients
document.publisher: John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION,PAIN MANAGEMENT,PROFESSIONS,COMPLEMENTARY & ALTERNATIVE THERAPIES,MUSIC THERAPISTS]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ "This article describes the process and results of a three-month music therapy clinical effectiveness study conducted with terminally ill patients. The purpose of this study was to quantify and evaluate the effectiveness of single-session music therapy interventions with hospice patients in three patient problem areas: pain control; physical comfort; and relaxation."]]>

document.description: Draft depression guideline open to consultation
document.body: Overall objective is to produce an evidence-based clinical guideline for the management of depression in palliative care, on behalf of the European Palliative Care Research Collaborative (EPCRC http://www.epcrc.org). The EPCRC is a project funded by the European Commission’s Sixth Framework Programme, with the overall aim of improving the management of pain, depression and cachexia through translational research."]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: The treatment of lymphoedema / chronic oedema
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,LYMPHOEDEMA,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION,HAEMATOLOGIC AND LYMPHATIC DISEASES]]>
document.body:
111-1The treatment of lymphoedema / chronic oedema

Written by Dr Vaughan Keeley, Consultant in Palliative Medicine, Derby Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust.


 

The evidence base for treatments

 

Physical treatments

 

The main treatment for lymphoedema and other chronic oedemas is based upon a combination of physical treatments which include:

• compression  (garments or bandaging)
• massage  (manual lymphatic drainage, MLD, and simple lymph
drainage, SLD)
• exercise
• skin care


Whilst there is evidence that the combination of physical treatments is effective (Ko et al, 1998), there is little evidence to determine which components are more important and whether all elements are needed in all patients.  As a result, the Lymphoedema Framework project (a national project in the UK which aims to develop effective service models) has published an international consensus document (Lymphoedema Framework, 2006 a).  This is an important source of guidance on management based upon current knowledge.


Further guidance on compression garments and compression bandaging can be found in Lymphoedema Framework (2006 b) and European Wound Management Association (2005).

 

Drug therapies

 

i) Diuretics

Pure lymphoedema does not respond to diuretic therapy (BNF 2007).  However, diuretics may have a part to play in the management of more complex oedema where fluid retention or heart failure may contribute.

ii) Benzopyrones

Various benzopyrones (e.g. coumarin, oxerutins) have been recommended for the treatment of lymphoedema.  There is some evidence for a beneficial effect (Casley-Smith, 1999) but a recent Cochrane review concluded that there was no evidence to support their routine use in the management of lymphoedema (Badger et al, 2003).  Unfortunately, there have also been examples of hepatotoxicity with the use of coumarin, so it has been withdrawn in a number of countries including the UK.

iii) Corticosteroids

Corticosteroids may play a part in the management of chronic oedema in advanced cancer where there is metastatic lymphadenopathy (Keeley, 2000).

 

Management of cellulitis / acute inflammatory episodes

Patients with lymphoedema are at risk of developing recurrent episodes of cellulitis / acute inflammation as a result of a “local immune deficiency” due to the malfunctioning lymphatic system (Mallon et al,1997).


There has been debate about whether these episodes are due to infection with Streptococcal or Staphylococcal bacteria.  A group of clinicians has recently produced consensus guidelines on the management of cellulitis in lymphoedema (BLS/LSN, 2007).  These are based upon the concept that the majority of episodes are caused by ß-haemolytic streptococci.  The oral antibiotics recommended for home management are summarised in Table 1.


Table 1

Management of cellulitis in lymphoedema – at home with oral antibiotics

1. Amoxicillin 500 mg 8 hourly for at least 14 days.

2. Add Flucloxacillin 500 mg 6 hourly if Staphylococcus aureus infection is suspected e.g. folliculitis, pus formation or crusted dermatitis is present.

3. If patient is allergic to Penicillin, use Clindamycin 300 mg 6 hourly for at least 14 days.

 

If a patient fails to improve on this regimen or is systemically very unwell, admission to hospital for intravenous antibiotics is recommended. 

 

Prophylactic antibiotics (Penicillin V or Erythromycin) should be considered in patients who develop recurrent episodes of cellulitis (=2 per year).  In these patients the management of the lymphoedema is also reviewed, as a reduction in limb volume is associated with a reduced incidence of cellulitis (Ko et al, 1998).  Likely causes of infection e.g. ingrowing toenails, eczema, Athlete’s foot are treated appropriately.

 

Conclusions

Treatments are available for chronic oedemas but they are not curative and the evidence for their effectiveness is limited.  An international consensus document (Lymphoedema Framework, 2006 a) recommends best practice for management based upon the current evidence.

 

References

Badger C, Preston N, Seers K, Mortimer P (2003).  Benzo-pyrones for reducing and controlling lymphoedema of the limbs.  Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2003, Issue 4, Art No: CD003143.

BLS/LSN (2007).  Consensus guidelines on the management of cellulitis in lymphoedema available at www.thebls.com and www.lymphoedema.org/lsn.

British National Formulary (2007).  British National Formulary 53.  BMJ Publishing Group and RPS Publishing, London.

Casley-Smith JR (1999).  Benzo-pyrones in the treatment of lymphoedema.  Int. Angiol. 18(1): 31-41

European Wound Management Association (EWMA) (2005).  Focus Document: Lymphoedema bandaging in practice.  London: MEP Ltd.

Keeley V (2000).  Oedema in advanced cancer.  In: Twycross R, Jenns K, Todd J, eds. Lymphoedema.  Radcliffe Medical Press, Oxford: 338-58.

Ko DSC, Lerner R, Klose G et al (1998).  Effective treatment of lymphoedema of the extremities.  Arch. Surg. 133: 452-458.

Lymphoedema Framework (2006 a).  Best Practice for the Management of Lymphoedema.  International consensus.  London: MEP Ltd. 

Lymphoedema Framework (2006 b).  Template for Practice: compression hosiery in lymphoedema.  London: MEP Ltd.

Mallon E, Powell S, Mortimer P et al (1997).  Evidence of altered cell mediated immunity in post-mastectomy lymphoedema.  Br. J. Dermatol. 137: 928-933.

 

]]>

document.body:
111-1Trans-Pennine palliative care research meeting

Network for researchers, and clinical staff in supportive and palliative care.  

 

"The aim is to provide a platform for discussions with colleagues interested in the field of supportive and palliative care research.  The meeting is open to all, whether you are an experienced researcher, a junior colleague or a newcomer in this field, or maybe not yet started on your first project. "

Professor Sam H  Ahmedzai
Head of Academic Unit of Supportive Care, University of Sheffield.

 

The 10th Trans-Pennine palliative care research meeting will be on Thursday 20th May 2010

Venue = The Source, Meadowhall, Sheffield S9 1EA.

 

All enquiries to the conference secretary:

Pauline Hutchinson
Sykes House
Little Common Lane
Sheffield  S11 9NE
Tel: +44 (0) 114 262 0174
Email: spcsg-conferences@sheffield.ac.uk

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: User involvement and End of Life Care. Contextualising User Involvement
document.publisher: National Library for Health: Supportive and Palliative Care Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,FAMILIES & CARERS,DEATH,COMMUNICATION ISSUES,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,COMMISSIONING,MIGRATED RESOURCES (HEALTH MANAGEMENT - COMMISSIONING)]]>
document.body:
111-1User involvement and End of Life Care. Contextualising User Involvement

Back to the CONTENTS PAGE

 

“We’re people, we’re not just nuisances”

Patient, User Forum, St Christopher’s, 1 April 2008

 

The 55 year-old service user with Parkinson’s Disease who expressed this view as she talked of her local hospital, is not alone. The ‘a person’ not ‘a number’ plea has been expressed repeatedly and yet services struggle still to bring to reality personalised care. The Healthcare Commission’s analysis of the 16,000 complaints it received for independent review between July 2004 and July 2006 revealed that 54% of complaints about hospitals related to care surrounding a death - what better indication is there of the need to get better engaged with and access the views of the people who experience services?

The challenge to capture the individual voice of service users and carers as well as the collective voice is great in end of life care. Users have increasingly become involved in care, and service delivery, research and education. The statutory requirements for the NHS to consult users and the public is another motivating factor (DH, 2008). For end of life care to be truly person-focused, the first and ultimate partnership needs to be with service users and carers to develop ways to overcome their main criticisms of end of life systems and pathways of care. There needs to be a multiplicity of ways to engage and listen better to individual users and carers and the communities to which they belong.

The particular challenges for user involvement in end of life care relate to the advanced nature of patients’ illnesses; fluctuating nature of patients’ conditions; patients’ preoccupations with immediate symptoms and other pressing care needs; the difficulties in attending external consultation meetings and forums; the high dependence on carers with a differing sets of views and priorities; the time-consuming nature of effective user engagement; the additional practical support required to enable participation by people with advanced illnesses; and accessing and engaging with the diversity of users and carers.

Still, experience has shown that providers can start small and provide a ‘mixed economy’ of ways for users and carers to communicate with them. In addition to eliciting feedback through conventional surveys, audits and analysis of complaints, providers of end of life care services have begun by using opportunities to meet users in small groups at out-patients clinics or in day centres, in advertised user forums and by encouraging written or email feedback.

The National Council for Palliative Care has planned a facility for users and carers to provide online feedback on aspects of care or to contribute ideas for improved user involvement. Even if this facility is only used once or twice by a patient, it can feel empowering and satisfying to have fed back on experiences in the system of care, especially when this contributes to better information for service planners and commissioners.

Service users and carers are not all passive recipients of care: we need to recognise and harness their own professional competence, life experience and individual skills.

We need to judge when to facilitate people to use their own resources and means to suggest changes and improvements to services for their own personalised care or at an organisational level. At other times, we are required to be more active advocates for users and carers. However, it is preferable that people are empowered to have their own voice heard. The creation of specific user involvement facilities is one clear way forward.

The Expert Patients’ and planned Caring with Confidence Programmes build on the empowerment of users and carers and extends it further. The new LINks (Local Involvement Networks) provide another opportunity for local communities to have a voice (Expert Patients’ Programme 2008; Caring with Confidence 2008; National Centre for Involvement 2008).

For involvement to be real, it will be at all levels in the organisation in order to increase the power base of those who use the services, for example, at the start of a new scheme, as it is being devised and designed, not just after all key decisions have been made. In fact, the use of blogs and other electronic means of communication are perhaps already changing the balance of power between users and providers. It is also important to remember that often users suggest small changes but it can be the smaller changes that create a bigger picture of change over time.

“It is not just about being a passive ‘data source’. It is a more active process, involving people in speaking for and acting for themselves.”
(Croft and Beresford, 2007)

Case study – structure of user involvement at St Christopher’s Hospice

User involvement is concerned with the meaningful and active participation
and consultation of service users (patients, clients and carers), according to their ability and experience and from their unique perspective, in aspects of:

  • Their own care
  • Service planning
  • Service delivery
  • Audit/evaluation/research
  • Staff training

As with many palliative care providers, St Christopher’s facilitates a ‘mixed method economy’ of methods and opportunities to engage the user voice:

  • User Forum
  • Individual feedback and interviews with users
  • Surveys of users, carers, visitors
  • Audits
  • Users’ Education Advisory Group

User Forum – Summary. An example of one activity

  • Aims to gain insight into the views of home and day care patients
  • All users and carers are invited, ie self-selection
  • 12-45 patients, including some carers, 3 times per year
  • 11-3pm, including lunch, with  short facilitated group sessions
  • Essential support – transport and nurse on duty

Feedback to all departments at Clinical Governance meetings

The primary purpose of the User Forum is to gain insight into the views and experiences of home and day care patients in order to improve service delivery.  The proceedings, which run from about 11am to 3pm are facilitated by the Director of Education and the Quality Assurance Adviser, neither of whom are engaged in clinical activity, the idea being that this will make it more likely that participants will feel able to feed back the negatives as well as the positives.  Attendees, made up of patients and carers, are invited to form small groups of 5-8 people and to consider their experiences of the care and various services at St Christopher’s.  Occasionally the groups will be asked to comment on a new patient information leaflet (a useful jargon-busting exercise). A report to heads of department and a trustee at the Clinical Governance Committee contains recommendations and comments. The Committee decides on any actions arising from these, and changes made as a result of the comments are reported to participants by letter. Typical suggestions have mostly been practical ones such as improved signage around the hospice, more varied menus in day care, better information about help with transport.

A secondary purpose has been to increase the knowledge and uptake of services, especially new ones. So, for example, our complementary therapists have spoken to  the group about a new home-based service for carers and encouraged people to ask questions. We found that the discussion prompted some male patients, who had previously dismissed complementary therapy, to refer themselves.

There have been, and continue to be, challenges. The biggest of these is to distil, from the personal accounts of individuals, messages for the organisation.  For example, patients and carers repeatedly praise the care and services they receive, despite the facilitators’ vigorous attempts at encouraging them to identify areas for improvement. But there is a reason for this:  patients’ stories tell us that their expectations on arrival at St Christopher’s are coloured by fear and apprehension, hence their relief at finding that hospices are places where you can laugh and enjoy life.  (What they tell us about their expectations has helped us develop our public education activities).

Another challenge is the uncertainty of who will turn up on the day- inevitably there is a big gap between the number of patients who say they will attend, and the number who make it on the day.  Catering and nursing support arrangements have to take this into account.  In order to increase numbers, we stopped asking patients’ clinical nurse specialists to identify patients well enough to be invited, and instead requested the names only of those who were too ill to attend. This has resulted in improved attendance (up to 45 patients and carers per event).

Carer attendance itself has increased to the point where they have requested their own separate discussion groups at the Forum.  They say that they gain a strong sense of support from this. 

All the above related to home and day care users. What about patients in the in-patient unit? We tried arranging an in-patient forum, but patients were often too frail for more than a couple to attend.  The Quality Assurance Adviser therefore visited patients and asked them about their experiences individually. This has now been superseded by research to develop a tool that will help us to identify patient-generated outcomes, so that we can discover by this means how well we are meeting patients’ objectives.

 

References

 

  • Caring with Confidence (2008) Introducing Caring with Confidence
    Leeds: Caring with Confidence
    http://www.caringwithconfidence.net/publications (accessed 9/1/09)

 

  • Croft S and Beresford P (2007) Foreword. In Jarrett L (ed) Creative engagement in palliative care. New perspectives on user involvement. Abingdon: Radcliffe Publishing

 

  • Department of Health (2008) Real involvement: working with people to improve services. London:  Department of Health
    http://www.dh.gov.uk/en/Publicationsandstatistics/Publications/PublicationsPolicyAndGuidance/DH_089787   (accessed 8/1/09)

 

  • Expert Patients’ Programme (2008)  Progress Report. London: Expert Patients Programme.
    http://www.expertpatients.co.uk/public/cms/uploads/ProgressReport08.pdf
    (accessed 2008)

 

  • National Centre for Involvement (2008)  Local Involvement Networks (LINks). Checking progress. Warwick: NHS Centre for Involvement
    http://www.nhscentreforinvolvement.nhs.uk/docs/Guide%2015%20-%20Checklist.pdf  (accessed 6/1/09)

 

Denise Brady (Librarian), David Oliviere (Director of Education and Training), Education Centre, St Christopher’s Hospice

January 2008

 

Back to the CONTENTS PAGE

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Palliative and Supportive Care]]>
document.title: Using strong opioids in advanced chronic kidney disease - what is the evidence?
document.publisher: National Library for Palliative and Supportive Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ RENAL DISEASES,MEDICINES,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION,CONDITIONS,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,KIDNEY DISEASES,INTERVENTIONS,OTHERS,CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE,KIDNEY DISEASES AND MALE UROGENITAL DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
111-1Using strong opioids in advanced chronic kidney disease - what is the evidence?

Written by Claire A Douglas, Specialist Registrar in Palliative Medicine, Ninewells Hospital, NHS Tayside, and Fliss Murtagh, Research Training Fellow, Department of Palliative Care, Policy & Rehabilitation, King’s College London.

 

Introduction

A recent systematic literature review has shown that pain is common, both in dialysis patients (1), and in those with stage 5 chronic kidney disease (CKD) managed without dialysis (2). Studies of those dying with advanced CKD also indicate that although most appear to have a ‘good death’, a significant minority experience distressing symptoms, including pain (3) (4) (5). Achieving good pain control for these patients is therefore important.

 

What level of renal impairment?

The UK CKD guidelines (6) classify CKD into five stages, according to estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR). The evidence presented here applies largely to Stages 4 or 5 CKD, when eGFR is = 30 mL per minute. At these levels of renal impairment, drug metabolism is significantly altered and the risk of toxicity from accumulation of renally-excreted drugs is high.

 

When to apply this evidence?

This evidence applies to those NOT on dialysis, either because they are being managed conservatively (without dialysis) or because they have withdrawn from dialysis, since these are the patients most usually seen by palliative professionals. There are additional considerations for the patient who remains on dialysis (7) (8).

 

Which strong opioid to use?

Certain opioids cause significant toxicity. Evidence for each of the main opioids is provided in turn; much of this evidence is detailed more fully elsewhere (8) (9) (10) (11) (12).

Alfentanil Alfentanil is a very short-acting opioid that undergoes hepatic metabolism to inactive, non-toxic metabolites which are renally cleared. Only 1% of the parent unchanged drug is excreted by the kidneys (13). Small pharmacokinetic studies have shown that in patients with renal failure, there is no change in volume of distribution or elimination half-life, with no reports of adverse effects in renal failure (14). Of all the strong opioids, it has the most evidence to support its safety in severe renal impairment.

Buprenorphine Buprenorphine is a potent partial ?-opioid receptor agonist. It is metabolised in the liver to norbuprenorphine, and buprenorphine-3-glucuronide (B-3-G) (15). These metabolites are excreted via the kidney, while unchanged buprenorphine is excreted principally via the biliary system (11) (15). There has been little evaluation in renal failure to date. In a single-dose study, the pharmacokinetics of the parent drug appeared unchanged in renal failure, but metabolites were not measured (16). Metabolite levels during continuous infusion are significantly higher in severe renal impairment (15) but with wide individual variation. However, norbuprenorphine is 40 times less potent analgesically than buprenorphine, while B-3-G is analgesically inactive (15). Both these studies recorded no adverse effects, but animal studies have identified respiratory depression (17) (18).

Fentanyl Fentanyl is metabolised to inactive and non-toxic compounds, and the metabolites (and 10% of unchanged fentanyl) are excreted by the kidneys (12). Controversies exist about the influence of renal failure. One study showed that patients with severe renal impairment had normal clearance and distribution of the drug after a single bolus injection (19), but further evidence shows reduction in clearance in renal impairment (20). An increase in half-life and distribution volume has been reported after continuous infusion, but without reports of adverse effects (21). This evidence suggests it is safer in CKD than morphine or diamorphine. 

Hydromorphone Hydromorphone is metabolised to hydromorphone-3-glucuronide (H-3-G) which accumulates in renal failure (22).  The activity of H-3-G in humans is not fully established although it is known to be neuro-excitatory in rats.  One study looked at pain management in patients with cancer and  renal impairment (23) and suggests that renally-impaired patients tolerate morphine better than hydromorphone.  The study is a retrospective design and the range of creatinine levels reported suggest that the participants had only mild renal failure.  There is little or no evidence in more severe renal impairment.

Methadone Methadone is a synthetic opioid with high volume of distribution. It is metabolised primarily by the liver and the main metabolite, 1.5-dimethyl-2-ethyl-3,3-diphenyl-1-pyrroline, is excreted in the faeces, although renal excretion of the unchanged drug is also an important route of methadone elimination. It displays large pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic inter-individual variations and considerable difference between acute and chronic phase dosing, with accumulation of methadone on repeated administration in tissues due to its high volume of distribution. There is some evidence which suggests plasma concentrations are no higher than in those with normal renal function (24), suggesting that faecal excretion might compensate in those with renal impairment.

Morphine and diamorphine Morphine and diamorphine are metabolised to morphine-3-glucuronide (M-3-G) (55%), morphine-6-glucuronide (M-6-G) (10%) and normorphine (4%). These metabolites (and approximately 10% of morphine) are excreted unchanged by the kidneys (25). M-6-G is a potent analgesic and central nervous system depressant. Pharmacokinetic studies show that M-6-G and morphine accumulate in ESRD (26). Studies report significant narcosis, toxic agitation and profound respiratory depression following the use of morphine in patients with ESRD (8) (11). Patients with advanced CKD are therefore at significant risk of toxicity if given morphine or diamorphine. Morphine and diamorphine are therefore not recommended, as better alternative opioids are available.

Oxycodone Oxycodone is metabolised to oxymorphone and noroxycodone; oxymorphone has minimal opioid activity in humans with normal renal function, but 10% of oxycodone is excreted unchanged by the kidneys, so toxicity may occur with regular use (27).  In one small study in renal impairment, clearance of oxycodone and its metabolites was delayed, although adverse effects from this were not reported (28). There is little further data on the use of oxycodone in patients with renal failure. The pharmacokinetics of oxycodone suggest that it may be safer than morphine, but as the evidence is currently very limited, oxycodone cannot be recommended.

 

General recommendations

All strong opioids should be used cautiously, with dose reduction and increased dosing interval. Early review and regular monitoring should be undertaken, since accumulation of opioids and subsequent adverse effects can occur very rapidly. In general, it is best to avoid the longer acting preparations and use short-acting preparations whenever possible. It is beyond the scope of this article to give detailed clinical and dosing information but this can be found elsewhere (9) (10).

 

Specific recommendations

Alfentanil and fentanyl can be cautiously recommended, and are probably the optimum opioids to use at the end of life when an injectable strong opioid is needed. Several clinical and practical considerations (other than safety) need to be taken into consideration; for instance, the short half-life of alfentanil makes it less practical for break-through pain, although it is appropriate for continuous infusion.

Earlier in the illness trajectory, transdermal fentanyl can be used, provided there is careful titration of dose, and early regular review to watch for accumulation. Transdermal buprenorphine is increasingly widely used clinically, without reports of adverse effects, although the evidence to support this remains very limited. For oral preparations, oxycodone, hydromorphone and buprenorphine all have very limited evidence to indicate whether they are safe or not, although buprenorphine is increasingly used clinically, and both hydromorphone and oxycodone are likely better than morphine or diamorphine. Methadone appears to be safe, and is generally used second line or for neuropathic pain – it should however be used by clinicians who are experienced in its use, given the wide individual variation and late accumulation.

 

In stage 4 and 5 CKD, morphine and diamorphine should be avoided where possible.

 

References

(1)  Murtagh F, Addington-Hall J, Higginson IJ. The prevalence of symptoms in end-stage renal disease: a systematic review. Advances in Chronic Kidney Disease 2007;14(1):82-99.

 

(2)  Murtagh F, Addington-Hall J, Edmonds P, Donohoe P, Carey I, Jenkins K, et al. Symptoms in advanced renal disease - a cross-sectional survey of symptom prevalence in stage 5 chronic kidney disease managed without dialysis. Journal of Palliative Medicine 2007;10 (6):in press.

 

(3)  Cohen LM, Germain M, Poppel DM, Woods A, Kjellstrand CM. Dialysis discontinuation and palliative care. American Journal of Kidney Diseases 2000 Jul; 36(1):140-4.

 

(4)  Cohen LM, McCue JD, Germain M, Kjellstrand CM. Dialysis discontinuation. A 'good' death? Arch Intern Med 1995 Jan 9;155(1):42-9.
